text:
Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee 
bean characteristics 
Jarrod Kath a,*, Vivekananda Mittahalli Byrareddy a, Shahbaz Mushtaq a, 
Alessandro Craparo b, Mario Porcel c 
a Centre for Applied Climate Sciences, University of Southern Queensland, Toowoomba, Queensland 4350, Australia 
b International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT), Hanoi, Viet Nam 
c Corporaci´on Colombiana de Investigaci´on Agropecuaria (AGROSAVIA), C.I.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
La Libertad, Vía Puerto L´opez Km 17, Meta, Colombia   
A R T I C L E  I N F O   
Keywords: 
Drought 
Extreme rainfall 
Harvest 
Heat 
Insect pests 
A B S T R A C T   
Robusta coffee is the primary source of income for millions of smallholder farmers throughout the 
world’s tropics.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The price smallholder farmers can get for their coffee is strongly influenced by 
bean characteristics (i.e.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: beans are of a sufficient size and have minimal defects).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Climate is a key 
determinant of successful coffee production, but scant research has been undertaken to test and 
quantify climate impacts on robusta coffee bean physical characteristics. Here we investigate how 
climate relates to the risk of poor coffee bean characteristics in one of South East Asia’s key coffee 
producing areas, the central highlands of Vietnam.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
We use 5 years (2012–2016) of coffee bean 
characteristic data from 60 farms.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Hierarchical modelling was used to investigate how rainfall 
and temperature related to two indicators of coffee bean characteristics (1) the probability of 
below average coffee bean size and (2) the probability of above average coffee bean defects.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Low 
rainfall (<1600 mm) during the late growing season (July-September) greatly increased the risk 
(>80% probability) of below average coffee bean size. Conversely, high rainfall (>750 mm) and 
high mean minimum temperature (>22 ◦C) during harvest (October-December) increased the risk 
(>75% probability) of above average coffee bean defects.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Various coffee bean characteristic 
subcomponents (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
insect damage and mouldy beans) and different bean sizes were also 
examined and were affected by a range of rainfall and temperature predictors across the flow­
ering, growing and harvest seasons.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
With this information targeted risk-management strategies (e. 
g. targeted irrigation during hot and dry growing seasons, adjusting harvest timing and 
employing drying techniques during wet and cold harvest periods) could be developed to mini­
mise the effect of climate conditions that increase the risk of coffee bean defects.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Successfully 
managing the impacts identified here, could decrease coffee bean defects and in turn increase the 
incomes of smallholder coffee farmers.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Introduction 
Robusta coffee (Coffea canephora, Pierre ex A. Froehner) supplies up to 40% of the world’s coffee and is a critical export for many 
tropical developing countries (ICO, 2019).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
With rainfall and temperatures projected to change in many important coffee producing

Climate Risk Management 32 (2021) 100281
2
areas (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
South East Asia, Chotamonsak et al., 2011; Dai, 2013) a key threat to the future sustainability of coffee production is climate 
variability and change (Moat et al., 2017; Kath et al., 2020).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
There has been some research on how farmers can maintain and increase 
robusta coffee yields under different climatic conditions (e.g. by managing biodiversity and optimizing inputs, DaMatta and Ramalho, 
2006; Byrareddy et al., 2020), but little on the climatic drivers of robusta coffee bean characteristics.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
This is a surprising knowledge gap 
given that price reductions caused by coffee bean defects and the importance of robusta for millions of the world’s farmers.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The chemical composition of green coffee beans is not only determined by species and variety, but also influenced by a number of 
different factors including; the terroir, harvesting methods (handpicked or mechanical), seed processing (wet, dry, or semi dry) and 
storage (Franca et al., 2005; Casas et al., 2017).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Ultimately, this chemical composition is what determines the price the coffee will 
attain. In order to objectively set a price, the coffee is commonly categorized or graded using three approaches: i) by types and defects, 
ii) by bean size (sieve) and iii) beverage quality (Brighenti and Cirillo, 2018).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Understanding the factors that affect coffee bean 
characteristics is a key knowledge requirement for coffee farmers as it ultimately determines the price farmers can get for their coffee 
crop (Boscollo.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: L. pers comm.).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
More importantly, the ability to tease apart the determinants of intrinsic coffee defects (quantification 
and importance of meteorological variables) underpins the development of management strategies that could mitigate the financial 
losses incurred by farmers.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Research on arabica coffee beans has emphasised the importance of rainfall and temperature (Vaast et al., 2006; Santos et al., 2015; 
Bote and Vos, 2017).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Higher temperatures accelerate berry ripening and in turn increase bean defects (Vaast et al., 2006; Santos et al., 
2015).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The amount and timing of rainfall can also affect coffee beans – too little rainfall during the growing season stresses plants, 
causing branch death and defoliation, reducing resources for fruiting and leading to small and damaged coffee beans (DaMatta et al.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
High temperatures can accelerate berry development and ripening (Craparo et al., 2015), which reduces bean filling and in turn 
causes smaller bean sizes (DaMatta et al., 2018).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Unfavourable rainfall and temperature can also promote the conditions that damage and discolour coffee beans. Too much rainfall 
can dislodge flowers and fruits, or if heavy rain occurs during harvest, increased moisture favours conditions for mould growth, disease 
and excessive fermentation, all of which may increase coffee bean defects (Taniwaki et al., 2014).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Alongside increased moisture from 
high rainfall, higher temperatures can also promote mould growth, as well as damaging insects, such as the coffee berry borer 
(Hypothenemus hampei) and mealybugs – the reproductive rates of which are closely linked to temperature (Jaramillo et al., 2009; 
Jayakumar and Rajavel, 2019).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Despite the potentially important role that climate has in driving factors known to damage coffee beans 
there has been little research on the impacts of rainfall and temperature on robusta beans throughout the production cycle (i.e.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
from 
flowering through to harvest).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Fig.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Vietnam with the study province (Lam Dong) in black in the coffee producing areas of the central highlands.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: J. Kath et al.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Climate Risk Management 32 (2021) 100281
3
It is not well tested whether robusta coffee bean characteristics respond to temperature and rainfall variation in a similar way as 
arabica beans. Arabica yields are more sensitive to temperature increases than robusta (Craparo et al., 2015; Martins et al., 2018; Kath 
et al., 2020), but it is unknown whether this is also the case for coffee bean size and defects.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Previous studies in the key robusta growing 
areas of South East Asia have focused on robusta coffee yields sensitivity to climate variability (Kath et al., 2020; Byrareddy et al., 
2020).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Kath et al.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: (2020) showed strong relationships between temperatures and yields.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
In the central highlands of Vietnam, Byrareddy 
et al.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: (2020) has also examined the impact of irrigation practices and drought on coffee yields.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
However, these studies did not look at 
the relationship between climate and robusta coffee bean characteristics, which along with yield, are key determinants of how much 
farmers get payed for their coffee. To address this gap, here we investigate the impact of rainfall and temperature on two economically important indicators of coffee 
beans, (1) the probability of small coffee bean size and (2) the probability of high coffee bean defects, both of which are metrics used to 
determine the price a farmer can get for their coffee crop (K’ Doan ECOM, pers.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: comm, 5 February 2020).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
We hypothesise that climatic 
conditions will influence the likelihood of undesirable robusta coffee bean characteristics occurring (hereafter referring to bean size 
and bean defects) in two ways.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
First, low rainfall during the growing season will increase plant stress and in so doing, reduce fruit 
development and ultimately coffee bean size. Second, high temperatures and rainfall during the growing season and harvest will 
promote conditions that increase the risk of bean defects (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: mouldy and insect damaged beans).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Methods 
2.1.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Study area 
The study was in the central highlands of Vietnam, one of the world’s most important robusta coffee producing areas.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
To investigate 
the impact of climate on robusta coffee beans we used data from Vietnamese farmers.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Vietnam is the largest exporter of robusta coffee 
in the world, accounting for 40% of the world’s supply (Marsh, 2007). Based on 2018/19 market prices (USD1.62/kg), the estimated 
value of robusta coffee exports for Vietnam is ~USD 2.8 billion per annum (USDA, 2019).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The main robusta coffee producing areas are located in the Central Highlands of Southern Vietnam, encompassing the provinces 
Lam Dong, Dak Lak, Dak Nong, Gia Lai, and Kon Tum. These areas account for > 90% of Vietnam’s robusta coffee production (D’haeze 
et al., 2005).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Within the Central Highlands, coffee bean data was collected from 30 farmers from Bao Loc and Bao Lam districts (total 
number of farms was 60) in Lam Dong province (Fig.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: 1) over 5 seasons from 2012 to 16 (total n = 300).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
This is a different dataset, 
covering a smaller spatial and temporal scale, than that examined by Kath et al.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Over the study period from 2012 to 2016 mean annual minimum and maximum temperatures in the region were 21.8 ◦C and 
29.9 ◦C respectively, while mean total annual rainfall was 2128 mm (NCHMF, 2018).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The coffee growing season in Lam Dong runs 
from January to September.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Flowering runs from approximately January to February.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The early growing season (including cherry 
development) from March to June, while the late growing season (including cherry maturation) from July to September.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Harvest is 
from late October to December.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Rainfall in the Central Highlands is usually concentrated around the summer monsoon (May-October).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
However, the rainy season 
onset data (RSOD) is primarily driven by El Ni˜no-Southern Oscillation (ENSO), which is responsible for substantial variation between 
years and regions (Pham-Thanh et al., 2020).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The RSOD generally starts later in El Ni˜no years and earlier during a La Ni˜na (Pham- 
Thanh et al., 2020).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Likewise, total precipitation and precipitation intensity (number of days with heavy rain) has increased over the 
years and will continue to do so in future (Schmidt-Thome et al., 2015; Pham-Thanh et al., 2020).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
In accordance with other regions of 
SE-Asia, temperatures have increased over Vietnam and are projected to increase further under future climate scenarios (Schmidt- 
Thome et al., 2015).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Robusta coffee cultivation practices 
Coffee in the study area is cultivated under open sun, with some inter-cropping of fruit and timber trees.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Overall, farms ranged from 
0.2 to 6.0 ha in size and were located between 694 and 905 masl.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
In the study region, bean yield varied between 2.8 and 6.8 ton−1 ha, 
and average yield recorded at 3.8 ton−1 ha.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Plants are irrigated during the dry season (January – April) to synchronize flowering and 
fruit setting, and to protect the crop from droughts and boost production (Byrareddy et al., 2020).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The major fertilizer types applied are 
blended NPK, urea, superphosphate and potassium chloride) in addition to compost and lime and is applied around four times in year 
(Byrareddy et al., 2019).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The major pest and disease affecting the crop are respectively mealybugs (Hemiptera: Pseudococcidae) and 
anthracnose (Colletotrichum spp.).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Farmers rely on chemical control as the main pest and disease management strategy.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The harvest is 
carried out manually by hand picking in 2–3 rounds, farmers collect the coffee cherries and dry them under open sun prior to pro­
cessing.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The surveyed farmers reported, drying and hulling of cherries takes about 8 to 10 sunshine days, and if it rains during this 
period they protect it by using plastic sheets.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Coffee bean and climate data 
Coffee bean data was collected after the completion of harvest and processing of coffee cherries into beans during January in each 
year.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Samples were collected directly from coffee farms. At each farm a composite sample was drawn, using a coffee bean sampler to 
draw a random sample of beans. Each sample was mixed thoroughly to make a composite representative sample weighing about 1500 
g, which was then used for analysis of bean characteristics.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: J. Kath et al.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Climate Risk Management 32 (2021) 100281
4
Two indicators of coffee bean characteristics were calculated (1) coffee bean size and (2) total coffee bean defects.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
These two 
indicators are used to price coffee beans, with good scores of coffee bean size and low defects leading to higher prices (up to 25% higher 
relative to gross returns), while poor scores can lead to losses of ~ 10%. When these two coffee bean metrics are poor (i.e.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
when bean 
defects are high and bean size small) farmers can lose up to a third of their gross returns (K’ Doan ECOM, pers.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
comm, 5 February 
2020).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Coffee bean size was assessed based on ISO 4150 (Size analysis — Manual and machine sieving).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
This involved transferring a 100 g 
test portion into a series of sieves of descending screen sizes (16 (largest) to 12 (smallest)).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Coffee beans were then agitated on sieves by 
hand for 3 min so that beans covered the whole perforated surface.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
After this the sieves were tapped once on a firm surface so that any 
beans loosely retained in the holes fell into the next sieve size.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The amount of coffee retained on each sieve and in the receiver was then 
weighed and transformed to a percentage (ISO, 2011).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Bean defects were calculated as in ISO 10,470 (Green coffee — Defect reference 
chart).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Sample size for defect counts was based on a representative sample of 300 g. The percentage of total defect beans, which 
included those with foreign matter (stones, sticks and husk), black, broken and brown beans, mouldy beans and insect damaged beans 
(after ISO, 2004), was calculated for each sample. From the dataset collected in this analysis, bean size and bean defects measurements 
were converted to above and below average (more than 11% total defects and less than 75% with a bean size above 16) (Table 1) for 
analysis so results could be presented as a probability that is directly interpretable by farmers and industry for risk management.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
All 
measurements were made at ECOM Agroindustrials Coffee Laboratory, Ecom Bao Loc factory, Bao Loc (Dist), Lam Dong province.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Descriptive statistics of the coffee bean data used are in Table 1.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Daily precipitation, mean, minimum and maximum temperature data was obtained from weather stations within 3 km of farms, i.e.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Boa Lac (Latitude = 11.55, Longitude = 107.81) and Boa Lam (Longitude = 107.91, Latitude = 11.55) stations from the Vietnamese 
National Centre for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting (NCHMF, 2018).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: These stations collect daily data on rainfall and temperature.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Climate variables for different coffee phenological stages; flowering (January-February), the early growing season (March-June) the 
late growing season (July-September) and harvest (October-December) (adapted from Kath et al., 2020) were calculated for total 
rainfall, average temperature, minimum temperature and maximum temperature.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Across the study period during the growing and 
harvest season mean total rainfall was 1620 and 508 mm respectively.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Mean minimum and maximum growing season temperatures 
were respectively 21.9 ◦C and 30.2 ◦C, while during harvest they were 21.6 ◦C and 29.0 ◦C.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Analyses 
The probability of certain coffee bean characteristics occurring was quantified using hierarchical models (also referred to as mixed- 
effect or multi-level models), which included climate variables as fixed effects, as well as random effects to account for potential spatial 
and temporal correlations (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: from annual repeat measurements at a particular site).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Traditional non-hierarchal linear regression 
models do not account for repeat measures or non-independence in observations.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
For example, bean characteristic observations at a 
site, or within particular years, may be more similar (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
higher on average if soils and management techniques are better) relative to 
other sites or during different years.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
To account for this, hierarchical modelling allows for the intercept (or baseline) in the model to 
vary amongst the same sites and years.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Hierarchical statistical models efficiently account for the influence of these grouping factors (e. 
g. site and year) and eliminate many problems associated with spatial and temporal autocorrelation, pseudo-replication and also 
reduce the risk of Type I and II errors (Bolker et al., 2009; Harrison et al., 2018).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Importantly, in the context of this study because 
hierarchical models allow for the intercept to vary, this enabled us to quantify the effect of rainfall and temperature on coffee bean 
characteristics, while accounting for differences between sites (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
management practices) and the non-independence of coffee bean 
data at each site.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Generalized linear mixed models (GLMMs) are a type of hierarchical modelling that extend linear mixed models (which include 
random effects) to non-normal data types such as counts or binary data, which widely occur in environmental studies (Bolker et al., 
2009).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
GLMMs were used to model the probability of coffee bean characteristics for the indicators assessed as a function of climate 
parameters.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: A separate model for each coffee bean characteristic sub-component (i.e.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
each defect and size class) was fit using a logit 
link and a binomial distribution.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: All models were fit in R version 3.6.0 (R Core Team, 2019) using the lme4 package (Bates et al., 2015).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Climate predictor variables (i.e.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
inputs) modelled as fixed effects using GLMMs were mean minimum temperature, mean average 
temperature, mean maximum temperature and total rainfall during the flowering, early growing, late growing and harvest seasons.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Models included two-way interactions between rainfall and each temperature variable within each season.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Predictors were stand­
ardised [mean(x)/1.sd(x)] so effect sizes could be compared.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Random effects were site and the year of each survey.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Predictors which 
were correlated at Pearson r ≥0.7, the level at which collinearity can bias regressions, were not combined in the same model (Dormann 
et al., 2013) (see Supplementary S1 for correlations between all climate predictors).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Model performance was assessed by calculating 
receiver operator characteristic (ROC) curve values using the Hmisc package (Harrell and Dupont, 2020) in R (R Core Team, 2019).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
ROC values over 0.9 indicate an excellent model, values between 0.8 and 0.9 a good model, values between 0.7 and 0.8 an acceptable

model, values between 0.6 and 0.7 a poor model and values of 0.5 indicate no ability to predict the outcome.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The most parsimonious set of climate predictors for each of the coffee bean characteristic indicators was selected using automated 
model selection through subsetting the maximum model using the MuMIn package (Barton et al., 2020) in R (R Core Team, 2019).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Model selection was performed using Akaike’s Information Criterion (AIC).

text:
Discussion 
We hypothesised that low rainfall during the growing season will reduce fruit development and ultimately coffee bean size and that 
higher rainfall and temperatures during the growing season and harvest will increase the likelihood of bean defects. In contrast to our 
first hypothesis, our analysis suggested that while low rainfall during the late growing season was associated with smaller beans, low 
rainfall during the early growing season and flowering had the opposite effect.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Therefore, our results suggest that there are important 
seasonal differences in how climate affects robusta coffee bean size. In regard to our second hypothesis we showed that higher rainfall 
and temperatures during the growing season and harvest were associated with an increased chance of coffee bean defects, but that the 
effect of rainfall interacted with temperature. We discuss these results about coffee bean defect and size responses to climate across 
seasons below.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Climate risk and coffee bean size 
No studies have previously investigated robusta coffee bean responses to climate in South East Asia.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Although, Martins et al.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
(2018) 
did suggest that robusta production in Brazil is highly sensitive to periods of low rainfall.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Our findings are also consistent with previous 
research suggesting differences in arabica coffee bean size were associated with low rainfall (Cannell, 1974).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Cannell (1974) argued 
that drought increased water stress and prevented ovules from reaching full size while fruits expanded, thus resulting in smaller coffee 
beans.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
In this study, rainfall and temperatures influenced coffee bean size across all of the size classes examined, although their effect 
varied depending on the season.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Dry and warm conditions in the late growing season lowered the likelihood of getting large beans. In 
contrast, dryer and warmer conditions during flowering and the early growing season seemed to favour the development of large 
beans.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: The seasonal differential response of coffee to drought has been well documented.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Moisture stress triggers flowering in coffee and 
so excessive rain and cool conditions during the quiescent growth phase can repress flowering, and in turn yields (DaMatta & Ramalho, 
Fig.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Across South East Asia, Kath et al.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
(2020) showed that while high temperatures coupled with dry conditions were the most 
favourable for robusta productivity during flowering, during growing the opposite was the case, with lower temperatures and high 
rainfall during the growing season being most favourable.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Likewise, the results of this study suggest robusta coffee bean size is 
differentially influenced by climatic factors with responses depending on whether it is the flowering or growing season.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Responses to climate were largely consistent across size classes, with large beans response being the inverse of small beans.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Although, it should be noted that the model for very small beans (bean screen size under 12) only contained variables from the early 
growing season, whereas all other size classes contained variables from flowering, early growing and late growing seasons.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
This could 
suggest that climatic conditions during the early growing season as the cherry begins to form, is a key period of vulnerability.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
It could 
be that heat stress during this period increases the risk of stunting coffee beans, causing them to remain very small (under a screen size 
Fig.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
High rainfall during harvest increases the risk of coffee bean defects 
Higher rainfall during harvest was associated with an increased risk of above average total defects. High rainfall during the late 
growing season was also associated with a higher risk of mouldy beans. Mould/fungal growth is stimulated under humid tropical 
conditions, reinforcing the observations found here that high rainfall late in the growing season increases the risk of coffee bean 
defects, and specifically mouldy beans (Poltronieri and Rossi, 2016).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Further along the production chain once the cherries have been 
harvested, increased precipitation or humidity, night dew and rewetting of partially dried cherries during coffee cherry drying (post 
harvest operations) has been identified as one of the crucial factors during which mould formation can take place (Coffee Guide 2014).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: The exception to the impact of high rainfall was for foreign matter, where increased rainfall in harvest decreased risk.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
This may be 
because rain during the harvest period removes dust and debris.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Increased temperature during the growing season and harvest was associated with an increased likelihood of total defects, as well 
as for many of its subcomponents (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
insect damage, black beans, brown beans and mouldy beans). Insect damage consists typically of 
beans displaying one or several entry holes and galleries that reduce bean weight and cup quality.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
This defect is generally attributed to 
the coffee berry borer, Hypothenemus hampei (Ribeyre and Avelino, 2012), although the coffee bean weevil (Araecerus fasciculatus), that 
may cause a similar damage, has been reported recently from field-collected robusta berries in the study region (Alba-Alejandre et al., 
2018).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Being reasonable to assume that H. hampei was behind most of the damage recorded, our results are consistent with previous 
research on the species’ thermal biology.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
We detected a pronounced increase in the probability of obtaining insect damage at 27.5 ◦C in 
early season average temperature, coinciding with the mean temperature at which the pest is predicted to display its maximum 
reproductive potential (Jaramillo et al., 2009). Optimum temperatures throughout the growing season contribute to more pest gen­
erations and higher population pressure, increasing the likelihood of insect damage at harvest (Jaramillo et al., 2011).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Insect pests are also associated with other bean defects.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Mealybugs, regarded as a key pest in the study region, may increase the 
presence of black beans due to their sap feeding activity (Ribeyre and Avelino, 2012). High temperatures promote the presence of 
mealybugs (Jayakumar and Rajavel, 2019) and might explain the observed relationship between high late season temperatures and the 
presence of black beans.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Brown beans that may evolve into black beans can be caused by anthracnose.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
We found no previous infor­
mation on the relationship between anthracnose incidence in robusta coffee and temperature.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
However, in laboratory conditions 
Colletotrichum gloeosporioides isolates obtained from coffee berries in Vietnam showed the highest mycelial growth at 30 ◦C, the highest 
temperature evaluated (Nguyen et al., 2009).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: The risk of mouldy beans also increased as temperatures rose.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
This is not surprising as high temperatures promote microorganism 
activity, which in turn could promote this coffee bean defect (Poltronieri and Rossi, 2016). Increased temperatures therefore appear to 
be an important climate risk that needs to be understood and managed in order to reduce particular causes of coffee bean defects.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: The impacts of rainfall and temperature interacted.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The impact of rainfall on total defects varied such that at high minimum 
temperatures (>22 ◦C), increasing rainfall increased the risk of defects, while at lower minimum temperatures (~20 ◦C) increasing 
rainfall reduced the risk of defects.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The combination of high rainfall and high overnight temperatures are likely favourable for mould 
growth (FAO, 2006).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
These complex interactions highlight the need to take into account multiple climate risks simultaneously when 
assessing climate risk impacts on coffee beans.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Additional to interactions between rainfall and temperature, there were also differential responses across seasons.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
For example, 
while the most parsimonious model for explaining total defects contained harvest rainfall and temperature, the best models for specific 
defects (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: insect damage, mouldy and black beans) comprised climate variables from early growing, late growing and harvest.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
As 
such, while any particular defect might be driven by a particular season(s) climate, the overall combination of defects (that is when the 
Fig.

(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Implications – rainfall and temperature impacts on robusta coffee bean characteristics 
The coffee industry in Vietnam, the largest producer of robusta coffee in the world, is dominated by smallholders with 85% of all 
farms being under 1 ha and only 1% being more than 5 ha (D’haeze et al.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Smallholder farmers also produce large amounts of 
robusta coffee in Indonesia, Brazil, Uganda and India (ICO, 2019).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Like Vietnam, these countries are subject to high variability in 
rainfall, with droughts and floods common and anticipated to intensify under climate change (Schmidt-Thome et al., 2015; Pham- 
Thanh et al., 2020).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Climatic conditions that reduce coffee bean profitability (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
because of increased defects) has widespread and 
high cumulative impacts.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: This study suggests that the climate poses a key risk to the quality (i.e.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
beans of sufficient size and limited 
defects) of robusta coffee that smallholder farmers can produce. Understanding and managing the impacts of adverse climatic con­
ditions on robusta coffee beans should therefore be seen as imperative part of ensuring the future income and sustainability of small 
holder robust farmers throughout the world’s tropics. This study identified seasonally important rainfall and temperature conditions that could inform management actions to mitigate 
and reduce the impact of climate on robusta coffee farmers.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
During flowering high temperatures increased the risk of small beans, 
while in the growing season low rainfall and cool temperatures increased the risk of small beans.

text: Specific and seasonally adapted management actions (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
irrigation, 
pest management and the use of shade trees to manage temperatures) (Vaast et al., 2006) are likely needed to target the drivers of 
coffee bean defects and small bean size throughout the different stages of the coffee production cycle (i.e.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
from flowering through 
harvest).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Successfully mitigating these climate impacts within each season should in turn reduce the risk of defects and small coffee 
beans and so increase the price farmers are able to get for their coffee beans - especially during adverse climatic conditions.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The development of seasonally targeted management aimed at reducing the risk of defects and small beans opens the way for 
management that can be linked to forecasts.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
This would allow climate risks to be proactively adapted year to year based on forecasted 
climatic conditions.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
In several South Asian countries that grow robusta, climate forecasts can provide accurate assessments about 
drought and excessive rainfall risk 1–4 months in advance (Phelps et al., 2004).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
With the forewarning of such forecasts, for example an 
increased risk of wet harvest conditions then farmers could alter picking times and/or sourcing mechanical drying equipment or 
shelter.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Similarly, with forewarning of upcoming drought conditions during the growing season, farmers could also increase irrigation to 
offset the negative effects of low rainfall on bean size.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
However, we acknowledge that trends in future precipitation are highly un­
certain and increased use of irrigation may have limited benefit and lead to the unsustainable use of water resources (Byrareddy et al., 
2020). Whether increases in precipitation, or strategic irrigation would be sufficient to offset the increases in risk from rising mean 
maximum temperatures is an important avenue for future research.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Limitations and future directions 
Further research is needed to separate the impact of in-field versus post-harvest drivers of poor coffee bean characteristics, which 
could help quantify the importance of post-harvest management strategies and how they could be used to mitigate climate induced 
coffee bean deficiencies.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The current study focused on physical attributes (bean size and defects), which are only two components of 
coffee quality. In addition to a bean’s physical attributes, coffee quality is also influenced by biochemical bean content and organo­
leptic properties. Understanding the links between these different components of coffee bean quality and how they respond to climate 
variability is an important avenue for future research. Our study was carried out using data at the farm level and so was restricted to understanding the key climatic drivers of coffee bean 
defects and size at this scale. We therefore acknowledge that the physiological mechanisms behind the relationship between coffee 
bean characteristic and climate needs further research, ideally at the plant scale and in experimental settings.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
For example, under­
standing the physiological mechanisms behind the causes of small bean sizes and the role of differential rainfall and temperature 
impacts depending on season could have important implications for minimizing not only small beans, but also help to better un­
derstand the drivers of productivity more generally.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Our study was restricted to Lam Dong province in the central highlands of Vietnam.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Indonesia, Brazil, Uganda and India all produce 
large amounts of robusta coffee and all are frequently impacted by drought that are likely to intensify under climate change (Dai, 
2013).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
In these countries alone, 2018/19 Robusta production exceeded three billion US dollars (Uganda, 388 Million, India 360 
Million, Indonesia 942 Million and Brazil 1.6 Billion, USDA 2019) and so any impact on coffee beans that reduces this value is likely to 
be collectively large (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: in the 10′s of millions of dollars).

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Indeed, recent news article report how heavy rainfall increased coffee bean 
deficiencies with subsequent impacts on coffee profitability and supply (Binh Minh, 2017; Ionova, 2017). We are not aware of any 
research that has quantified the climatic conditions and associated costs of unfavourable rainfall and temperature conditions on coffee 
bean characteristics in these countries (but see Martins et al., 2018). The high economic value of robusta to these countries emphasizes 
the importance of the results found here and highlights the need for future research to understand and manage the financial impacts of 
climate on coffee bean characteristics and coffee production sustainability more generally.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Conclusion 
Robusta coffee exports underpin the economies and rural communities of countries throughout the tropics.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
The price farmers can 
get for their coffee is largely affected by coffee bean characteristics – however there has been limited research on how climate impacts 
robusta coffee bean characteristics. Our results suggest that there are important seasonal differences in how climate affects coffee bean 
size and coffee bean defects.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Low rainfall during the late growing season was associated with smaller beans, while low rainfall during 
the early growing season and flowering had the opposite effect. Higher rainfall during harvest was associated with an increased chance 
of coffee bean defects, but the effect of rainfall was moderated, or interacted, with temperature.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Several sub-components of coffee bean 
defects (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: mouldy beans and insect damage) were also related to climate during the early and late growing season.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
With this in­
formation farmers and the coffee industry could develop targeted proactive (e.g.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
irrigation based on forecasts) systems to manage 
climate risks that reduce the likelihood of negative coffee bean characteristics.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Ultimately, better management of climate risks that 
reduces coffee bean defects and small coffee beans would increase the income of farmers and countries dependent on robusta coffee 
production.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text: Fig.

metadata.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
(2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

text:
Probability below average coffee bean size for each particular size class in relation to each climate predictors with the strongest effect in the 
best model (see Table 2), while all other predictors are held at their mean.

text:
Chapter 4
Plant nutrition & fertiliser management
Nutrients are recycled within the environment.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
A 'closed' environment such as a rainforest,
recycles its own nutrients and is more or less self-sufficient.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
However, where plants are grown
in a commercial situation, it is necessary to replenish the nutrients that are removed from the
system.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Without additional nutrients in some form of fertiliser, coffee yields will remain very low
as nutrients are removed with the coffee beans.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Unshaded plants of dwarf, high-yielding
varieties such as Catimor, will quickly develop dieback and die if adequate nutrients and water
are not added to the soil.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Plants with mild to moderate dieback will recover with timely good
fertilising, watering and weed management.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
In India, it was found that for every 6,000 kg of ripe coffee cherry (1 tonne of green bean)
removed from the plants, approximately 40 kg nitrogen (N), 2.2 kg phosphorus (P) and 53 kg
potassium (K) must be replaced yearly.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: There are 16 natural elements (nutrients), that are essential for plant growth (see table below).

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Three elements (carbon, hydrogen and oxygen) make up 94% of the plant tissues and are
obtained from air and water.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
The other 13 elements are obtained from the soil and are divided
into two broad categories - 'macro' and 'micro'.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
These terms do not refer to the importance of
the elements; macronutrients are required in greater amounts than micronutrients for normal
plant growth.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

Soil and leaf analysis
The objective of sampling is to get an
AVERAGE (representative sample) of soil in
the block, not the best or the worst.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
To keep
costs down, and if plantings are of the same
age and appearance, three samples per two
to four hectare block will be adequate,
provided the three samples are composites
from the 20 sites sampled.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: To help determine the best nutrition practices, soil and leaf analyses are recommended.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
While
Lao currently does not have access to these services, in nearby Thailand the Mae Jo
University in Chiang Mai and Department of Land Development (DLD) can offer fee-for-service
analyses.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
The FAO project used Mae Jo University for the soil and leaf analysis survey of
Arabica coffee farms in the Bolovens in 2005.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
In order to standardize procedures between farms, years and personnel involved, the following
practices are suggested for soil and leaf analysis.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Soil sampling

Figure 23.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Remove surface litter and old fertiliser etc., from area to be sampled but do not
remove soil.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Take samples to a depth of 150 mm
Remove surface litter (leaves, etc.)

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: before sampling.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Do not scrape away soil (Figure
23).

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Take samples to a depth of 150 mm with soil auger or spade.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Place soil in a CLEAN bucket.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Sample from a minimum of 20 sites across a block of two to four hectares.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Thoroughly mix each soil sample collected and then sub-sample to reduce volume for
sample bags.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Properly label all samples and laboratory sheets.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Clean the auger or spade after sampling each of the sites.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
DO NOT sample after fertilizer application. Scrape away any fertilizer/lime residue from
previous applications before taking a sample.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Do not sample next to shade trees.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Areas of different tree size, age, soil types, fertilizer or other major differences should be
treated as separate samples.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Samples need to be dried before sending for analysis.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
If laboratory ovens are
unavailable, spread out each sample on a paper bag or plain paper and dry slowly on
raised benches under shade and protected from rain.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Samples are usually air dry in four
to five days.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: If possible, soil samples should be taken once per year before flowering.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Leaf sampling
The objective of leaf sampling is to get an
AVERAGE (representative sample) of trees,
not the best or the worst.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
The 40 trees per
hectare samples can be bulked and three
composite samples made to reduce analysis
costs.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
A minimum of 100 leaves is needed for
each composite sample.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Figure 24.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Leaf sampling
Sample the third or fourth pair of leaves from the tip of an actively growing branch.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Do
not count new leaves if they are not fully expanded (Figure 24).

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Sample at the same time/growth stage each year, before flowering.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Sample a minimum of 40 trees per block across a block size of two to four hectares.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Sample diagonally across the block.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Sample average trees only.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Do not sample obviously sick, excessively healthy or
odd/unusual coffee trees.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Sample in the morning where possible when leaves are the most turgid (full of water).

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Use CLEAN HANDS.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Do not smoke while sampling and make sure hands are free of
fertilizer, soil etc.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Do not sample when leaves are wet as the paper sample bags will break!

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Do not sample after any application of foliar fertilizer sprays.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Areas of different tree size, age, soil types, fertilizer or other major differences should be
treated as separate samples.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Properly label all samples and laboratory sheets.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Samples are to be stored in paper (not plastic) bags.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Keep leaves cool but do not
freeze!

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Samples need to be dried if they are not sent for analysis within one to two days.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
This is
normally done at the laboratory at 60 to 65°C until dry and brittle.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Pre-flowering is preferred sampling time if only one sample is taken each year.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
More frequent
sampling (every four months) is highly desirable for large plantations, especially if nutritional
problems occur.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
A soil and leaf sampling survey on 15 properties has recently been conducted on the Bolovens
Plateaux; results were not available at the time of publication.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Optimum leaf and soil nutrient levels

Once the soil and leaf samples have been taken, it is important to analyse the results and
compare them to levels that have been determined as optimum in coffee plantations around
the world in order to devise a nutrition programme for the coffee.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Fertiliser programme
Fresh manure or non-composted pulp should
never be used as they can burn the plants
and tie up nitrogen in the soil during break-
down.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
They also are a source of Orchratoxin
A (OTA) moulds.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Coffee soils in Lao PDR are low in a number of essential plant nutrients; therefore these must
be supplied to promote high yielding, high quality coffee.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Manure, bio-fertiliser, cover crops,
compost, legume tree leaves and shoots and chemical fertilisers all supply nutrients.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Manure and compost such as coffee pulp and husks have a low nutrient content.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
When utilised
as a source of nutrients, they must be used in large quantities to supply sufficient nutrients for
coffee plants.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Manure and compost help improve soil structure and organic matter.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Chemical fertilisers are higher in nutrient content than organic fertilisers and are a more
effective method of applying nutrients.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
For optimal results, it is best to apply a combination of
manure and compost and chemical fertilisers.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
At present, there has been little or no soil and leaf analysis services available for Lao coffee
growers.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
When such services are available, a detailed coffee fertiliser programme can be
devised.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Meanwhile the following fertiliser programme is suggested for Arabica coffee in Lao.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Year
Time
Application
Year 1
(Up to 12 months in the field)
Before rains finish
September
30 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
Year 2
April/May (with first rains)
30 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
July
30 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
September
30 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
500 g/tree of Dolomite
Year 3
April/May (with first rains)
60 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
July
60 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
September
60 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
Year 4
April/May (with first rains)
90 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
July
90 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
September
90 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
500 g/tree of Dolomite
Year 5
Onwards

April/May (with first rains)
120 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
July
120 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
September
120 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
Note: NPK is nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium
Explanation
1g N
=
1,288 g N (Urea)
1g Ca
=
1,399 g calcium oxide (quick burn lime)
=
1,780 g calcium carbonate (lime or limestone)
1g Mg
=
1,658 g magnesium oxide
1g S
=
3,750 g magnesium sulphate
Higher yielding coffee plots may require 25% more fertiliser.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Use lime or preferably, dolomite (Ca + Mg) at 500 g per plant every two years and apply before
the end of the rainy season.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Use the last rains to wash the lime into the soil or water in well by
hand or irrigation.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:

parts of coffee tree (expected yields / ha: 1000 kg green beans). Nutrient uptake of a coffee tree

It is obvious from this table that leaves need the major part of the uptake - more than the

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: However, nutrients are returned to the soil when the leaves drop.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
The early
years of root development are very important as branches and roots store nutrients for a long
time.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Nutrients accumulated in the fruits will be removed when cherries are harvested.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
This loss
needs to be compensated by the addition of fertilizers, organic manures, leaf fall or prunings
and leaves from shade trees.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Recycling of pulp to the soil after composting can help to reduce
the additional (chemical) fertiliser needed.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Fertiliser placement
While good for the soil, manure or compost
may not supply the full range and amount of
nutrients required by the coffee tree and
some mineral fertiliser or micronutrients or

other organic fertilisers may be needed
occasionally.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Figure 25.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Place a band of fertiliser around the drip line
Spread fertiliser evenly on the soil around the drip line (the outside edge of the canopy) of the
coffee tree, as this is where most feeder/hair roots are found (Figure 25).

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Keep fertiliser at
least 100 mm from the stem of the plant; fertiliser applied closer than this can damage the
coffee tree.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Manure (if not using fertiliser).

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
The minimum amounts to apply are:
Year 2
0.7 kg/tree
Year 3
1 kg /tree
Year 4
2 kg /tree
Year 5 onwards
2.5 kg/tree
Legume shade trees, ground covers and suitable intercrops supply nutrients and organic
matter through litter and leaf fall and through prunings added as mulch to the surface of the
soil.

text:
Nutrient deficiency symptoms
The overall rate of coffee growth and production depends on the least available plant nutrient.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Plants will grow and produce only as much as the least available nutrient will allow them to. It
does not matter how much of the other nutrients are available to the plant because it is the
least available nutrient that limits growth and development.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
This is well illustrated in the
following 'Barrel Analogy', where the barrel can hold only as much water as the shortest plank
will allow (Figure 26).

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
This is known as the 'Law of the Minimum' and is explained thus:

Figure 26.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
'Barrel Analogy' using nitrogen as the least available nutrient
The level of water in the barrel represents the level of crop yield that is restricted by the most
limiting nutrient, nitrogen.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
When nitrogen is added, the level of crop production is controlled by
the next most limiting factor (in this example, potassium).

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Poor nutrition is a major cause of coffee dieback.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Plants lacking sufficient N (nitrogen) and K
(potassium) suffer from dieback, especially where there is poor shade cover and insufficient
water.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Low soil calcium and phosphorus will hinder root development and contribute to
dieback.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text:
Dieback causes loss of yield and when severe, plants can die, especially high
yielding, dwarf Catimor varieties.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

text: Each nutrient has unique deficiency symptoms.

metadata.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

seen in the photographs.
