text:
2.1.2.2 Green coffee main impact contributors and discrepancies 
Focusing on the green coffee production, the discrepancy across results could be critical especially 
when switching from positive to negative global warming impact indicators, at the hectare level, with 
carbon storage due to LUC.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Overall, four studies investigated LUC and four others considered some 
biogenic carbon storage in the coffee plantations without modelling any LUC. Biogenic carbon stored 
in plantations, within coffee or other trees, should not be included in the carbon footprint as specified 
by the guidelines (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: PAS2050, GHG Protocol, etc.)

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
unless considered within a proper long-term LUC 
modelling.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Carbon storage in any stand may be accounted only in relative quantities compared to 
previous stands and providing that a consistent time frame is aligned with a minimum time-averaged 
storage (at least over 20 years according to IPCC recommendations).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Across the reviewed studies, 
negative global warming impacts, such as in Noponen et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2013), might have resulted from distorted 
LUC modelling or inconsistent biogenic carbon accounting.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Distortion might be due to varying choices 
across studies in terms of time parameters.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Inconsistent biogenic carbon accounting might be due to 
flaws in the extrapolation of carbon stock changes or imbalanced accounting for carbon storage and 
release in LUC contexts.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Although net benefits from LUC are possible in some given contexts, such 
cases were not thoroughly assessed in the reviewed corpus.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: In Noponen et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2013), carbon stocks 
were estimated and amortised over 9 years due to experimental constraints.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The consensual time 
frame for carbon estimates is at least 20 years, therefore the LUC modelling in Noponen et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2013) 
might be distorted compared to other studies and those results were not further discussed.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
According to the remaining studies, the global warming impact indicator of green coffee following 
land use change to establish the plantations varied from 1.63 to 10.52 kg CO2eq/kg green coffee (based 
on IPCC 2006 Tier 1 for LUC modelling).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
LUC contribution to the final global warming impact ranged 
from 1%13 to 75%, hence leading up to a four-fold impact increase.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
LUC contribution is usually quite 
critical in agricultural LCA, particularly in the tropics where rainforest may be converted into 
                                                             
13 In this study, LUC contribution was averaged over a whole region including thousands of farmers, among whom very few 
would mention any LUC.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The authors specified that the modelled LUC was very likely underestimated and would require a 
more in-depth investigation (Enveritas, 2023).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
23 
 
agricultural land.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It can hence lead to significant differences between coffee systems given contrasted 
local development contexts and LUC history.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The overall global warming impact indicator of green 
coffee with or without LUC varied between 0.15 and 14.5 kg CO2eq/kg green coffee, with a median 
value at 3.6 kg CO2eq/kg green coffee (Figure 3).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Figure 3.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Overview of global warming impacts and main contributors at cradle-to-mill gate (1st processing).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
All % 
are expressed as the percentage of the global warming impact.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Notes: Green coffee is averaged for both dry and 
wet processing routes.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Coffee icon from Muhammad Nur Auliady Pamungkas (beans), Noun Project CCBY3.0 
 
LUC apart (studied systems, n=51), overall main contributors to the global warming impacts of 
green coffee production were synthetic fertilisers with a median contribution for both fertilisers 
upstream (manufacture and transport) and downstream (field emissions) together of 66% (Figure 3).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In studies providing disaggregated information, greenhouse gas emissions from fertilisers upstream 
contributed to 8-49% of the impact (median value at mill gate: 20%), and those from downstream 
emissions to 18-58% (median value at mill gate: 37%).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The second main contributor was wet processing where both energy for processing and emissions 
from anaerobic treatment of wastewater could contribute to GHG emissions.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Fermentation emissions 
related to wet processing were not consistently modelled across studies, which raised a critical issue 
as they were quite significant contributors, from 27% to 66% of the global warming impacts (Killian et 
al., 2013; Maina et al., 2016; van Rikxoort et al., 2014; Van Rikxoort et al., 2013).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the end, this 
contribution was highly variable and uncertain across studies.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Some studies did not include emissions 
from wet processing due to a lack of data or with no disclaimer (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Brommer et al., 2011; Quack et 
al., 2009; Vera-Acevedo et al., 2016; Rahmah et al., 2023).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In comparison, emissions from dry 
processing and other post-harvest operations up to green coffee were negligible.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Drying was mostly in 
the sun and hulling only contributed to 1-2% when disaggregated from other post-harvest energy-
related contributors.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
24 
 
The third main contributor were N2O emissions from residues, albeit those emissions were not 
systematically considered and led to quite contrasted contributions.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Overall, only seven studies 
considered emissions from residue decomposition in the field and contribution varied from 4% in 
Maina et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: (2016) up to 90% in Jaramillo et al., (2017).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: In Noponen et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2012, 2013) emissions 
related to residue decomposition contributed between 9 to 42% of the global warming impacts across 
systems.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Crop residues in Maina et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: (2016) were not detailed.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the other studies, all considered 
coffee leaf litter, but only four also considered coffee pruning as well as litter and pruning from 
associated trees (Noponen et al., 2012, 2012; van Rikxoort et al., 2014; Van Rikxoort et al., 2013).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Finally, only one study also accounted for emissions related to coffee husk decomposition, i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Enveritas (2023).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The median contributions for those residues across these studies were 11% and 14% 
at mill and farm gate (no transformation), respectively.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Besides those main contributors, the respective contributions of fuel for transport (median 
contribution of 3% at mill gate) or field operations (median: 2% at mill gate); pesticides upstream 
emissions (median: 5% at farm gate) or irrigation were less critical.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Only 15% of the studied systems 
included irrigation (in 7 studies) and only three studies provided some details on its global warming 
contribution, which was highly variable between 4% and 31% at mill gate.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The results on irrigation 
contributions were unlikely to be representative of contrasted types and intensities of irrigation across 
coffee farming systems and are not further discussed.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.1.3 Uncertainty sources and data gaps 
LUC apart, at the plantation level, despite some mentions of quite complex coffee systems, such as 
agroforestry plots, little attention was paid to consider this complexity and potential allocation issues 
within the impact assessment.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Figure 4 shows no clear-cut difference in the global warming impacts 
based on the cropping system type and large variabilities within system types.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This may be partly due 
to the fact that, when discarding LUC, the cropping system type among the displayed categories may 
not significantly affect the carbon footprint compared to other main contributors such as fertilisers 
(e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Noponen et al, 2012).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, part of the effects may also be missed due to incomplete 
descriptions and modelling of the diverse system structures and functioning.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Some studies estimated 
carbon stock in associated shade trees but did not investigate how competitions for resources may 
affect inputs/outputs among crops and trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Apart from a few studies mentioned before, there was 
a lack of a clear systemic delineation between coffee and associated plants in the case of agroforestry 
plots.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
25 
 
 
Figure 4.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Green coffee global warming impact according to cropping system types (cradle-to-1st processing gate, 
no LUC considered, n=49, no result available for the 1% Full sun polyculture for this system boundary).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Besides, the overall balance in inputs/outputs should also include the residues from coffee and 
potentially other associated crops or trees, should the latter be considered within the system 
boundary.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Inclusion of residue emissions clearly affected the final global warming indicators (Figure 
5a).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
More attention should be paid to quantify on-farm or off-farm residue decomposition and 
emission profiles properly, so as to make sure that the quantification of emissions is complete, as well 
as to check whether synthetic fertilisers were or could be substituted.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Many studies focusing on coffee 
co-products or waste could provide insights on quantities and properties of those residues to derive a 
more systematic accounting (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Catalan et al., 2019; Cruz, 2014; Dadi et al., 2019).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: The added emissions of first processing were also highly variable and questionable (Figure 5b).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The 
clear cut between dry processing for arabica or robusta may rather relate to differences at farm stage 
as dry processing would not be significantly different depending on the coffee variety. The clear cut 
between dry and wet processing for arabica is due to large variabilities and uncertainties in the 
modelling of both coffee supply chains.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It stresses the likely underestimation of emissions and impacts 
from the wet process, as not all studies included wet process emissions nor used the most updated 
GWP for biogenic CH4.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Emissions from wet processing depend on many factors that can be highly 
variable but mostly depend on the amount of water used for washing and fermenting.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The origin of 
water may also affect the energy-related emissions for pumping.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the end, the amount of emitted 
CH4 is related to the wastewater amount and treatment that differ widely among geographical 
contexts and applied processes.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Traditional fully washed processes use up to four times as much water 
compared to processes that reuse water (Van Rikxoort, 2011).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
CH4 emissions, when included, were 
mostly based on IPCC coefficients for wastewater treatment but there was a lack of information across 
the studies on the overall process; i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
detailing the origin of water, the amount of water used, the 
duration of the whole process, which influences fermentation outputs, and the type and duration of 
wastewater treatments.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
More data and knowledge would be needed to decipher the proper emission 

Cirad report 
26 
 
profiles of wet processes according to their specificities.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Moreover, when wastewater is not treated 
and directly discharged into the environment, which may limit the CH4 emissions, other pollutants may 
also become an environmental threat (Beyene et al., 2012; Blinová et al., 2017; Chanakya and De Alwis, 
2004).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Figure 5.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Global warming impacts of green coffee depending on the accounting for emissions from (a) residues: 
yes/no (n=51); and (b) the type of first processing: wet/dry (n=50) (cradle-to-1st processing gate, no LUC 
considered).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Although fertilisers-related field emissions were explicitly modelled across the studies14 (mostly 
based on IPCC 2006 and derivatives), there was still a lack of transparency and details.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Apart from a 
few studies (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Noponen et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2012, Maina…), most studies did not specify if indirect N2O emissions 
or CO2 field emissions related to urea and liming practices were accounted for.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Moreover, not all 
studies provided a detailed inventory on inputs, notably on fertiliser types and amounts, nor 
systematically differentiated between synthetic and organic ones.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The variability among studies with 
no details available spanned a larger range than that of the other studies (Figure 6).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Hence, the lack of 
transparency and details hampered a clear analysis of correlations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
When analysing results per class of 
N-fertilisers, we could not identify any clear trend15, despite residues and impact of 1st processing being 
split in order to try and disentangle the many factors.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Figure 6a,b first show an extreme variability 
across all classes of fertiliser intensity and no clear cut between fertiliser managements.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Some low-
input systems had large emissions and vice versa.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Those managements embed many factors that could 
not be fully discriminated against due to the lack of details available.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In particular, the difference in 
organic versus synthetic fertilisers played a key role in some fertiliser-intensive systems as upstream 
emissions from organic fertilisers were much lower than those of synthetic ones, while fertiliser 
upstream emissions were significant contributors (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Noponen et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Finally, large 
discrepancies in wet emissions modelling may have also smoothed out part of the comparative results 
                                                             
14It should be noted that it was a robustness criterion to actually retain a study.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: 15N-fertiliser classes were defined in order to yield comparable sample sizes across classes.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The in-depth analysis revealed 
further doubts on some results that might not be fully consistent with the fertiliser doses displayed.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
27 
 
across fertiliser-classes, as exemplified in the >334 N class where wet process coffee supply chains had 
a lower impact than dry process coffee supply chains, which had a similar median impact as for the 
other N classes with wet processing.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Figure 6.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Global warming impacts of green coffee by N-fertiliser classes and depending on the accounting for 
emissions from (a) residues: yes/no; and (b) the type of first processing: wet/dry (cradle-to-1st processing gate, 
no LUC considered, n=51).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In conclusion, more information and data, as well as a more harmonised accounting, is needed to 
cover better emissions and impacts from coffee plantations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
A more systemic approach is needed to 
grasp the complexity and variability of coffee supply chains at both crop and processing levels.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The 
plantation complexity influences the biomass stocks, within the frame of LUC accounting, the 
ecosystem functioning and input/output flows, as well as the co-products and residue emissions over 
the whole perennial cycle.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Post-harvest emissions also are critical and there is still a gap in knowledge 
and primary data to characterise processing emissions as well as to properly quantify losses along the 
supply chain.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
28 
 
2.2 Review on carbon footprint guidelines and harmonised parameters  
We reviewed the key methodological guidelines applied to LCA and carbon footprint.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
These 
guidelines are internationally recognised as fundamental to ensure the reliability of results.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
After the 
ﬁrst life cycle assessments in the early 1980s, LCA gained more traction in the 1990s with the 
development of bioenergy.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, at that stage the lack of harmonisation in the methods led to 
confusing results, varying upon the methods applied more than the data used, as highlighted in a 
seminal publication by Farrell et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: (2006) looking back at contradictory corn ethanol LCA studies.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This 
confusion called for an unprecedented international harmonisation regarding environmental 
assessment, particularly through the structuring and formalisation work led by SETAC16.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Since the early 2000s, LCA has become a standardised conceptual and methodological framework 
under ISO series 14040 (2000–2006).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: It is based on two fundamental principles.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
First, environmental 
impacts are quantiﬁed throughout the supply chain or ‘life cycle’, from raw material extraction 
(‘cradle’) to end-of-life of the product or service (‘grave’).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Then, the impacts are quantiﬁed with respect 
to a functional unit, either a product quantity (one kilo, one car, etc.)

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
or a usage or service (hours, 
kilometres, etc.).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In that way, the environmental impacts of systems producing a similar function can 
be compared.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Thus, LCA has become the worldwide standard for implementing environmental product 
declarations (ISO 14025:2006 Type III Environmental Declarations).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
ISO standards were defined, and 
translated into various languages, in order to make sure these fundamental principles and steps in 
application are commonly respected.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: They are regularly reviewed.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Further 14000 series ISO standards were developed, notably the ISO 14067 (2013) with relation to 
single issue LCA focusing on global warming assessment or carbon footprint.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Besides, further guidelines 
were derived from the seminal ISO standards to provide sector wise declinations and practical 
information also called Product Categories Rules (PCR).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The Carbon Footprint Product Category Rules (CFP-PCR) for the assessment of the greenhouse gas 
emissions of UN CPC 01610 (Green coffee) has expired in 2016, but was considered as a central 
guideline in this review for two reasons: 
• 
This is (was) the most accurate and specific standard in terms of impact (Global warming, also 
called Carbon footprint) and system studied (Green coffee)  
• 
The ISO 14067 states “where relevant PCR or CFP-PCR exist, they shall be adopted” 
Hence the use of the CFP-PCR (2013) as a first entry point, then complemented with the other 
standards when relevant. In summary, the chosen key methodological guidelines, in the case of coffee carbon footprint, were 
the following (Figure 7): 
• 
CFP-PCR (2013): Carbon Footprint of a Product – Product Category Rules for the assessment of 
the greenhouse gas emissions of Green coffee 
• 
ISO 14067 (2013): an adaptation of ISO 14040 and 14044 to carbon footprint specificities 
• 
LCA derived specific guidelines for food and perennials: PAS 2050:2011 (BSI 2011) and PAS 
2050:2012 (BSI 2012) for horticultural products.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
16 SETAC: Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry, one of the most important international scientiﬁc organisations 
dealing with structural issues of life cycle assessment.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
29 
 
• 
Product Category Rules (PCR) for Moka17 and Espresso18 (International EPD System 2019 and 
2018): partially analysed, because relying on CFP-PCR for green coffee. The CFP-PCR for green coffee (2013), the PCR for Moka and Espresso have also expired, but they 
were still considered partially.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: The various coffee CFP-PCR would need to be updated.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Figure 7.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Key carbon footprint methodological guidelines analysed in this review: CFP-PCR for green coffee (2013), 
ISO 14067 (2013) and PAS 2050 (Including PAS 2050:2011 (BSI 2011) and PAS 2050:2012 (BSI 2012)), and their 
relation with guidelines addressing other impact categories: PCR for Moka and Espresso (International EPD 
System 2019 and 2018), and LCA standard ISO 14040 and 14044.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Guidelines highlighted in red were considered 
as the most comprehensive baseline.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The review aimed at stressing both i) the minimum reporting requirements to make valid 
statements on the impact of coffee; and ii) stress robust methodological approaches and parameters 
against bottlenecks or knowledge gaps.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Key principles of a Carbon Footprint are based on the Life Cycle Assessment methodology (mostly 
described in ISO standards 14040 and 14044: Life cycle perspective, functional unit, iterative approach, 
relevance, completeness, transparency.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Therefore, all guidelines follow more or less extensively the 
ISO stepwise methodology, which structures this section; i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
1) Goal & scope definition, 2) Life Cycle 
Inventory (LCI), 3) Life Cycle Impact Assessment (LCIA), and 4) Interpretation, reporting and 
communication.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.2.1 Goal and scope definition 
The goal and scope definition should ensure that the system boundary is explicit and consistent 
with the objective of the study.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The goal of the study is embodied in the chosen functional unit that 
determines the proportion of all inputs and outputs relative to the reference flow aiming to the 
provision of the functional unit.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: For a given product, e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
green coffee, the goal and scope of the study 
may vary depending on the temporal, geographical and technological scopes.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As LCA integrates various 
                                                             
17 EPD System (2018).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: PCR 2018:03 Espresso coffee, version 1.01 (UN CPC 23912).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: 18 International EPD System (2018).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: PCR 2018:03 Espresso coffee, version 1.01 (UN CPC 23912).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
30 
 
processes taking place at different locations and time points, it represents a snapshot of a product 
system, whose validity is limited to the defined scope.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Besides the “mere amount” of a functional unit 
(e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
1 kg green coffee), details on its scope should be provided when introducing the study goal and 
scope (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
1 kg green coffee provided at farm gate by X on average in 2020 - see recommendations 
below).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Therefore, it is important to bear in mind that LCA results for a given functional unit may vary 
due to variations in the scope that may not be properly considered or elicited within this functional 
unit.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The scope of the system boundary is adjusted through an iterative process, whereby all processes 
and flows should be first considered and only discarded if it can be demonstrated that their 
contributions are negligible or below a defined cut-off.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Transparency is a key principle and all 
assumptions and decisions along the LCA stages need to be made crystal clear and justified.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The final LCA results should be interpreted in light of adequacy of the system boundary to the study 
goal and scope, as well as the quality of data used relative to the study scope (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
data on Brazilian 
arabica coffee may not be suitable for a study in another country, also commonly found in the 
literature).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The CFP-PCR (2013) - further referred to as CFP-PCR only - recommends a description of the 
production system (organic, polyculture, monoculture…) and the number of trees per hectare for 
coffee trees (distinguishing Robusta from Arabica) but also for other trees in the case of polyculture.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Functional Unit 
A proper FU should address the “what,” “how much,” “how well,” and “how long.” The quality of 
products is not considered in some of the PEFCR (Pedersen-Remmen 2022).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For green-coffee, the CFP-
PCR recommends: 1 kg of Green Coffee at 11.5% moisture delivered to port of origin or the roaster’s 
warehouse if processing domestically.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As recalled before, it is paramount that the FU reflects the study 
goal and scope and vice versa.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
System boundaries  
Green coffee carbon footprint can either be from cradle to the ’port of origin’ or from cradle to the 
warehouse of the domestic roasting facility studies.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
A sub-system at farm gate can be found in the 
literature, notably when first processing takes place on-farm.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, it may be confusing as further 
stages up to green coffee, such as processing or final coffee grading and sorting usually go beyond the 
farm.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The inclusion or not of such final stages and potential intermediary transports should be specified 
and reflected within the study goal and scope and the functional unit.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It is usually more efficient to list all the included stages and processes, rather than trying to make 
an exhaustive list of excluded ones.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: A common exclusion in agricultural LCA are the capital goods.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
All reviewed standards agree that 
capital goods are to be excluded.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Capital goods are input to the system, such as machines or buildings, 

Cirad report 
31 
 
with a lifespan greater than 3 years (CFP-PCR).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Conversely, any input/consumable whose lifespan is 
less than or equal to 3 years should be included.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For instance, irrigation pump manufacture may be 
excluded but not the manufacture of irrigation pipes that may be changed regularly (if their lifespan is 
less or equal to 3 years).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The impact of such capital goods is usually negligible due to their long lifespan 
(more than 20 years for most infrastructure) and large throughputs, whereby only a negligible amount 
of their total impact would be allocated to the functional unit (equivalent to a small proportion of the 
total throughput over the complete lifespan).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Only the manufacture and installation of such capital 
goods are excluded.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Impacts related to their daily use and regular maintenance are included in the LCA 
in proportions to their use to fulfil the functional unit.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Another common exclusion is human energy inputs (CFP-PCR).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The main reason is the difficulty to 
allocate human caloric expense to a given functional unit considering other daily activities and the 
great variability of individual metabolisms and labour costs.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cut-off rule 
Although simple by essence, the cut-off rule is a fuzzy concept in LCA because it applies at system 
boundary stage but should be based on quantified information further down the LCA calculations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cut 
off rule varies slightly between standards.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
At least 95% of climate change potential associated with the 
declared unit shall be included according to the CFP-PCR.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The same cut off value is used in the PAS2050, 
where it is specified that the cut-off applies to the anticipated GHG emissions and removals.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It indeed 
raises the question of how to accurately anticipate (<5% error) all contributions without actually 
making a full inventory.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the PCR for Moka, it is specified that the cut-off should be checked based 
on a combination of expert judgement and a sensitivity analysis demonstrating how the un-
investigated input or output could affect the final results.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
But this latter sensitivity analysis requires to 
be able to still quantify the cut-off flows.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Besides, the PCR for Moka sets a higher cut off value with a 
minimum of 99% of the environmental impacts that shall be included.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In practical terms, decisions on 
cut-offs should be adjusted along an iterative process.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Where cut-offs are as low as 1-5% and need to 
be justified on quantitative analyses, they do not translate into an actual criterion to reduce the LCI 
workload.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
LCA scope and sampling approach 
The scope is quite critical in agricultural LCA, as agricultural systems are much less homogeneous 
than industrial systems (for which LCA was originally developed).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The scope of a coffee LCA will be very 
different if the objective is to analyse one farm, a national average or a roaster supply area for instance.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As mentioned earlier, LCI data need to be adapted to the goal and scope, meaning representative of 
the actual studied system in all its dimensions (geographical, temporal and technical).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Given the great 
variability in coffee farming and first processing systems (c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
section 2.1), defining the sampling 
approach may be critical to reach the study goal.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Across the guidelines, there are three sampling options:  
1.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Random sampling: relevant when calculating the carbon footprint of a coffee cooperative 
in which the farms and practices are homogeneous (CFP-PCR).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
PAS2050:2012 offers an alternative of random sampling that could be applied even if farms 
are not homogenous: The minimum sample size can be determined via a statistical 

Cirad report 
32 
 
approach that is further explained in the “Guidelines for the Carbon Footprinting of Dairy 
Products in the UK, 2010” (Chapter 4 and Appendix 3).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
More details on its application within 
a broader decision context is provided in the recommendations (c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: section 3.1).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Stratified sampling: first identify representative clusters (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
sub-groups) within the 
complete population of farms.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Clusters should be chosen based on characteristics that have 
a significant influence on the results such as management type (organic vs. other), shade 
type, climate.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In other words, clusters gather growers that are expected to have a similar 
Carbon footprint.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Clustering reduces the standard deviation within each group, thus 
reducing the number of farms that must be sampled to reach an acceptable margin of error.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In this case, the CFP-PCR and PAS 2050:2012 recommend a sample size equal to the square root of 
the full population size.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The sample size in each cluster should reflect the proportion of product 
supplied (then a weighted average can be calculated).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Note: the sampling effort should be based on the proportion of the product supplied by each sub-
group (not the number of suppliers for each group); thus, the average dataset will be weighted 
according to the percentage supplied.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The reporting must clearly state the approach applied, the sample size and how this was 
established.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The time dimension is one of the most complex dimensions to apprehend in LCA, which is time-
disconnected by nature due to the integrated snapshot (except for dynamics LCA).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In agricultural LCA, 
time is critical due to the impact of climate and varying practices from year to year.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Furthermore, in 
the case of perennial cropping systems, the time dimension is even more complex to integrate due to 
varying practices and delayed impacts along the crop cycle (Cerutti et al., 2011; Bessou et al., 2013).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In 
any case, the sampling strategy must also consider this time factor.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the CFP-PCR, they recommend that the most recent three consecutive years be averaged, 
without further details (Figure 8).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The PAS2050:2012 is more specific for perennials: the three-year 
period should correspond to a “steady state” situation.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
If not, GHG emissions shall be corrected by 
bringing the areas of different growing stages in proportion to the expected proportion in steady state.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Finally, the PCR for Moka and Espresso (2019) mentions that unproductive years of the coffee 
plantation shall be considered (not the CFP-PCR for green coffee).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The consumptions and emissions of 
unproductive years of the coffee plantation shall be spread out over the productive years considering 
the yearly yields and entire lifetime of the plantation.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Guidelines are hence not consistent regarding 
that matter, so that we shall made more specific recommendations (c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Section3.2).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
33 
 
 
Figure 8.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Representation of the various stages of a coffee plantation that should be accounted for (in yellow) 
according to the guidelines.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Allocation 
When co-products remain in the system (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
husks used as fertiliser or energy used in bio-digesters 
in the mill), no allocation is necessary (CFP-PCR).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The guiding principles for allocation in the CFP-PCR are aligned with the allocation procedure 
described by ISO 14044 and ISO 14067: 
1.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Allocation should be avoided by dividing the unit process into 2 or more sub-processes, or by 
expanding the product system to include the additional functions related to the co-products.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Where allocation cannot be avoided, the inputs and outputs of the system should be 
partitioned between its different products or functions that reflect the underlying physical 
relationships.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Where physical relationships cannot be established or used, the inputs should be allocated 
between products and functions in a manner that reflects other relationships between them.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
All guidelines propose to avoid allocation as first choice, but still provide recommendations on 
allocation since it may be sometimes unavoidable.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
So, the general principles are further specified in 
the CFP-PCR, with two types of allocation:  
A. Allocation of input quantities and processes between the different crops in polycultures and  
B. Allocation of GHG emissions from multi-output systems 
A. Allocation rule hierarchy of input quantities between the different crops in polycultures: 
• 
Fertiliser inputs and irrigation: 
1.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Break down the process into sub-processes by obtaining primary data on fertiliser use for 
each crop.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Manure ‘production’ is allocated 100% to the animal with transport, storage 
and on-farm handling all to be allocated to the coffee production.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
If collecting data on the quantities of fertilisers for all crops is not possible, the farmers 
should be encouraged to estimate the data for coffee.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
If this cannot be done, use the default value tables (based on an agronomic approach using 
the N requirements of the different plants – c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Table 3).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
If practitioners have other higher 

Cirad report 
34 
 
quality or more representative data, they should be used preferably.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The CFP-PCR specifies 
future updates may include other crops and cater for situations where there is more than 
one other crop.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
If this cannot be done, use economic allocation  
5.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: If there are more than one crop or if the crop is not in the table: allocate 100% to coffee.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Table 3.

Fuel use: 
If crop specific data are not available, use economic allocation based on local values averaged over a 
3-year period.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
Pesticides and herbicides inputs:  
No allocation unless the product has an impact on both coffee and co-crop.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
If pesticide/herbicide are 
applied to the ’benefit of both species, the allocation approach for fertiliser should be applied.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
B. Allocation of GHG emissions from multi-output systems:  
In case of allocation between coproducts that are exported out of the system, an economic 
approach is to be applied using local values averaged over the previous three-year period.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Below more 
specifications from the CFP-CPR: 
• 
Exported husks: 
1.

Economic approach based on local value, 
2.

• 
Timber sold on off farm (from pruning or replacement processes):  
• 
Economic approach where values have been averaged over the previous three years 

Cirad report 
35 
 
• 
Gas or electricity exported from the mill:  
Economic approach using local grid price.

• 
Husks sold for energy generation:  
1.

Economic (three-year average value) approach, 
2.

generated 
The allocation of pesticides or herbicides inputs is debatable: when a pesticide/herbicide is applied 
to the ’benefit of both species’ (this is often the case), the allocation approach specified above for 
fertiliser is to be applied: 1.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Breaking down is not relevant in this case, 2.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The default table based on N 
requirement is not relevant, 3.

text: Economic allocation may be the best option.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Recycling of co-products and GHG emissions  
The CFP-PCR requires: 
• 
Where there is recycling activity (ex: husk used for fertiliser), this will be included in the 
calculation; where appropriate the benefits will be recognised through the calculation 
displacing fossil sources that would have otherwise been used.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
If there is an inflow of recycled material to the system in the production/processing phase, the 
recycling process and the transportation from the recycling process to where the material is 
used shall be included. • 
If there is an outflow of material to recycling, the transportation of the material to the recycling 
process shall be included. The material going to recycling is then an outflow from the 
production system.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.2.2 Life Cycle Inventory  
Emissions 
According to CFP-PCR, emissions to be included are as follow: 
• 
Fossil carbon dioxide (energy use, e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
combustion of diesel and some forms of electricity 
production) 
• 
Fossil methane emissions 
• 
Biogenic methane emissions (wet processing water treatment) 
• 
Nitrous oxide emissions (N2O emissions from fertiliser production and application of both 
mineral and organic fertilisers as well as ‘N’ contained in pruning residues returned to the soil 
through cultivation) 
• 
Carbon stock changes due to land use change (LUC) within the last 20 years in order to 
establish the coffee plantation (Following the guidance provided by the Greenhouse Gas 
Protocol – Product Life Cycle Accounting and Reporting Standard, Appendix B, Page 119, 
applying scenario B).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Can be reported separately, but must be reported.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Emissions excluded: 
• 
Emissions associated with the ‘short’ carbon cycle where photosynthesis and respiration are 
the primary components 

Cirad report 
36 
 
• 
Emissions from biogenic sources (as per the PAS2050 (2011) guidelines, section 5 – Cf.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
“Short 
carbon cycle” and note below) 
• 
Carbon sequestration in above and below-ground biomass (other than in the context of land 
use change) – but CFP-PCR actively encourages practitioners to report the sequestration figure 
separately to the core results.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
Soil carbon changes (other than in the context of land use change) which is not aligned with 
the ISO 14067 
 
 
Figure 9.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Summary of GHG emissions included or excluded in the Carbon Footprinting.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Discrepancies between 
guidelines are highlighted.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
“Short biogenic carbon cycle”  
For food and feed, emissions and removals from biogenic sources that become part of the product are 
excluded because the carbon is not stored for a long period.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
They are considered neutral from a global 
warming point of view.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: There are exceptions to this rule in PAS2050 and CFP-PCR for green coffee (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
biogenic carbon 
emissions and removal to include): 
> emissions and removals of biogenic carbon used in the production of food and feed (e.g. in 
burning biomass for fuel) where that biogenic carbon does not become part of the product; 
> non-CO2 emissions arising from degradation of waste food and feed and enteric fermentation 
(given differences in radiative forcing of various C-compound GHG); 
> any biogenic component in material that is part of the final product but is not intended to be 
ingested (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: packaging).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In addition to these exceptions, emissions and removals from biogenic sources within the frame of 
long-term LULUC should be accounted for (biogenic CO2 is not considered as neutral in this context 
due to the long-term time frame).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
37 
 
Methodological gap/flexibility:  
• 
Soil carbon shall be included according to ISO14067, but excluded in CFP – PCR Green Coffee 
(2013). Although carbon storage (both soils and standing biomass) holds a potentially 
significant mitigation opportunity for the coffee production sector, the CFP-PCR recommends 
to exclude changes in soil organic matter (carbon) and standing biomass, but encourages to 
report the sequestration figure separately.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It is intended to fully incorporate carbon 
sequestration calculation guidelines once scientific developments and necessary data are 
generated.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
There is a confusion created by these different guidelines when distinguishing carbon stock 
changes due to LUC or not.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Carbon sequestration on a given land area in any pool, including 
soil organic carbon, actually depends on the previous land use change, because carbon catch 
and release by the biosphere is a time-dependent process so that no proper sequestration can 
actually be considered if the time frame is too short.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
While all the guidelines refer to some 
part of IPCC guidelines (2006), the only way to be consistent is to consistently apply IPCC Tier 
1 for both LU and LUC stock variations (c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: section 3.3).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
IPCC Gain-Loss method proposes a 
more dynamic approach to stock changes that may rely on shorter time frames but those are 
only consistent at national levels, where different areas may be at complementary 
development stages.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Those are hardly relevant for product chains.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Sequestration in any coffee plantation is to be considered in comparison to previous land use (pools 
and time frame must be consistent).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Given the critical impact of LULUC on carbon footprint, we 
dedicated a complete section of recommendations to this matter.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Data origin 
The CFP-PCR emphasises the collection and use of ‘specific’ data (gathered from the actual activity 
or outcome where product-specific processes are carried out) that we also referred to as site-specific 
data in the report (c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: glossary).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Specific data are required for the farming and milling operations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The 
environmental impact of the processes where the other generic data are used must not exceed 10% 
of the overall environmental impact from the product system.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: It is important to mention that the terminology regarding the type of data varies among guidelines.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
While CFP-PCR focuses on site-specific data, ISO 14067 differentiates between site-specific data and 
primary data as follows: All site-specific data are primary data but not all primary data are site-specific 
data.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Indeed, the ISO 14067 specifies that “Primary data that are not site-specific data, based on global 
or regional averages, collected by regional or international organisations and which have undergone 
third-party verification should be used when the collection of site-specific data is not practicable”.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Varying terminologies create confusion, so that carbon footprint studies should always display a 
glossary of key terms.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
38 
 
Data quality  
Data should be of quality that reduces uncertainty and bias as much as possible.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
ISO 14067 and 
GHG protocol provides criteria regarding data quality, but, as mentioned in the CPF-PCR, the most 
extensive recommendations can be found in the ILCD handbook (now PEF).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
parameter uncertainty for EFs and activity data) 
Note that some of the above-mentioned criteria are redundant.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For a more practical data quality 
assessment, the ILCD / PEF guidelines are providing an interesting approach we summarised in section 
3.1.2.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The ISO 14067 mentions that “specific values for data quality requirements can be specified in a 
CFP-PCR”.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Thus, this could be improved in the next update of the CFP-PCR.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Emissions factors 
Emission factors provide an indication of the quantity of GHGs emitted from a particular source or 
activity.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
GHG emissions shall be calculated using the IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas 
Inventories.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Although the CFP-PCR encourages “Tier 2” or “Tier 3” approach (respectively based on 
country-specific information or individual data), the simplest approach “Tier 1” is considered 
appropriate.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It is important to note that various sources need to be combined in order to get the most updated 
values for the various emission factors.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Table 9 and Table 10 in section 3 provides more details on 
default emissions factors and databases.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.2.3 Life Cycle Impact Assessment 
As shown in Table 4, Global Warming Potentials (GWP) relative to CO2 for the 100-year time horizon 
for the various GHG are varying depending on the IPCC Assessment Report years.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The GWP actually 
used in calculations should be the latest available from the IPCC (PAS2050:2011 and ISO 14067).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: “latest” version is not mentioned in the PCF-PCR.

Cirad report 
39 
 
We recommend checking IPCC updates on GWP and clearly reporting which version was used in the 
applied LCIA method. One should be also aware that some LCIA methods may use various versions of 
those IPCC GWP.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

RECIPE (2016), for instance, is based on 20-year, 50-year or 100-year integrated GWP 
depending on the societal model selected.

The hierarchist model RECIPE (H) is the most commonly 
used and relies on the 100-year integrated GWP.

2.2.4 Interpretation, reporting & communication  
Interpretation 
The PCF-PCR does not provide any information on interpretation.

We thus referred to the ISO 14067 
guidelines providing the required steps: 
1.

An evaluation that considers completeness, sensitivity and consistency checks;

text:
Results shall be interpreted according to the goal and scope of the study and shall:  
• 
Include a quantitative and/or qualitative assessment of uncertainty, 
• 
Identify and document the selected allocation methods (section 2.2.1.

text:
), 
• 
Identify the limitations of the study, including:  
o The focus on climate change as the single impact category: decisions about product 
impacts that are only based on a single environmental issue can be in conflict with goals 
and objectives related to other environmental issues) 
o Limitations related to the methodology (e.g.

text:
system boundary, availability and selection 
of appropriate data sources, allocation rules, assumptions regarding the transport)  
o Ideally, interpretation should also include: 
• 
a sensitivity check for significant inputs, outputs and methodological choices (including

allocation methods) in order to understand the sensitivity and uncertainty of the results 
• 
an assessment of the influence of alternative use profiles and end-of-life scenarios on the 
results.

Study report 
Contrary to the PCR for Espresso and Moka, the PCF-PCR for green coffee does not provide details 
regarding the report structure and requirements apart from mentioning the principles of the WRI’s

coffee should be more specific on this aspect.

Requirement for reporting/communication depends on the goal and scope of the study.

It may be voluntary or mandatory, 
international, national or sub-national).
