2.3 Review to fill specific gaps  
Main identified gaps concerned the quantification of biomass and related LUC impacts, the 
identification and accounting for co-products, waste and their emissions, and the use of biochar.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
A 
review of the knowledge available was carried out in order to provide recommendations on methods 
and data to be used.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.3.1 Biomass estimation and allometric data    
Biogenic carbon is stored in the above- and belowground biomass of the coffee plantation (coffee 
bushes and other trees) among other carbon pools.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Biometric measurements of bushes or trees are 
converted into biomass values using empirical allometric models.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
An allometric model is a 
mathematical equation that allows relating one or more easily measured variables (for example 
diameter at 15 cm for coffee bushes or diameter at breast height for shade trees, height, age) to 
estimate a variable otherwise difficult to measure (for example volume, biomass, carbon).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Such 
allometric equations are therefore commonly used to assess the above- and belowground biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In 
this section we reviewed the existing estimations and ways to assess these two pools of carbon.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.3.1.1 Arabica coffee 
Field measurements of above-ground and below-ground biomass in Arabica coffee trees have 
yielded several allometric models, fitted with either the measured stem diameter, coffee tree height, 
or a combination of both.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Stem diameters are often measured at 15 cm or 40 cm from the ground for 
maximum accuracy (Segura 2006, Andrade 2018, Negash 2013).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, in the case of regularly 
stumped coffee trees, large stumps prevent these measurements close to the ground, in which case 
the diameters are measured on top of the stump and at the base of new re-sprouting stems, or at 
breast height (Lugo-Pérez 2023).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The stump biomass can then be estimated separately from the other 
tree components (Segura 2006, Defrenet 2016).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
When coffee trees are managed with several stems, 
some authors tend to favour the use of basal area to aggregate the multiple stems of one coffee plant 
before fitting their allometric model (Defrenet 2016, Lugo-Pérez 2023).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
We only found one allometric 
model fitted on stem circumferences (Guillemot 2018).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
All allometric models expressed the biomass 
in mass of dry matter (DM) (Figure 11).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The various allometric models show that the above-ground biomass of coffee trees with a stem 
diameter between 4 cm and 8 cm ranges from 1.5 to 5 kg DM/tree in the case of dwarf coffee cultivars 
planted at high densities (2500-6000 tree/ha). Negash (2016) suggests the only allometric model with 
significantly higher estimates of above-ground biomass, up to 78 kg DM/tree for trees with stem 
diameters of 23 cm.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, this model applies to old Ethiopian varieties, with much larger (5-23 cm) 
and higher (5-7 m) stems than the usual dwarf coffee cultivars, as well as much lower planting 
densities.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Only in these specific conditions can this model apply.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
44 
 
 
Figure 11.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Above-ground biomass of arabica coffee trees estimated from several allometric models within their 
range of application.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Allometric models were fitted with stem diameter at 15 cm (d15), stem diameter at 40 cm 
(d40), basal area (ba), or stem circumference at 30 cm (c30) 
Note 1. we assume 2 stems per coffee trees in Defrenet (2016) and Lugo-Perez (2023) 
Note 2: d15 is approximated as DBH*2 in Lugo-Perez (2023) 
Note 3: values from Defrenet (2016) only consider the biomass from the stump itself, not considering the biomass 
from the stems, therefore underestimating the total above-ground biomass 
Note 4: projected crown area is estimated at 4 m2/tree in Guillemot (2018) 
Note 5: Basal area and stem circumferences were converted into stem diameters when needed, using simple 
geometry.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
When using allometric models, it is crucial to keep in mind orders of magnitude to check and 
validate the results.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The above allometric models all yield similar orders of magnitude of above-ground 
arabica coffee biomass per tree or per unit area.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The following section details rough calculations to 
help readers grasp these orders of magnitudes20.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Considering arabica coffee farm densities around 5,000 trees/ha in the case of intensively managed 
dwarf cultivars, as is common in Latin America, and an average AGB around 1.5 kg DM/tree (Segura 
2006, Andrade 2018), the AGB per unit area amounts to 7.5 t DM/ha. In case of older trees, the AGB 
can fetch up to 4 kg DM/tree, and the AGB per unit area can go up to 20 t DM/ha.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Teran-Ramirez (2018) 
finds a similar result in Mexico, with 5 t DM/ha in coffee systems under low levels of shade and less 
intensive management practices.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The AGB can go as low as 1 t DM/ha in highly shaded and diversified 
systems.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: These rough orders of magnitude still hold in very different systems.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For example, in shaded 
coffee systems based on larger coffee trees planted at the lower density of 2,200 trees/ha in India, 
Guillemot (2018) observes AGB between 0 and 5 kg DM/tree, and an average AGB per unit area 
between 6 and 10 t DM/ha. Going one step further in completely different coffee systems, in the case 
of old coffee trees in forest-gardens in Ethiopia (Negash 2013), the average above-ground biomass 
goes up to 23 kg DM/tree.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, with an estimate density of 400 to 500 coffee trees/ha commonly 
found in these traditional enset-coffee gardens (Abebe et al., 2013), the AGB would amount to 10 t 
DM/ha, once again within the same order of magnitude as the other coffee-agroforestry systems.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
20 Defrenet (2016), Ehrenbergerova (2016) and Niguse (2022) were discarded from the calculations of orders of magnitude, 
for there were concerns regarding either their datasets or some other important indicators in these articles 

Cirad report 
45 
 
2.3.1.2 Robusta coffee 
There is less information available for Robusta coffee growth than for Arabica coffee growth.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The 
only peer-reviewed allometric equation found to estimate above-ground biomass of Coffea canephora 
was modelled after coffee trees found in Indian agroforestry systems (Guillemot 2018).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This equation 
relies on the stem circumference at 30 cm as well as the projected crown area.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Another study, 
conducted in Cuba, shows a growth curve for the first five years of Robusta coffee trees after planting 
or after pruning, and constitutes an interesting comparison (Bustamante 2015) (Figure 12. Comparison 
of above-ground biomass for Robusta coffee trees planted at a density of 2 222/ha  
For the purpose of comparison, we made the rough assumption that the stem diameter at 30 cm 
increases by 1.0 cm/year (Podong (2021) estimates the DBH growth at 0.7 cm/year).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Furthermore, the 
projected crown area is estimated from the planting density (for instance a density of 2 222 trees/ha 
in Bustamante (2015) results in PCA = 4.5 m2).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Under these assumptions, the above-ground biomass 
estimated from Bustamante (2015) is higher than the above-ground biomass estimated from Guillemot 
(2018)’s allometric equation, but the gap between the two curves is narrowing down towards 4 to 5 
years old.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Considering that Guillemot (2018) developed its allometric model from older coffee trees, it 
makes sense to avoid its use for coffee trees below 5 years old and to rely on it for older coffee.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In Cuba, the Robusta coffee trees are pruned after 5 years, when the above-ground biomass reaches 
16.5 t DM/ha.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This coincides with the fact that the biomass accumulation curve is slowing down, and 
it therefore could be expected that the biomass accumulation would reach a plateau after a few more 
years without rejuvenation, roughly around ~10 kg DM/tree, equivalent to ~22 t DM/ha under their 
planting density of 2 222 trees/ha.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In comparison, in Vietnam, coffee trees are planted at a theoretical 
density of 1111 trees/ha but an average density of 1,000 trees/ha (Rigal 2023).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Guillemot (2018) 
indicates that 10 to 15-year old trees would sequester an average 14-24 kg DM/tree, thus an 
approximate 14-24 t DM/ha, in line with the estimated 20 t DM/ha from D’haeze (2021)21 (also relying 
on Guillemot 2018) and with the 34-38.7 t CO2eq/ha equivalent to 18.5-21 t DM/ha from Kuit (2020).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Figure 12.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Comparison of above-ground biomass for Robusta coffee trees planted at a density of 2 222/ha  
                                                             
21 From D'haeze 2021 report Optimizing water use in the Central Highlands of Viet Nam 

Cirad report 
46 
 
 
It should be noted that an allometric model based on tree age was developed by Kuit (2020) for 
Robusta coffee in Vietnam.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, this specific growth curve yields unreasonable results: for 
instance, the above-ground biomass of 3-year old coffee trees would amount to 30 kg DM/tree, more 
than 5 times the values of Bustamante (2015).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
We believe that this may come from a mistake in units 
or in one of the formulas displayed in the report.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Indeed, other results from that same report are in 
line with Guillemot (2018).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In particular, it is said that monocropping coffee systems store 40 t C/ha, 
equivalent to 24 kg DM/tree for a density of 1,008 trees/ha and coffee trees on average 15 years old 
(D’haeze 2021, Kuit 2020).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
With the above assumptions, Guillemot (2018) also estimates the above 
ground biomass of 15-year old coffee trees at 24 kg DM/tree.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.3.1.3 Shade trees 
In agroforestry systems, most of the above-ground biomass belongs to shade trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The precise 
estimation of standing biomass in shade trees is thus more impactful to the total carbon balance than 
the precise estimation of biomass in coffee trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Yet, the high diversity of intercropped tree species 
and the large range of growing conditions increase the complexity of analysis.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the section below, we 
divide shade tree species into two categories: fruit trees vs other trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Fruit tree species 
When it comes to fruit trees, there are a number of published articles estimating their standing 
biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, a close look at their methodology reveals that the majority of these studies rely on 
a single allometric model, sometimes referred to Andrade et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2008), and other times referred to as 
Somarriba et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Both references actually provide the same allometric model, based on an 
unpublished dataset derived from CATIE institute.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
AGB of fruit tree (kg DM/tree) = 0.0776 * DBH (cm) ^ 2.64  
 
 
Equation 1 
Range of application: DBH from 1.9 to 46.5 cm 
Interestingly, Kuit (2021) provides a database of species-specific allometric models for a panel of 
tree species commonly found in Vietnam, including jackfruit, durian, and avocado trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, 
these growth models are site specific since they are based on tree age rather than on shape-related 
input variables.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In Northwest Vietnam, under less favourable growing conditions, it is estimated that 
jackfruit trees grow 2 to 3 times slower (Figure 13. Comparison of the standing biomass in jackfruit 
trees based on 3 datasets: Kuit (2021) from Central Vietnam; an unpublished dataset from SIPA project 
for Northwest Vietnam; an unpublished dataset from Northwest Vietnam relating jackfruit age and 
DBH fed to the default allometric equation developed by Andrade (2008)This shows the difficulty to 
generalise results from site-specific models.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
We actually suspect that Kuit developed a model of stem 
diameter as a function of tree age, and thereon used this data to model the aboveground tree biomass 
based on default allometric models, such as Andrade (2008), rather than felling trees and weighting 
their components.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: This strategy can provide relatively accurate and site-specific data at low cost.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Generally speaking, we discourage the use of allometric models based on age as the main input 
variable (example: Quantis report for Cool Farm Tool).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
These models are extremely simple to use, since 
they do not require on-farm measurement of tree size.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
They are also well adapted to the modelling of 
biogenic carbon sequestration throughout the whole duration of the farming system, as it is easy to 
change the age to estimate biomass at different times.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, they come with high levels of 

Cirad report 
47 
 
uncertainties related to tree growth rate, depending among others on local climate, soil, and 
management practices.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Figure 13.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Comparison of the standing biomass in jackfruit trees based on 3 datasets: Kuit (2021) from Central 
Vietnam; an unpublished dataset from SIPA project for Northwest Vietnam; an unpublished dataset from 
Northwest Vietnam relating jackfruit age and DBH fed to the default allometric equation developed by Andrade 
(2008) 
 
Other tree species 
Many more allometric models are available for other tree species, from general models to species- 
and site-specific ones.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Below are some examples (AGB is expressed in kg DM/tree, DBH in cm, Height 
in m) Figure 14:  
➢ Chave (2014) for tropical forest stands:  
○ 
Mixed species: AGB = 0.0673 * (q * DBH ^2 * H) ^ 0.976   
 
Equation 2 
where q is the wood density (g.cm-3) 
➢ Acosta Mireles (2002) in Mexico:  
○ 
Quercus, Liquidambar, Inga: AGB = 0.112 * DBH ^ 2.412   
 
Equation 3 
○ 
Alnus, Clethra, Rapaeca: AGB = 0.140 * DBH ^ 2.189  
 
 
Equation 4 
➢ Segura 2006 in Nicaragua:  
○ 
Inga spp: AGB= 0.129 * DBH ^ 2.317  
 
 
 
 
Equation 5 
○ 
Cordia alliodora: AGB = 0.176 * DBH ^ 2.072  
 
 
 
Equation 6 
➢ Navar (2009) in tropical dry forests in Mexico:  
○ 
Pinus spp: AGB = 0.123 * DBH ^ 2.396   
 
 
 
Equation 7 

Cirad report 
48 
 
○ 
Quercus spp: AGB = 0.089 * DBH ^2.523  
 
 
 
Equation 8 
 
 
Figure 14.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Comparison of several above-ground biomass allometric equations based on DBH.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For Chinese fir, a 
relationship between DBH and H was derived from Li et al (2015) and fed into Chave (2014)’s allometric equation, 
considering a wood density of 0.3 g/cm3 
 
Surprisingly, the estimated above-ground biomass of fruit trees (Andrade, 2008) is always higher 
than that estimated for other trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
A possible reason to explain this difference might lie in the ratio 
of branch mass over stem mass (often referred to as biomass expansion factor) in fruit trees, higher 
than in most other tree species.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Still, this raises the question of accuracy in Andrade (2008) allometric 
model.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For this reason, and to avoid large overestimation in biomass for large fruit trees, we 
recommend to limit the use of Andrade (2008) to fruit trees with DBH ≤ 25 cm.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.3.1.4 Below-ground biomass 
Belowground biomass commonly accounts for approximately 20–30% of total carbon allocation of 
a tree (Armson, 1977; Young, 1989; Oelbermann et al., 2005) and can contribute to a considerable 
portion of the total inputs to soil organic matter (Nye and Greenland, 1962; Nye, 1960; Nair/Dury, 
1989).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For tropical and subtropical forests, the root to shoot ratio ranges in the IPCC 2006 guidelines 
(Annex 3A.1, Table 3A.1.8) between 0.24 and 0.42.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, for coffee plantations, few studies exist concerning the assessment of belowground 
biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Dossa et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2008) quantified the total vegetation biomass and biomass distribution in a 
mature coffee plantation (Coffea canephora var robusta) with and without shade of Albizia 
adianthifolia in Southwestern Togo.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Coffee coarse root biomass (>10 mm diameter) was estimated by 
excavating the coffee root from a 0.40 m deep hole stretching up to midpoint between the felled coffee 

Cirad report 
49 
 
bush and the next one.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Biomass of fine roots (<10 mm diameter) was determined by means of a 20 x 
20 x 20 cm3 metal box with cutting edge used to take soil monoliths.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: For each coffee system, i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
shaded 
coffee plot (1230 plants per hectare) and open-grown coffee plot (1267 plants per hectare), soil 
monoliths were taken from four random locations per subplot (replicate) at 0–20 and 20–40 cm 
depths.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In this study, coarse roots of coffee bushes accounted for 3.6 +/- 0.4 t DM/ha and 10.7 +/- 1.1 
t DM/ha for fine roots (from coffee bushes and Albizia trees) in shaded coffee plots. In open-grown 
coffee plots, coarse roots of coffee bushes accounted for 5.3 +/- 0.8 t DM/ha and 13 +/- 1.1 t DM/ha 
for fine roots.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: These values are slightly higher though similar to Guillemot et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Therefore, 
Dossa et al (2008) assessed a belowground biomass to total stand biomass ratio of 0.19 in the shaded 
coffee system (coffee and shade tree combined), while 0.48 in the open-grown coffee system.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Defrenet et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2016) carried out a study in an agroforestry coffee (arabica) plantation (5,580 plants 
per hectare) in Costa Rica and measured the root biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
They performed root excavation in the row 
and inter-row of the plantation to a depth of 150 cm, and extrapolated to the whole rooting profile (4 
m) effectively colonised by roots, considering tap, coarse (<10 mm) and medium (2–10 mm) roots, as 
well as ephemeral (fine <2 mm) roots.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
They showed that the total root biomass in coffee plants was 
preferentially distributed just below the surface with nearly 30% of roots contained in the top 10 cm 
of soil and 55% in the top 30 cm of soil.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This amount was 87% in the top 1 m and up to 92% at 1.5 m. 
Therefore, only 8% of the total root biomass was found at depth > 1.5 m. They found a value of 18.34 
t DM/ha and a root to shoot ratio of 0.49 for all roots, or 0.29 for perennial roots only.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This high ratio 
can be a consequence of the management practices, in particular the shoot pruning.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The value of 
belowground biomass found in this study was comparable to the one found by Dossa et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Indeed, considering that roughly 70% of the amount of root is found between 0 and 40 cm depth, for 
a shaded coffee system, approximately the belowground biomass would account for 20 t DM/ha 
according to data given by Dossa et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Conversely, values of below ground biomass per coffee 
shrub are not consistent between the two studies likely due to very different planting density.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Defrenet 
et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2016) developed the following allometric equation to assess the total root biomass: 
Y = 14.96 X + 1749.33  
 
 
 
 
 
 
Equation 9 
where Y is the total root biomass in gram of dry matter 
and X is the basal area at collar in cm2 
This equation is valid for a diameter at the collar between 0 and 16 cm.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Another and last comparison point was found in Siles et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2010), which studied arabica coffee 
trees in Costa Rica, in both agroforestry and monoculture farming systems.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The authors estimated the 
aerial biomass of coffee trees (excluding leaf) between 14.2 and 15.5 t DM/ha, and the below-ground 
biomass of coarse roots between 5.1 and 5.2 t DM/ha, therefore leading to a root-to-shoot ratio of 
0.33-0.37. Furthermore, the sampling of fine root biomass (<2 mm) during the rainy season and at 
different locations related to the coffee row and inter-row, and to the distance to shade trees, resulted 
in an additional biomass of 4.1 to 4.7 t DM/ha.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The three above studies all agree that root-to-shoot ratios specifically developed for coffee trees 
are larger than root-to-shoot ratios developed for tropical forest.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For coarse roots (> 2mm), a value of 
0.40 seems reasonable for both Arabica and Robusta coffee trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Such a default value does not 
consider fine roots that are repeatedly reported to compose a significant fraction of the below-ground 

Cirad report 
50 
 
biomass in coffee plantations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, as highlighted in the IPCC Guidelines22, it is often empirically 
challenging to distinguish fine roots from soil organic matter of litter.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Similarly, Quantis justifies the 
exclusion of fine roots from carbon accounting since fine roots are assumed to die, decompose and 
regrow every year, while sequestering and emitting biogenic carbon dioxide, and modifying the soil 
organic carbon pool.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Therefore, accounting only for coarse roots is simultaneously, more convenient, 
realistic and conservative.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It is also worth mentioning that several publications related to coffee plantations apply the 
allometric equation developed by Cairns et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(1997): 
Root biomass (t DM/ha) = exp(-1.0850+0.9256*ln(AGB))  
 
 
Equation 10 
According to this equation, the root to shoot ratio ranges between 0.23 and 0.34.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, this 
equation was developed for upland forests and is therefore not specific to coffee plantations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
According to the above coffee-specific studies, it leads to underestimating the below-ground biomass 
of coffee.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
A higher value of root to shoot ratio should be applied for coffee plantation to fully consider 
the whole rooting depth and the large number of fine roots, especially in the case of regularly stumped 
coffee trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.3.1.5 Biomass and carbon per area unit  
The review of studies reporting values for both above and below-ground biomass was illustrated in 
Figure 15.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The figure does not report all studies in an exhaustive manner; it aims at illustrating the 
balance between, on the one hand, biomass in coffee trees versus biomass in associated trees, and on 
the other hand, the balance between above-ground and below-ground biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
From this representation, it appears clearly that the biomass increases with the complexity of the 
farming systems: Full sun monoculture < simple agroforestry < complex agroforestry < coffee in semi-
forest. Furthermore, while coffee trees represent the main biomass pool in monoculture systems, they 
only represent a small fraction of the biomass in the most complex agroforestry systems. In these 
diversified systems, associated trees represent the main pool of biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Some of the studies also report the biomass values for non-perennial woody biomass: litter, 
herbaceous cover and dead wood.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Specific on-farm measurements must be set up to estimate this 
pool of biomass as it cannot be accounted for with allometric models.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It might be an important 
contributor to nutrient cycling in the system, but it only has an overall limited impact on the biomass 
balance.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This biomass should not be accounted for within the LULUC balance but some emissions 
(other from biogenic CO2) from residue decay may be part of the carbon footprint.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Wherever it was 
estimated, it was lower than 10 t DM/ha, and was often the smallest pool of estimated biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: The figure represents biomass only (Figure 15).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Although not the focus of this section, it is important 
to remember that soil organic carbon also represents a large pool of carbon in ecosystems. Hence, it 
appeared necessary to represent and compare these different carbon pools, based on the few studies 
that report values for both biogenic and soil organic carbon (Figure 16). Values for soil organic carbon 
are reported for different depths, with no harmonised protocol, complexifying the representation. The 
figure shows that soil organic carbon gathers most of below-ground carbon, with roughly 100 t C/ha in 
the first 40 cm.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This carbon pool alone is substantially larger than all biogenic carbon from coffee trees 
in full sun monoculture and simple agroforestry systems.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
22 https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/gpglulucf/gpglulucf_files/Glossary_Acronyms_BasicInfo/Glossary.pdf

value for tropical rainforests was derived from IPCC guidelines (2019) as a comparison point, but it should be

2.3.2 Co-products and waste management  
Co-products can have various meanings or extents in LCA or carbon footprinting (c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: glossary).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In 
this report, in its broad sense, co-products include all other products, residues or waste produced 
within the considered system besides green coffee.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Following a mass balance approach, considering 
all co-products, being valued, recycled or not, is necessary in order to avoid hidden pollution sources.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Related potential impacts due to either added treatment and/or transport or direct field emissions 
should be fully assessed then partitioned or not depending on whether a co-product stays or exits the 
assessed system.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Details on the recommendations regarding the quantification of emissions and 
inclusion or not in the carbon footprint are given in section 3.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The following section proposes a state-
of-the-art of potential co-products and management options in the coffee sector.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
First, at the coffee plantation level, large amounts of crop residues are generated in the field due 
to management practices (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: crop and trees associations, pruning, etc.).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For instance, it has been 
estimated that 32 million t of wood residues are generated annually in Brazil coffee plantations due to 
pruning.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Moreover, despite the difficulty of estimating residual leaves biomass (due to pruning, natural 
or stress-induced defoliation), there are estimations of 5.5 t DM/ha being shed in Brazil, where planting 
densities are in the order of 4000-5000 plants/ha (Mendoza Martinez et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It has been 
suggested that coffee lignocellulosic residual biomass is suitable for thermochemical conversion, as its 
low heating value ranges from 17.5 to 18 MJ/kg (Garcia-Freites et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2020), which is comparable, and 
even slightly higher that of most wood pellets produced from residual wood (Telmo and Lousada 2011).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Even if coffee crop residues are not explicitly valorised, if left in the field they contribute to soil carbon 
turnover as C inputs to soil but also potentially to GHG emissions such as N2O, which need to be 
accounted for.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As highlighted in section 2.1, the carbon footprint of coffee plantations is often 
dominated by fertilisation, and occasionally heavily impacted by LUC when associated with 
deforestation.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Further down the chain, co-products from coffee cherries processing into green coffee (Figure 17) 
consist of pulp or husk, depending on the processing method: wet (full-washed) or dry, respectively.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
A 
third processing method, called semi-washed, combines elements of wet and dry processing (Sinaga 
and Julianti 2021).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Processing separates the seed from the surrounding skin (exocarp), mucilaginous 
pulp (mesocarp) and parchment/hull and silverskin (endocarp), fractions that together represent ~80% 
of the weight of the fresh cherry (Woldesenbet, 2015).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Wet processing generates as well large volumes 
of wastewater, as 1-15 l of freshwater are used to process 1 kg of beans (Sengupta et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Moreover, both processes generate important amounts of residual biomass such as leaves, in the order 
of 5% of input raw material (Karim et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Yields of green coffee from the three processes are 
estimated at 19-24% of the fresh cherry (Echeverria and Nuti, 2017; Karim et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2019; Rotta et al., 
2021).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The carbon footprint of green coffee processing is dominated by energy use and water 
consumption (Nab and Maslin, 2020), thus a gradient of energy use intensity is expected to be 
associated with the continuum of processing industrialisation intensity.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: For instance, Pramulya et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2019) suggest a cumulative energy demand for a semi-washed system in India of 3 068 MJ/t green 
coffee, 54% of which consists of sun energy during drying and finishing.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Usva et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2020) studied the 
carbon footprint of coffee sourced from four Latin American producing countries following wet 
processing and consumed in Finland, finding energy consumptions between 114 and 3 110 MJ/t green 
coffee, depending on the level of reliance on direct solar energy and energy generation from 
processing residues.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
53 
 
Solid residues representing 55-67% of the whole cherry and liquid processing effluents representing 
20-45 l per kg of beans (Sengupta et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2020; Laili et al, 2022), are often disposed of without further 
valorisation, which represents an environmental pressure in producing countries.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For instance, wet 
processing effluents have been indicated to feature between 1200 and 35 000 mg BOD/l (Beyene et 
al, 2012; Laili et al, 2022).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Moreover, said effluents may include agrochemical residues, high COD loads 
in the order of 3 000 - 15 000 mg/l, and feature pH<7 (Sengupta et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: 2020; Laili et al, 2022).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Semi-
washed processing liquid effluents (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
wash water), may feature higher organic loads than pulp water 
from wet processing (Chanakya and De Alwis, 2004).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The improper disposal of solid and liquid effluents 
contributes to climate change, acidification, eutrophication and (eco)toxicity.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Several valorisation pathways for green coffee residues were proposed (Table 6).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Among the 
agricultural applications of coffee pulp, as summarised in the literature (Marin-Tello et al., 2020; Serna-
Jiménez et al., 2022), the following three main uses and associated pathways were identified: 
• 
As organic fertiliser: composting with or without inoculation with mycorrhizae, 
vermicomposting, and co-composting with other agricultural residues.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
As organic amendment: application of composted or raw pulp in combination with legumes 
and/or mycorrhizae, towards mechanical improvement, phytoremediation, or stabilisation of 
trace elements.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
As a source of substances (vinegar, proanthocyanidin, raw pulp) for biological control.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Green coffee residues feature variable content of carbon, but often around 50% FM, with values 
for pulp ranging from 30 to 60% FM, and those for husks from 42 to 60% FM.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Gross calorific value of 
husks (dry route) ranges between 19 and 25 MJ/kg DM (https://phyllis.nl/), and that of pulp (wet and 
semi-washed routes) is ~14 MJ/kg FM (Twinomuhwezi et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Nitrogen content in both fresh and 
composted husk and pulp are in the order of: 
• 
raw pulp 2.23% N (Netsere and Takala 2021) 
• 
composted pulp 1.39 (1.0-2.3)% N (Netsere and Takala 2021; Fatmawati et al. 2022) 
• 
raw husk 1.71 (0.7-2.9)% N (Netsere and Takala 2021, https://phyllis.nl/) 
• 
composted husk 1.15% N (Netsere and Takala 2021) 
Composting of pulp and husk has been amply identified as a key pathway for agricultural 
valorisation (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Kassa et al., 2012; Marin-Tello et al., 2020; Nguyen et al., 2013), yet alternative 
valorisation strategies also exist (Marin-Tello et al., 2020; Serna-Jiménez et al., 2022): biological 
control, animal feed, human food, feedstock for biorefineries, feedstock for energy.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Composting 
emissions can drastically vary between 0.03 and 129 g CH4/kg substrate, depending on the composting 
technology, the ratio of green coffee residues to co-substrate and other conditions, yet they remain 
lower than those from open field deposition (San Martin Ruiz et al, 2018, 2021).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Coffee management practices vary highly across producing countries.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For instance, synthetic 
fertilisers are seldom used in Ethiopia and Uganda, while in Colombia there are efforts to substitute it 
with organic fertilisers produced on-farm by composting processing residues (Dawid, 2018).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
One key 
product (that can be produced from coffee husks) occasionally applied in coffee systems is biochar, 
widely promoted towards improving soil properties and SOC sequestration (Duku et al., 2011; Hansson 
et al., 2021). The benefits of biochar application to coffee nurseries has been explored (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Herviyanti 
et al., 2020), including its phytosanitary effects (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Suci Rahayu and Puspita Sari, 2017).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
54

(2019), Echeverria and Nuti (2017), Sevenster and

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2011) 
2.3.3 Insights on biochar use and potential 
Biochar production and application from non-valorised coffee residues might be of interest to 
mitigate GHG emissions and/or for agronomic purposes. In this section, we reviewed the existing 
literature on the GHG balance of biochar production and application, the technological processes to 
produce biochar from coffee residues, and the agronomic impacts of the application of biochar in 
coffee plantations. 2.3.3.1 GHG balance of biochar production and application 
Biochar involves transforming plant biomass into a product similar to charcoal.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The biomass is 
pyrolysed (heated to between 350 and 900 degrees Celsius in an oxygen-free atmosphere), which 
radically changes its chemical composition.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Its chemical structure becomes highly aromatic (McBeath 
& Smernik 2009), making it difficult for microorganisms to break it down.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This material also has reactive 
surfaces that bind strongly with mineral surfaces, reducing its accessibility to micro-organisms (Singh 
et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This material can then be brought to agricultural soils where its resistance to microbial 
degradation allows carbon storage over centuries, even millennia (Singh et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In addition to 
these carbon storage capacities, biochar has been shown to modify ecosystem properties such as soil 
fertility and resilience or pollution remediation. The effectiveness of biochar in storing carbon over the 
long term and its co-benefits have drawn attention towards its large-scale application, with some 
successes, but also potentially significant feedback problems that are still poorly understood. The ability of biochar to store carbon effectively over the long term depends on the balance 
between the amount of carbon lost to the atmosphere during its production (and application) and the 
amount and duration of storage of organic matter in the ecosystem.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
During the pyrolysis process, a 
large proportion of the carbon is lost, as the carbon and oxygen present in the organic matter react 
and form CO2 until the oxygen source is exhausted.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This generally represents more than 50% of the 
organic matter.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
If a positive mass balance of carbon is to be achieved in biochar production, this means 
that the remaining carbonaceous material must remain in the environment for much longer to 
compensate for the losses that occur during pyrolysis, which generally takes several years or even 

Cirad report 
56 
 
decades (Woolf et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Understanding the residence time of biochar in the environment (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
the 
time it takes for the material to be transformed into CO2 or CH4) is therefore essential for assessing its 
effectiveness.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
There is strong scientific consensus that the mean residence time (MRT) of biochar 
carbon in soil is higher than that of all other organic carbon compounds (Coppola et al., 2018; Wang et 
al., 2012,2016b).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Wang Lee et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2016) found that biochar has a small labile C-fraction of 3%, which 
degrades within the first year, and a large recalcitrant C pool of 97% with an MRT of 556 years.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Therefore, the large recalcitrant fraction can contribute directly to long-term C sequestration in soil.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, on the basis of current knowledge, if the application of biochar appears to be effective in 
storing a large quantity of carbon, it is not possible to say precisely for how long and with what long-
term consequences for agro-ecosystems (Schmidt et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, these authors stated that no 
negative agronomic or environmental effects have been consistently demonstrated, so far, for any of 
the parameters evaluated regarding performance (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: yield) and environment.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Regarding other GHG emissions (CH4, N2O) related to the application of biochar, Schmidt et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2021) highlighted, that due to the high variability and insufficient robustness of the studies, it is 
currently only possible to speculate on the reasons for a potential increase or decrease in soil-borne 
CH4 emissions.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, it should be noted that agricultural methane emissions only reach climate-
relevant levels in flooded soils such as in rice cultivation, on former peat soils with near-surface water 
tables or after heavy and extended rainfall events.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Therefore, it should not be of high concern for 
coffee plantations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
On the contrary, the reduction of soil nitrous oxide emissions through biochar 
amendment is one of the best-documented effects of its use.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: According to Schmidt et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2021), there 
is a clear consensus that biochar soil application reduces agricultural N2O emissions.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, further 
research on the permanence of N2O emission reduction is still needed because the vast majority of 
field studies primarily measured emission reduction in the first year after application only.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.3.3.2 Technological processes to produce biochar from coffee residues 
Coffee husks and residues from pruning of coffee bushes can be valuable sources to produce 
biochar if not already valorised by other processes.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As mentioned in the previous section, coffee husk 
is the main by-product of the dry method and is formed by all the layers at once, including dried skin, 
pulp, mucilage, and the parchment (Esquivel et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
When the coffee cherry is dried, ≈12–18% of 
the dried fruit weight is coffee husk (Monaco et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Though available in large quantities throughout the years, the main application of coffee husk has 
been limited to composting, animal feeding or energy production. Most of the coffee husk is disposed 
of in landfills or arable land, usually with no care of its fate and changes to the source of pollution, 
especially in developing countries (Hoseini et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Coffee husk can have several re-uses, but it is 
important to have environment-friendly methods to change it into usable material or material to be 
recycled in nature because of its important content of organic matter, chemical nutrients, and 
secondary compounds.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
57 
 
Kiggundu and Sittamukyoto (2019) studied the pyrolysis parameters to produce biochar from coffee 
husks.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Coffee husk was fed into a batch reactor and heated to temperatures 350˚C, 450˚C and 550˚C 
for residence times 30, 45 and 60 min in a slow pyrolysis anaerobic setting.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
They showed that 
temperature was one of the most important factors that affect the process of biomass pyrolysis.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Biochar yield from coffee husks decreased when the pyrolysis temperature increased, with minimum 
yield of 29.9% recorded at 550°C and maximum yield of 35.09% recorded at 350˚C. They also recorded 
a decrease in the yield of the biochar with the increase in the pyrolysis residence time, with biochar 
maximum yield of 36.87% recorded in 30 min and minimum yield of 34.07% recorded in 60 min at a 
constant temperature.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, in rural areas, having such controlled conditions (temperature, 
anaerobic) might be a challenge.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.3.3.3 Agronomic impacts of biochar application 
Biochar generally have high porosity, high surface area and surface-active properties that lead to 
high absorptive and adsorptive capacity, especially after interaction in soil (Joseph et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As a 
result of these properties, biochar could contribute to avoiding, reducing and reversing land 
degradation through the following documented benefits: 
• 
Improved nutrient use efficiency due to reduced leaching of nitrate and ammonium (e.g., 
Haider et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2017) and increased availability of phosphorus in soils with high phosphorus 
fixation capacity (Liu et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2018), potentially reducing nitrogen and phosphorus fertiliser 
requirements.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
Management of heavy metals and organic pollutants: through reduced bioavailability of 
toxic elements (O’Connor et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: 2018; Peng et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2018), by reducing availability, through 
immobilisation due to increased pH and redox effects (Rizwan et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2016) and adsorption 
on biochar surfaces (Zhang et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2013) thus providing a means of remediating 
contaminated soils, and enabling their utilisation for food production.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
Stimulation of beneficial soil organisms, including earthworms and mycorrhizal fungi (Thies 
et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
Improved porosity and water-holding capacity (Quin et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2014), particularly in sandy soils 
(Omondi et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: 2016), enhancing microbial function during drought (Paetsch et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
Amelioration of soil acidification, through application of biochars with high pH and acid-
neutralising capacity (Chan et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: 2008; Van Zwieten et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
More specifically, the agronomic impacts of application of biochar from coffee husks were assessed 
in different studies.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Ngalani et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2023) showed, in laboratory conditions (incubation) that the 
application of biochar from coffee husks on acid soil had a significant effect on the increase in soil pH 
as compared with control. Similarly, in this study, the incorporation of biochar in soil significantly 
increased the soil electrical conductivity as compared to control.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Finally, the quantity of available P in 
acidic soil significantly increased when amended with biochar.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Reversely, compared to control, 
treatment application of biochar decreased drastically exchangeable acidity as well as exchangeable 
Al and Fe.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Domingues et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2017) pinpointed that the high ash content associated with alkaline 
chemical species such as KHCO3 and CaCO3 made biochar from coffee husks a potential liming agent 
for remediating acidic soils. They also suggested that the high Ca and K contents in coffee husk biomass 
could significantly replace conventional sources of K and Ca, suggesting a high agronomic value for this 
biochar.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Besides, according to Domingues et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2017), high-ash biochar, such as coffee husk, produced 
at low-temperatures (350 and 450°C) exhibited high CEC values, which can be considered as a potential 

Cirad report 
58 
 
applicable material to increase nutrient retention in soil.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Hoseini et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2021) mentioned that studies 
on coffee husk biochar showed improvement in soil chemical properties by increasing pH, electrical 
conductivity, cation exchange capacity, organic matter, total N, and available P. Dume et al. (2015) 
reported that the application of 15 t/ha of coffee husk biochar that had been produced at 500 ◦C 
temperature had positive result on soil fertility and yield. However, as previously mentioned, the key challenge is the availability of coffee husks to produce 
biochar.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For instance the range of production of coffee husks is 100 to 600 kg/ha of coffee plantation, 
meaning around 33 to 200 kg of biochar/ha of coffee plantation, which is far from the usual application 
rates of biochar.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Therefore, residues from pruning of coffee bushes could be a more valuable source 
of biomass to produce biochar.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Yet no specific study assessing the agronomic impacts of such biochar 
was found.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Besides, apart from the type of biochar, the agronomic impacts should be assessed for coffee 
plantation.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Again, such an assessment was not found in the literature.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, some insights might 
be given by studies focused on the effect of biochar application in tree cultures.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Thus, Thomas and 
Gale (2015) examined the literature on how forest trees responded to biochar's soil amendment and 
summarised 17 scientific publications covering 36 tree species with trials both in nurseries and adult 
trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
They reported a mean increase in tree growth of 41% in the treatments with biochar, compared 
with the control without biochar.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Growth increases were particularly pronounced at early growth 
stages, higher in tropical than temperate climates and higher in deciduous trees than conifers, but 
significant for all tree species in all climates.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It should be noted that biochar for tree treatments is 
usually applied in the root zone, usually by precise manual application. When planting a tree, the 
biochar substrate is then added to the planting hole, and for already established trees, it is applied 
either in the topsoil directly around the tree or in holes or furrows around the radius of the tree canopy 
where the use of low biochar doses (<2 t/ha) achieved significant yield increases.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2.3.3.4 LCA impacts of biochar production and application 
There has not been, yet, LCA studies on the comprehensive impacts of biochar production and 
application in coffee plantations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As usual, from a life cycle perspective it is important to consider both 
the production of the biochar itself but also all potential activities and impact up- and further 
downstream.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: In a recent review, Matustik et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2020, concluded that in spite of all the differences across studies, 
being contextual or methodological, there was still a clear trend that application of biochar into 
agricultural soil would provide significant benefits throughout the life cycle of the system.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Across the 
reviewed LCA studies, the main source of GHG emission was the pyrolysis system itself, while the 
impact of transportation was usually low or marginal.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the reviewed studies, the GHG emissions 
caused by the biochar production and handling were always outweighed by the benefit of both carbon 
capture in biochar and the energy production offsets, providing that the co-products of pyrolysis such 
as syngas and bio-oil are recycled.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, carbon sequestration and overall agronomic benefits 
varied among the projects.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Likewise, the impact of biochar manufacture and transport would highly 
depend on the context.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In a scenario analysis of rice and maize productions in China with biochar 
application, Xu et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2019, highlighted how the net GHG balance varied with assumptions on the SOC 
storage (based on IPCC coefficients) and process co-products recycling (Figure).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In another study, 
where those co-products were recycled, biochar transport appeared to be the only remaining GHG 
emission hotspot (Munoz et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

The optimisation of the pyrolysis process and biochar supply to the field: 
a.

2020) producing further benefits in the 
field.

The improvement of soil health and management practices: 
a.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Reduced use of mineral fertilisers, where nitrogen and phosphorus losses would be reduced 
thanks to biochar application (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
=> The benefits in the field depend on the soil and climate contexts and require a systemic 
adaptation of practices, in other words a comprehensive approach of the cropping system by adjusting 
all practices in terms of fertilisers, irrigation, etc., as biochar input only may not be sufficient to harness 
all potential environmental benefits and compensate for biochar embedded environmental costs.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

Cirad report 
60 
 
3 Recommendation on the coffee carbon footprint 
In view of the review of coffee LCA and methodological guidelines, we identified some gaps and 
provided recommendations based on updated research results and detailed guidelines compilation.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This section covers the following recommendations: 
1.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Sampling strategy, including typology and clustering, and data quality appraisal, 
2.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Perennial crop cycle modelling to account for all development stages, 
3.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Emission factors and databases for GHG emissions across the green coffee life cycle, 
4.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
LULUC and estimation of carbon stock in biomass (above and below ground)  
5.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Co-products (residues from plot and mill) handling and wastewater management: 
management practices, composition and associated emission factors, 
6.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Reporting and communication 
 
LCA and carbon footprint studies are strictly codified and one must rely on official guidelines to 
conduct any robust assessment.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
We recommend using the CFP-PCR for green coffee and ISO 14067 as 
a baseline, and to complement it with recommendations in section 3.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As illustrated in Figure 18, these 
could be useful resources for the future update of the CFP-PCR.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
While this report does not substitute 
any existing guidelines, we aimed to provide sound information and recommendations where 
guidelines are not specific or detailed enough.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Hence, in this section, we do not cover all exhaustive 
stages in LCA or carbon footprinting but rather focus on key recommendations to facilitate and 
improve the quality of green coffee carbon footprints.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
On a side note, it is important to mention that regionalisation in LCA has been under-development 
for two decades with new promising development thanks to new LCA open software. Given the global 
scope of this study with no specific insights on some countries, this report does not explore the status 
of LCA regionalisation for any given specific region or country.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Hence recommendations apply 
potentially in all coffee producing regions.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the first section, we focus on the methodological recommendations regarding sampling strategy 
and overall data quality needs to carry out a proper assessment.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Then, we focus on the specificity of 
perennial crop modelling and provide recommendations on ways to proceed, also in agreement with 
the following recommendations on biomass and LULUC accounting.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Finally, we provide exhaustive 
recommendations on comprehensive ways to handle co-products and ensure sound accounting of 
emissions related to crop residues and processing.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:

coffee  
3.1 Recommendation on the sampling strategy and data quality check 
3.1.1 Sampling and typology  
Choosing the sample size is dependent on the objective, the acceptable uncertainty error, the 
anticipated distribution in variation.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Thus, the sampling protocol should rely on the best possible 
knowledge of the system.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Before using any statistical formula (which varies slightly depending on the 
guideline) we recommend designing the sampling protocol on a specific typology of the farms (and the 
post-harvest stages).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Figure 19 provides a decision tree for the sampling protocol, including the guidelines 
recommendation (where relevant) and our recommendations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Below we further detail the most 
frequent and recommended pathway based on a system typology.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Since complete sampling is rarely feasible, the remaining sampling strategies in CFP-CPR are both 
based on the assumption of “homogeneous” population or cluster (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: sub-group).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Homogeneous 
clusters need to be determined by context-relevant typologies to make sure the actual variability is 
captured.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: The cluster selection is thus critical.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
An expert-based typology focusing on how practices 
diversity affects carbon footprint results allows the identification of key variables (ex.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
N fertiliser input, 
yield…).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Amongst the criteria to consider, we recommend that each cluster: 
1.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Must be in identical agroecological potential zones according to Global Agro-ecological Zones 
(GAEZ) classification23, 
2.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Must fit into the same broad cropping system category: i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
monoculture unshaded, 
monoculture shaded, polyculture or agroforestry, 
3.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Must use similar fertiliser type (organic/mineral) and amount (for N fertiliser in particular), 
4.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Must use the same 1st processing technology 
                                                             
23 https://gaez.fao.org/pages/data-viewer

Once clusters are identified, the sample size can be determined based on the square root of the full 
population size weighted by the supply share (CCF-PCR), or a more elaborated approach considering 
the variance of key parameters for each cluster (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

Since N fertilisation is often a key 
variable, we recommend using as a default the standard deviation of kg N inputs/ha/yr.
