We 
thus propose an alternative option of sample size based on expertise, as long as it is based on a robust

3.1.2 Data quality appraisal system  
Qualitative diagnosis24 
The most detailed guidance on the use of the qualitative assessment of data in LCA is provided in 
the latest version of the European Product Environmental Footprint (PEF) Category Rules Guidance 
(2018) (EC 201825).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The data quality rating system (DQR) consists in: 
Four criteria:  
● 
Precision (P)  
● 
Time representativeness (TiR) 
● 
Geographical representativeness (GR) 
● 
Technological representativeness (TeR) 
A two-tier approach to score those criteria depending on the data: 
● 
Primary data: score for precision cannot be higher than 3 and the other scores cannot be 
higher than 2  
● 
Secondary data: scores from 1 to 5 
A formula to aggregate the scores (Equation 11).

text:

(Frischknecht et al.

The total uncertainty 
accounts for a basic uncertainty based on expert knowledge (and varying depending on the type of 
input/output) and the cumulated uncertainty factors related to the five scores, which were recently 
updated based on several datasets compiled by Ciroth et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2016) (see Empirically based uncertainty 
factors for the pedigree matrix in ecoinvent v.3.0).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
66 
 
3.2 Recommendation on the perennial crop cycle modelling 
Perennials, such as coffee trees, differ from annual crops in many aspects arising from their long-
term development.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Perennial long and partitioned cycles (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
immature, then mature phases) imply 
specific management usually combining long-term management strategies and short or medium-term 
adjustments.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It also implies complex and evolving interactions with the ecosystem that affect the 
potential performance of the crop and the efficacy of the management.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Indeed, management feedback 
on the production may be delayed due to the long-term development of the agroecosystem and may 
be more or less direct depending on the harvested product (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
biomass from Miscanthus × giganteus 
versus cherries from coffee trees).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Assessing perennial crops in the same way as annual ones may 
hence induce an important bias notably due to the variability in practices and yields over the plantation 
lifespan or the potential importance of long-term changes in carbon stocks (Mithraratne et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Beyond the scientific logic behind the whole perennial crop cycle modelling, at sector as well as 
individual levels, a comprehensive modelling is also key to be able to monitor management effects and 
track changes over several years.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Annual-like modelling might vary drastically from one year to another 
due only to changes in perennial crop phase or delayed feedback, which may produce confusing 
results.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Recent reviews highlighted the need to better account for the specificities of perennial cropping 
systems within LCA and to harmonise the way LCA of perennial crops is conducted (Bessou et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2013; 
Cerutti et al. 2013; Cerutti et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Studies also exemplified bias in results due to varying choices 
in modelling the perennial crop cycle within LCA (Bessou et al., 2016), including in the specific case of 
coffee in Trinh et al., 2020, as discussed in section 2.1.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, guidelines are not precise enough yet 
regarding the modelling of perennial crops within the LCA framework.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Based on recommendations 
published by Bessou et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(2013), we propose to apply a modular approach to model the perennial 
cropping system as detailed below. The modular approach consists in a weighted average of each key development phase of a perennial 
cropping system depending on its duration over the complete cycle.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The modular approach only 
concerns the plantation within the coffee process chain up to green coffee.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For each phase, considered 
as a module, a data set of at least 2-3 continuous years should be compiled to also account for yearly 
climate variability.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Those datasets should be compiled to compute a mean yearly inventory for each 
phase.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The minimum recommended number of development phases for coffee plantations is 3 (Figure 
20): 
1.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The immature or vegetative phase, when production is null, not yet profitable or too random 
(i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
output set to zero); 
2.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The senescing phase (optional), when production starts to decline slowly but irremediably 
(may or may not occur depending on the intensity of the farming system, notably the 
frequency of replanting).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Depending on data availability and the plantation dynamics, more sub-phases or sub-modules may 
be defined.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: The more the better but following the parsimonious principle; i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
each added sub-module 
should be justified by physiological and productive significant changes across sub-modules.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Moreover, 
a more sophisticated modelling of various sub-modules is only worth it if primary data is available.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
67 
 
 
 
 
Figure 20.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Inputs/outputs data should be collected for at least 2 years of each development phase, also called 
module, then averaged over the whole cycle based on each module duration or weight 
 
According to the modular approach data would be computed according to equations (12 & 13).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: These equations refer to one perennial plantation over a fixed land use area (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: 1 ha).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Equation (12) 
provides the weighted average annual elementary flows of 1 ha plantation when integrating the whole 
cycle.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: It could hence provide the result in the case of a FU of 1 ha plantation.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Elementary flows in LCA 
refer to all inputs and outputs, used materials and emitted substances, at each unit process of the 
product supply chain. The LCI is the list of all elementary flows that are summed up and characterised 
to calculate the impacts.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In a complete LCA, the weighted annual averages should be computed for all 
elementary flows.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the case of carbon footprint, elementary flows only concern the inputs to the 
plantation that lead to GHG emissions on- and off-farm (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
sum of GHG emissions due to the 
manufacture, transport and field application of nitrogen fertilisers) and waste.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Equation (12) needs to 
be divided by the weighted average annual production over the whole cycle, when the FU is in mass 
of output, e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: kg of green coffee.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In this case, the equation (13) is simplified with the total crop cycle 
length cancelled out.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Equation 12 
        
Equation 13 
 
 

Cirad report 
68 
 
Equation (13) stresses that the longer the immature unproductive phase, the higher its contribution 
as the numerator increases but not the denominator.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
On the other hand, if the overall plantation 
duration is increased, the contribution of the immature phase and other fixed costs is reduced, so is 
the averaged result as long as the production does not decrease.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Likewise, if inputs are stopped near 
the end of the cycle, e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
senescing phase, but that some production goes on, the denominator 
increases and not the numerator.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The application of the modular approach can be challenging when little information is available on 
past years or in the case of very young plantations with no perspectives on expected development and 
performance.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
There are, however, ways to overcome such obstacles: 
• 
A same producer may have several plantations in different development phases within similar 
or close-enough pedo-climate and management contexts.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Information from such plantations 
can be concatenated to produce a comprehensive composite data set (interpolation).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Likewise, if young trees are mixed up with older ones through partial replanting, varying 
managements according to tree ages may be found and recorded within a given plantation; 
• 
Scenario analysis can be used to test various options of potential future developments 
(extrapolation), and scenario results may be then averaged.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In all cases, such scenarios are as 
uncertain as modelling LCA only based on a partial cycle.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, at least one scenario is very 
likely to be right, whereas with partial modelling the only result is very likely to be wrong.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The 
use of scenario analysis is also interesting to highlight how potential development may affect 
the carbon footprint and which options should be pursued as far as possible; 
• 
Ultimately, secondary data from literature may be used to model one or more sub-models 
(approximation).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
When facing these challenges, one should test with a sensitivity analysis how assumptions 
influenced the modelling outputs and where largest uncertainties arose.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The estimation of each module duration depends on the plantations specificities and should be 
defined ad hoc by the carbon footprint assessor based on primary data (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: farmer’s survey).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The 
plantation lifespan can greatly vary across regions, cropping systems and management intensities.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For 
instance, full-sun monoculture coffee plantations may only last a decade or so (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
in Brazil), whereas 
old agroforestry plantations may still be producing after 50 years (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: in Angola).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Also, the intensity of 
trimming, pruning or replanting will affect the average duration of coffee tree lifespan and phases 
within this lifespan.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The average duration of each stage should be defined at the plantation level, smoothing out 
variability among trees, i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
some may grow more or less quickly and be more or less productive, as 
well as integrating the replanting strategy, i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: the average age of coffee trees when they are replaced.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In some plantations, variability may be high due to pathogens or non-homogeneous quality of 
seedlings, or for other many reasons.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Also, replanting may be hampered or fostered by many factors 
such as costs or changes in management strategies.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In practical terms, the average durations of phases 
may not be computed on exhaustive records of individual tree histories or prospective futures but 
rather on rough estimates based on farmers’ knowledge and cross-checks with records (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
expenses 
for replanting) and/or field visits.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Over the whole plantation lifespan, within a given finite land area 
(i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
as long as there is no expansion of the used land area), depending on the intensity and frequency 
of the replanting, trees of different ages will co-exist.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The weighted average of all phase averages 

Cirad report 
69 
 
enables the integration in a snapshot of the perennial dynamics in both temporal and spatial 
dimensions (Figure 21).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Figure 21.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The average durations of each development phase over the whole coffee plantation should be 
computed accounting for the variability across the plantation due to the individual tree heterogeneity and/or 
replanting frequency 
 
Further specifications: 
● Land preparation and uprooting/end of life of the plantation shall be accounted for and 
considered as fixed costs amortised over the full cycle.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In practical terms, those fixed costs are 
added to Equation (13) numerator, implicitly considering a one-year timeframe.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Land 
preparation for the first plantation cycle may require more energy input than when 
establishing a second plantation cycle; 
● Although the nursery stage would usually also be included in LCA of perennial cropping 
systems, it may be excluded from the green coffee carbon footprint as its contribution would 
be negligible for the global warming impact indicator, which would be not true for other impact 
indicators such as water depletion or human toxicity (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Cabot Lujambio et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2023, Bessou 
et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The nursery stage should be included, though, in the following cases: 
○ 
Nurseries in greenhouses; 
○ 
Coffee plantations with high planting density (>5000 seedlings/ha) or a plantation 
lifespan <10 years, and intensive nursery management with numerous inputs including 
an automatic irrigation system.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
● Other associated perennials (crops or trees) that would be considered within the coffee system 
due to interactions (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
shade service) should be modelled also based on a modular approach, 
where the modules and the durations would be adapted to the other perennial specificities.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The nursery stage for associated trees with a long lifespan of several decades should not be 
included.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Associated perennials that would be managed completely independently from the 

Cirad report 
70 
 
coffee trees (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
fruit trees with no interaction with the coffee trees) might be kept out of the 
coffee system boundaries and not further investigated.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Perennial cycle modelling with a modular approach 
 
Concept: weighted average of all inputs-outputs by key development phases based on their 
respective durations over the full cycle.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The development phases, also called modules here, may be defined (number and duration) by 
the assessor depending on the coffee plantation specificities and/or prospective scenarios.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: As much as possible, primary data (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
specific field data for a given plantation) should be 
recorded and used.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Where data is missing, one may i) extrapolate from another similar plantation 
managed by the same farmer or group of farmers, ii) interpolate existing data with prospective 
scenarios, or, at last resort, iii) approximate data based on secondary data from literature.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: In all cases of challenging data collection, a sensitivity analysis on main parameters (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
varying 
phase durations, varying yield evolutions or input demands…) should be carried out to check how 
uncertainties propagate up to the final results.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
3.3 Recommendation on LULUC and biomass accounting 
3.3.1 Accounting for coffee plantation biomass within the frame of LULUC 
There are four steps in LULUC assessment: 
1.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Determining whether there has been LUC or not linked to a given coffee plantation; 
2.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Apply steps 2 and 3 in the case of carbon stock changes within a given land use (LU) “remaining 
in the same land use category”, i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: no LUC.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Although the first stage would seem the most obvious because the farmer should be aware of what 
the land use was before planting the coffee trees, it is not.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The main reason lies in the subjective 
choices made by the scientific community, notably in the field of attributional LCA, that are not 
systematically applied consciously.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In a long-term perspective, in any given land area, land uses may have changed many times over 
the years, e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: from native vegetation to grassland up to urban built area, eventually.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The drivers for 
LUC can hardly all be defined nor prioritised.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
At a given point in time, the simplest solution may be to 
only consider the last immediate direct land use change (LUC), providing that any past previous LUC 
impact had been already accounted for (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: paid off or amortised).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
IPCC recommended the 20-year 

Cirad report 
71 
 
timeframe as a minimum delay for natural regrowth on average globally26 (excluding irreversible 
impacts such as biodiversity losses).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
So, if a land use stays unchanged for at least 20 years, it may 
regrow to some original point if left abandoned or kept in a constant applied land use state.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In both 
cases, past LUC is considered paid off and there is no more LUC to consider.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This 20-year span, although 
being continuously discussed, has got a lot of implications in LCA modelling.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As land area is a finite resource, another complexity dimension arises when determining further 
indirect drivers for LUC linked to the connected pressure across various land resources.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Within the LCA 
framework, however, indirect LUC should only be accounted for in consequential LCA since it is 
considered as a rebound effect. In practice, though, some indirect LUC may be also included in 
attributional LCA.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Step 1: Determining whether there was LUC or not linked to a given coffee plantation 
Considering the previous paragraphs, one needs to look at 20 years back to check for LUC or 
continuous land use.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Either the farmer has the historical record of the past 20 years of the coffee 
plantation land area or a national average can be used.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Looking at national data on comprehensive 
land uses enables us to identify which types of land uses have gone through area increase or decrease 
over the investigated time period.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: If a crop, e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: coffee, is among a land use category (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
perennial 
crops) whose overall land area has increased, then this increase percentage will be accounted for as 
LUC share within the coffee plantation (Figure 22).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This procedure was originally recommended by 
PAS2050 based on IPCC guidelines, then implemented in various guidelines such as the GHG Protocol 
or the Blonk tool, which implements global FAO data to compute LUC.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Statistical data for 3 to 5 years 
is usually also averaged on each end of the 20-year span to smooth out yearly variability.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The reference 
to land use “categories'' such as arable land or forest land was originally linked to the IPCC guidelines 
(first editions in 1996), where a land use change was defined as a change from one land use category 
to another one; i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: a change from one arable crop to another one was not considered as LUC.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Also, at 
the national level, the analysis by land use category is easier.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
On the one hand, one can notice that the national average approach cannot identify shifting 
cultivation, whereby LUC may occur while the total crop area may stay stable but moved around 
various land areas (it is not an issue in the case of long-term perennials such as coffee plantations 
which cannot be easily moved around over short time periods).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
On the other hand, the national 
average approach encompasses both direct and indirect LUC within a given country at the land use 
category level.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For instance, if coffee land area increases, as well as the perennial total land area, 
meanwhile forest land area decreases.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Part of the deforestation will be allocated to LUC to coffee, 
even though the directly observed LUC may have been “forest to maize” somewhere and “maize to 
coffee” somewhere else within the same country, which would be defined as indirect LUC.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: 26 IPCC notes that it would be longer in temperate and boreal systems, although it is the default.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
72 
 
 
Figure 22.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Decision tree to identify LUC based on national average when historical record for a given coffee 
plantation is missing.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Source: adapted from Mila i Canals et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2012 
 
Step 2.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Calculating the LUC total impact 
We recommend applying the IPCC Tier 1, stock difference method (2006), which is the most 
commonly applied and aligned with the 20-year timeframe27 (Eq.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The principle lies in comparing 
two “stabilised” carbon stocks in two land uses.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The 20-year timeframe is considered as the minimum 
duration to reach “stabilisation” in agreement with the previously developed argument.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It is important to stress i) IPCC guidelines are related to GHG only, therefore the assessment of LUC 
impacts based on IPCC is only partial as it does not look at biodiversity losses nor models irreversible 
impacts; ii) the 20-year timeframe may be relatively correct for the bulk of above-ground biomass 
globally but it is relatively incorrect for carbon stocks that take longer to build up, notably soil organic 
carbon; finally iii) the IPCC guidelines mentioned that longer time period than the 20-year default may 
be used in other Tier approaches, if justified.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, the default value ensures consistency across 
studies and a longer time period would increase the risk of untraced or unamortised LUC.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Equation 14 
 
 
 
                                                             
27 “20 years is the time period assumed for carbon stocks to come to equilibrium for the purposes of calculating default 
coefficients in the 1996 IPCC Guidelines and retained for GPG-LULUCF and used here also, though other periods may be used 
at higher Tiers according to national circumstances” In IPCC 2006, Vol 4, Chapter 2, p13/59 

Cirad report 
73 
 
IPCC guidelines provide carbon stock values by default but which are hardly coffee and site-specific.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
All carbon pools should be accounted for, including above and below ground biomass, dead wood and 
litter, and soil organic carbon (SOC).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Dead wood and litter are usually considered as null given their 
fast turnover (except for forest with >30% canopy closure).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Considering all these carbon pools does 
not mean that the full sum of those stocks will eventually face the same fate as it depends on the land 
clearing process (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: burning or not).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: The fate of the stocks and emissions are discussed below.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The IPCC default carbon stock values could be used for other land uses, but for coffee plantations 
we recommend relying on the biomass review presented in this report (c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: section 3.3.2).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
IPCC default 
carbon stock values were estimated at maturity or after 20 years, whichever the earlier.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For coffee 
plantations, we recommend to use carbon stocks that are time-averaged over the plantation cycle.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: First, time-averaged carbon stocks are aligned with the perennial crop cycle modelling (c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: section 3.2).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Second, time-averaged carbon stocks account for the succession of cycles, which enables a more 
consistent comparison with very old stands such as natural forests. As described in section 3.2 for the 
perennial crop modelling, time-averaged carbon stocks account for the different development phases, 
which lead to various biomass and carbon accumulations, and those accumulations are weighted by 
the varying phase durations along the crop cycle.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Time-averaged carbon stocks were proposed by 
ICRAF in the late 90s with an example on coffee plantation (c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Annex 1).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
When comparing carbon stocks in tropical forests with those in different types of coffee plantations 
(Figure 23), one can grasp the potential importance of LUC emissions and the importance of the 
compared time dimensions.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
From a global perspective, land areas all have an original stock, therefore 
cumulated carbon stocks in human made landscapes may not come at no cost.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Where a few original 
trees may be kept in an agroforestry plantation (grey trees in complex agroforest on fig indicated with 
an arrow), the initial stock right after LUC may not be zero and the overall time-averaged stock may 
stay above that of less complex systems such as monoculture unshaded.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the stock difference, those 
kept trees will reduce the difference as their stocks were not lost nor gained.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
When shade trees are 
planted together with the coffee trees, their stocks will also matter both in quantities and in the 
duration of their stocks. The total carbon stock will depend on both the planting densities of coffee trees and associated 
trees, and the duration of the different growth phases.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Carbon stocks in annual crops are not 
accounted for due to their too short lifetime.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Most parts of annual crops are rapidly exported and used, 
the rest usually decomposing within a year or two.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Hence, if a coffee plantation is established after an 
annual crop land, the LUC consists in an increased net carbon storage.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In full sun coffee plantations 
with or without associated crops, the overall carbon stock will not be directly modified by the carbon 
stock in associated annual crops that is too short-lived. However, the net carbon stock may be 
influenced by the coffee planting density with relation to that of the associated crops and eventual 
competitions for resources and growth.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
74 
 
 
Figure 23.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Framework for LUC accounting where time-averaged stocks are compared between tropical forest and 
various types of more or less complex coffee plantations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Once the stocks are calculated for a given LUC scenario, to compute the stock difference, emissions 
“from” LU1, the cleared land use stock, need to be determined and subtracted from the potential 
storage “to” LU2.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
If information is available on the land clearing process, primary data should be 
prioritised.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In other cases, the IPCC-based default table provided by ecoinvent V3.0 et reused by 
WFLDB V3.0 is recommended (Table 8).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Although the characterisation of LUC was first focused on carbon stock changes, emissions related 
to the release of some carbon pools are not limited to C-based GHG only.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In particular, N-based GHG 
may be also released with relation to C/N components in the biomass and SOC.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The release process 
will also influence the emission profiles, as the gas profiles vary when burning compared to decaying, 
or when decay occurs in aerobic or anaerobic conditions.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Emission factors depending on the release 
process and C/N default values depending on the biomass sources are provided by IPCC (2006).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
On the 
contrary, for the increase in stock to LU2, only CO2 sequestration is considered as the capture of other 
biomass compounds such as N does not come from atmospheric GHG but other gases without radiative 
forcing (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Given the long timeframe (at least 20 years), emission and sequestration of 
biogenic CO2 are not considered as neutral.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As a side note, in annual crops as mentioned before and in Table 8 dead organic matter is 
considered null within the frame of LUC, i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
the biogenic CO2 from crop residues decaying is considered 
as neutral. It is consistent with the other pools containing biogenic CO2 not considered as neutral given 
their longer residence time in the biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, it is important to bear in mind that other GHG 
from crop residues decaying are to be accounted for in the carbon footprint as part of the annual LCI 
and not within the LUC accounting framework.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
75 
 
Table 8.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: LUC from crop production follows the methodology applied in ecoinvent V3.0 (Wernet et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2016), which 
is based on IPCC (2006) methodology 
 
Step 3.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Amortising the LUC impact 
The time frame is key to identify LUC and amortise it, both are intrinsically connected.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
So, IPCC 2006 
guidelines recommend a linear amortisation over 20 years. The implementation of this 20-year 
amortisation has different meaning, though, depending on the starting point.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
When looking straight 
backwards for a LUC 20 years ago28, the 1/20 of LUC impact (emission or sequestration) is somehow 
meant to be the final share (19th) of the specific LUC 20 years ago and then this assumption is checked 
year after year of assessments.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
However, some amortisation years may be missed depending on the 
starting point of the assessment Figure 1 and a cross-check with plantation age and/or first 
establishment year is necessary.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Using the actual 20-year historical record (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
based on primary data 
or remote sensing classifications) can help to model LUC amortisation more consistently.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
On the other 
hand, when accounting for known LUC that has occurred recently, the 20-year amortisation supposes 
that the 1/20 of LUC impact should be allocated to the many years of future continuous land use until 
amortisation is completed.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Consistently, on the 21st year of a continuous land use, when looking 20 
years back there is no more LUC to consider.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Figure 24.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
LUC amortisation depending on the assessment starting date 
                                                             
28 See Figure 24 as recommended by various guidelines when direct data on LUC is not available.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Such an approach may be 
only robust at a national level, whereby all land use resources are considered across many sec 

Cirad report 
76 
 
In all cases, modelling the full perennial cycle provides some guardrails.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
First, it requires being 
aware of the cycle starting point and duration.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Second, it implies an amortisation over the whole cycle, 
whereby doubt about future completion of LUC amortisation may not arise.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For plantation duration 
around 20-year (±2-3) lifespan, the perennial modelling does not create distortion compared to the 
baseline 20-year IPCC default.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For plantations with shorter turn-over around 10-year (±2-3), we 
recommend amortising the LUC impact over two cycles, which is the minimum duration to consider 
LUC and which is consistent with time-averaged stocks over the cycle.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For plantations older than 20 
years (±2-3), no more LUC should be accounted for anyway.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In order to check how amortisation choice 
affects the final result, we recommend testing the 20-year amortisation period (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
adding 1/20 LUC 
impact to the result calculated over the whole cycle) in a sensitivity analysis and displaying both results.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Amortisation of LULUC impact should be consistent with allocation rules at the plantation level.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In 
particular, in the case of associated tree-crops together with coffee, which may also store some 
biogenic carbon for at least 20 years, either the whole storage potential of a given area is allocated to 
coffee or it is split between tree-crops depending on the allocation rules defined for the study.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For 
instance, if fertiliser environmental burdens are allocated to various tree-crops within the coffee 
plantation according to their respective needs (c.f.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Section 2.2), the potential LULUC impact should be 
also allocated to the various tree-crops based on the same rules.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In such allocation cases, both results 
with and without allocation should be displayed.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Step 4.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Land use remaining in the same land use category 
Once LUC impact has been amortised and there is not anymore land use category change, i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
land 
use remaining in the same land use category, IPCC 2006 guidelines provide the same recommendations 
in terms of carbon stock variations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As long as changes occur over a sufficient period of time to reach 
a new steady state (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
always 20 years by default), carbon stock variation can be computed following 
the stock difference equation Eq.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
applying steps 2 and 3 for long-term changes from one coffee 
plantation type to another one.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For instance, if an old complex coffee agroforest (>20 years old) is 
replaced by a coffee full sun monoculture, carbon stock changes will lead to net GHG emissions.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It 
would go the other way, i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
net sequestration, when changing from full sun monoculture to simple 
agroforest.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Again, accounting for the full perennial cycle is needed to try and ensure, as far as possible, 
that the time frame is consistent with long-term management changes that do consistently affect the 
carbon stocks.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As detailed in section 3.3.1, more knowledge and data are still needed to properly model 
all stock changes, especially regarding SOC stocks.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
By default, IPCC (2006) proposed various tillage and 
input weighting management factors that can be used to model long-term changes in SOC around the 
soil type and climate defined standard SOCST and within a given land use category (i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
perennial crops 
in the case of coffee).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
3.3.2 Biomass estimation for coffee plantations 
In the case of LULUC, biomass stocks need to be estimated based on the plantation specificities. The estimation of a coffee plantation biomass relies on a set of parameters to model the main aspects 
of the farming system design and management (mainly planting densities and duration of rotations), 
and allometric equations and default factors to model the different perennial components of the 
farming systems (the different species and their biogenic carbon).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For simple and complex agroforestry systems, associated trees represent the largest pool of 
perennial woody biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Efforts should be made to quantify this pool in the most detailed possible 

Cirad report 
77 
 
manner, as it will have the most influence on the overall biomass and carbon estimation.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Numerous 
allometric models exist to quantify the above-ground biomass of associated trees from simple 
measurements in the coffee plantation.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Note that we discourage the use of allometric models with 
tree age as the main input variable, due to high levels of uncertainties.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The types of allometric models 
are listed below, from the most to the least specific:  
● (Developing) species-specific and site-specific models for associated trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
These models can 
have either tree shape parameters (height, DBH, basal area) or tree age as input variables to 
characterise growth, considering that growth is sufficiently homogeneous in the study area.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: ● (Using existing) species-specific models for associated trees.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
These models can only use tree 
shape parameters (height, DBH, basal area) as input variables to characterise growth.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: ● (Using existing) default models for groups of associated tree species.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Before using any model, one must first ensure that the model yields outputs within the proper 
orders of magnitude, both at the individual tree level and at the stand level (after multiplication with 
tree density).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: It is not uncommon to find models returning unrealistic values; those must be discarded.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Considering the difficulty of estimating the below-ground biomass of associated trees, the majority 
of studies use multiplicative coefficients, known as root-to-shoot ratios, to derive the below-ground 
biomass from the above-ground biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
These coefficients were developed for forestry, not for 
agricultural systems, and are therefore only used in agricultural systems due to the absence of more 
specific data.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For tropical and subtropical forests, the root to shoot ratio ranges in the IPCC guidelines 
between 0.24 and 0.42, while according to Cairns et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
(1997), the root to shoot ratio would range 
between 0.23 and 0.34.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Except if there are species-specific and/or site-specific data available on below-
ground biomass, we recommend following the same approach.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Finally, the biomass estimated at tree level must be multiplied by tree densities to get the above-
ground biomass at the stand level.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
It is important to check, at this stage, that the values of biomass 
obtained for the coffee plantations are lower than those of forested areas found nearby.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Furthermore, 
one should not forget that this method based on allometric equations returns biomass estimation for 
trees of a certain size or age, but that the global footprint of the coffee plantation must consider the 
whole duration of the plantation, and the time-averaged biomass estimation across this duration 
(Figure 23).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The above method focuses on the perennial woody biomass and forgoes the non-perennial and 
non-woody components of the system, such as leaf, leaf litter, herbaceous cover, and dead wood.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
These pools are time consuming to measure and often only have small contributions to the overall 
biomass balance of the system.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Furthermore, they are assumed to decompose rapidly while emitting 
biogenic carbon dioxide, and should therefore not be accounted for in LCA and carbon footprints.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Cirad report 
78 
 
Recommended default allometric models for biomass of associated trees, in the absence of 
species-specific models

○

○

○ 
DBH = 25 cm => AGB_fruit ~ 380 kg DM/tree | AGB_other ~ 140-300 kg DM/tree 
○ 
DBH = 30 cm => AGB_all ~ 200-470 kg DM/tree

○ 
Simple agroforestry: AGB ~ 30-100 t DM/ha  
○ 
Complex agroforestry: AGB ~ 50-300 t DM/ha

Above-ground biomass of agroforest ≤ Above-ground biomass of local forests

○ 
~ 30% of above-ground biomass 
 
The biomass in coffee trees constitutes the second pool of perennial biomass in coffee agroforestry 
systems, and the first one in full sun systems.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Similarly, to shade trees, the estimation of above-ground 
biomass is done with the use of allometric equations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Numerous allometric models were developed 
for Arabica coffee, allowing the use of models adapted to various ranges of application (dwarf or non-
dwarf cultivar; short or long rotations).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
On the other hand, few models were developed for Robusta 
coffee.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Below-ground biomass of coffee trees is seldom studied and one of the important knowledge gaps.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Overall, based on the few studies available, the use of a coffee-specific root-to-shoot ratio can provide 
a rough estimate of the biomass of coarse roots.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This low level of accuracy might still be enough to 
estimate the overall biomass at the plot level, especially in agroforestry systems, where coffee trees 
only represent a small fraction of the biomass.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Here again, one should not forget that methods based on allometric equations returns biomass 
estimation for coffee trees of a certain size (and therefore age), but that the global footprint of the 

Cirad report 
79 
 
coffee plantation must consider the whole duration of the plantation, and the time-averaged biomass 
estimation across this duration.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Recommended allometric models for biomass of coffee 
Above-ground biomass of Arabica coffee 
o Dwarf cultivars managed through regular pruning and stumping, with stem diameter below 
8 cm: Andrade (2018).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
o AGB (kg DM/tree) = 0.36 - 0.18*D(cm) + 0.08*D^2                    Equation 10 
○ 
D is measured at 40 cm from the ground or above the stump 
o Non-dwarf cultivars planted at low densities (< 2,500 tree/ha): Guillemot (2018)

○ 
D is measured at 30 cm from the ground 
○ 
The projected crown area (PCA) in m2 is deducted from planting density (PCA ~ 4 m2 
for a planting density of 2,500 trees/ha) 
o Very large and old arabica trees, i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: taller than 5 m and with stems larger than 8 cm.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
These 
are often found in old forests and homegardens: Negash (2016) 
o AGB (kg DM/tree) = 0.147*D^2                                                     Equation 12 
Above-ground biomass of Robusta coffee 
o Single peer-reviewed reference: Guillemot (2018) 
○ 
AGB (kg DM/tree) = 0.0177*π*D*PCA^0.818                             Equation 20 
○ 
With D the stem diameter (cm) at 30 cm from the ground  
○ 
With PCA = projected crown area (m2) that can be derived from the planting density. Below-ground biomass 
o Root-to-shoot ratio for coarse roots of either Arabica or Robusta 
○ 
R = 0.40 
Orders of magnitude 
o Above-ground biomass of Arabica coffee 
○ 
0 kg DM/tree ≤ AGB ≤ 5 kg DM/tree (for most common arabica coffee varieties, but 
can go higher for wild coffee trees) 
○ 
1 t DM/ha ≤ AGB ≤ 20 t DM/ha (with most common estimates between 5 and 10 t 
DM/ha) 
o Above-ground biomass of Robusta coffee 
○ 
5 kg DM/tree ≤ AGB ≤ 25 kg DM/tree for a mature tree 
○ 
5 t DM/ha ≤ AGB ≤ 20 t DM/ha for a mature plantation 
o Below-ground biomass of Arabica & Robusta 
○ 
≤10 t DM/ha for coarse roots (≥ 2 mm) 
○ 
~10-20 t DM/ha for all roots (including ≤ 2 mm) in a mature plantation

80 
 
A clear gap of knowledge was found regarding the assessment of the belowground biomass in 
coffee plantations while this pool could account for between 20 and 100 % of the above-ground 
biomass.

Therefore, there is a need to carry out additional studies with robust methodology (see

Similarly, based on our review, we found that SOC stocks in coffee plantations can account for a 
considerable amount of carbon that would need to be better assessed.

SOC stocks are impacted by 
land-use, land management but also environmental parameters (e.g.

Therefore, a 
comprehensive review of the literature related to coffee plantations would be an asset to improve the 
accounting.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Additionally, in section 2.3, we reviewed the existing literature on biochar for coffee plantations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The following recommendations can be proposed: 
● A long-term assessment of the impact of the application of biochar on GHG emissions would 
be necessary as the vast majority of field studies primarily measured emission reduction in the 
first year after application only.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
● Development of field experiments with biochar application as most of the studies were carried 
out in laboratory conditions (incubation).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
These experiments would be crucial to assess the 
agronomic impacts of biochar application in coffee plantations in soil and climate specific 
contexts 
● A huge need to characterise the biochar from residues from pruning of coffee. Indeed, residues 
from pruning of coffee bushes could be a valuable source of biomass to produce biochar, yet 
no specific study assessing the agronomic impacts of such biochar was found. ● Assessment of the LCA impacts of biochar production and application for coffee production as 
no comprehensive studies encompassing the biochar production and its application in coffee 
plantations was found.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Besides, as indirect benefits in the field depend on the soil and climate 
contexts and require a systemic adaptation of practices, such assessment should be context-
dependent.

IPCC 2019 - V5 Ch3 – Methane emissions:  
Methane emission estimate is based on the amount of decomposable degradable organic carbon (the 
part of the organic carbon that will degrade under the anaerobic conditions) = product of the fraction 
of degradable organic carbon (DOC in kg C/kg), the fraction of the DOC that decomposes under 
anaerobic conditions (DOCf), and the part of the waste that will decompose under aerobic conditions 
(prior to the conditions becoming anaerobic, which is interpreted with the Methane Correction Factor 
MCF).

3.5.2 Characterisation of biochar from and in coffee plantations 
There are two dimensions in further investigating and documenting the role of biochar in coffee 
plantations: 
1.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Quantifying and characterising the type of biochar that could be produced from coffee 
plantation residues; 
2. Assessing the potential impacts of biochar application in coffee plantations. Quantifying and characterising the type of biochar 
Important biochar characteristics, fur the purpose of its use in agriculture, are pH, electric 
conductivity and cation exchange capacity. Those variables influence how biochar can be effective in 
enhancing water retention, retaining nutrients to improve microbial activity, and nitrogen 
fixing(Mujtaba et al., 2021).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
A review of chemical properties of coffee residues should be the starting 
point in identifying biomass sources available for conversion into biochar and their chemical 
characteristics (Protásio et al., 2013; Vandeponseele et al., 2020). For the biochar production itself, pilot-scale tests should be implemented on the various potential 
coffee feedstocks and testing various pyrolysis temperatures and residence times, then quantifying 
biochar and further outputs.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Various technologies can be then applied to further characterise the 
biochar properties (Jindo et al., 2014; Yaashikaa et al., 2020; Mujtaba et al., 2021).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
As mentioned earlier in this report, coffee husk may not be suitable due to too low volume, 
compared to pruning residues notably, but husk might be used to fuel the biochar production system.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
There should be a holistic appraisal of the technological optimisation for coffee biochar production 
accounting for i) minimum viable throughputs ; ii) circular recycling of all potential waste flows within 
the process and at the coffee value chain level to reduce energy cost; iii) minimising all transport 
distances and costs.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Quantifying and characterising the impacts of biochar in the coffee plantations 
Once biochar feedstock and production process are identified, field experiments are needed to 
demonstrate the added value of such an input.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
A first trial should be established with the aim to 
investigate only one variable regarding biochar (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: the type of biochar or the amount applied).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The 
recommended field trial protocol is a Complete Randomised Block Design, within homogeneous pedo-
climatic conditions, with at least 3 replicates per treatment, including control (=no biochar input) as 
one of the treatments.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Blocks should be defined on order to minimise the variability within a block 
(e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
in terms of planting design, fertilisation) and to maximise the differences across blocks due to 
undesired factors (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: microclimate, hazards).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Ideally, this first trial setup should be established in 
various contrasted pedo-climatic conditions and coffee plantations.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The duration of this first trial 
should be at least 10 years, with first preliminary results analysed after 5 years.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Further trials may be 
established once first results are analysed, in order to test further variables, notably the combination 
with various types and doses of fertilisers, both mineral and organic.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In the trials, the minimum set of measured variables on an annual basis would be : 
• 
Coffee yields ; 
• 
pH, bulk density (with cylinders), and SOC (dry combustion) over the first 0-20 cm ; 
• 
Biofunctool® indicator sets of soil quality (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
POXC, aggregate stability) over the first 0-20 
cm (Thoumazeau et al., 2019b; a).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Further measurements should be : 
• 
GHG emissions (CO2, N2O, possibly CH4) with static chambers (at leat 2 measurements per 
day continuously over 2-3 years) ; 

Cirad report 
89 
 
• 
SOC (dry combustion) over the first 0-100 cm every 5 years.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
3.6 Recommendation on the handling of co-products 
Table 11 and Table 12 detail possible management pathways for coproducts from green coffee 
processing.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
These flows could be handled as a “waste” to be dealt with or as marketable raw materials 
for other value chains, such as livestock, bioenergy or biorefinery.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In principle, and inspired by Circular 
Economy principles, the concept of cascading should be privileged: to obtain as many and diverse 
benefits as possible from a “waste” stream (Campbell-Johnston et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: 2020; Jarre et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This 
implies, for the green coffee value chain, to prefer, when possible, co-product handling pathways that 
enable the recovery of chemicals, nutrients, materials and finally energy.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For the sake of simplicity, we included in “co-products”, all other outputs from the green coffee 
supply chain, i.e.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: from associated crops to residues or process waste.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Ultimately, emissions related to 
a co-product do not only depend on the nature of a co-product (or type) but on its fate and whether it 
needs a treatment and can be recycled or not.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
The management of co-products, hence how to handle 
their GHG emissions, can vary according to local conditions.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Concerning carbon footprint procedures, 
three cases of management can be considered to appraise various co-products within a given coffee 
supply chain: 
• 
Waste: Co-products are not used and are dealt with as a waste.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In this case, all emissions 
related to transportation, waste management and disposal must be included.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
Closed-loop valorisation: Co-products are used for another activity inside the system 
boundaries (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
application of organic waste such as husk as fertiliser on coffee 
plantations).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In this case, GHG emissions from all steps required from production to 
valorisation must be included (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
transportation, composting, field emissions from 
application, etc.).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
• 
Open-loop valorisation: Co-products are used for an activity outside the coffee system 
boundaries (e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: associated crop outputs or chemical extraction from coffee residues).

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
In 
this case, an allocation or system expansion issue arises.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Allocation or system expansion 
procedures were described in section 2.2 according to the ISO and PCR guidelines.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
One should notice that co-product handling has been a matter of controversy in the LCA community 
since the very beginning due to the combined issue of varying interpretation of concepts and guidelines 
(e.g.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Heijungs et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: 2021; Dominguez Aldama et al.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
2023), and the tremendous influence of the 
contrasted choices.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Co-product handling implies subjective choices and uncertainties that cannot be 
simply objectified.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
We hence do not make any further recommendation on those choices but insist on 
the need for mass balance consistency and co-product handling transparency, as both are guardrails 
for interpretation and reproducibility of any carbon footprint study.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Where co-products may lead to 
open-loop valorisation, one should carry out some sensitivity analysis on how various choices 
(allocation ratios and/or system expansion) would affect the final results.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Hence, the key element in any carbon footprint is the construction of a mass balance table that 
enables the identification of all potential co-products and their management as waste, close- or open-
loop co-products.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
This table should list all carbon partitioning within the system, considering all co-
products and their relative humidity.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Once the mass balance is established, and all co-products and 
other mass and energy flows accounted for, a baseline scenario representing the current stable state 
of the system should be constructed, to be later compared against alternative scenarios on which 

Cirad report 
90 
 
management changes are introduced.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text: Table 11 and Table 12 are not exhaustive, as multiple alternative pathways exist.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
For instance, we 
retained the most likely storage and composting technologies.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:
Moreover, both tables present a 
selection of key emission factors.

metadata.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

text:

IPCC emission factor database (https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/EFDB/) as well as Table 9 and Table 
10.
