the tea plant, the cocoa bean, and the coﬀee bean.” – William Ukers, 1921
The appropriately titled book All about Coﬀee (Ukers, 1922) proposed that the lure and
universal appeal of coﬀee can be explained by a so-called twofold eﬀect.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
First, the
enjoyable, aromatic sensations of drinking coﬀee and second, the increased eﬃciency
which provides its recipient via caﬀeine stimulation.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
It is no wonder that coﬀee is virtually
ubiquitous in kitchens, cafes and in the hands of pedestrians on just about every street
corner.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Ethiopia may be the widely accepted origin of the oldest known species of coﬀee,
Coﬀea arabica, but Yemen is thought to be the birthplace of consuming coﬀee in the
beverage form we know today (Friis, 2015).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Early observations from Ethiopia described
the invigorating eﬀects of chewing roasted coﬀee beans as “better than a loaf of bread or
a meal of meat” (Friis, 2015).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
In Yemen, coﬀee as a hot drink went by at least three Arabic
names: “bunna”, “gahve” and “geschr” and was said to be drunk by people at any time of
day (Friis, 2015).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Nowadays, most coﬀee drinkers could not imagine going a day without
their cup of “liquid gold”.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
This means that coﬀee is a big business; annual global earnings
exceed US$200 billion.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Consequently, any pest and disease which impact coﬀee yield are
of keen interest to the farmer and the scientiﬁc community at large.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Severe leaf defoliation caused by coﬀee leaf rust can lead to plant death.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Courtesy of Dr
Melanie Bordeaux, director of NICAFRANCE Foundation’s research centre, Nicaragua.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Coﬀee leaf rust (CLR) is one of the most signiﬁcant diseases to strike coﬀee production.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Due to its widespread prevalence across all global coﬀee-growing regions and the
calamity it brings in terms of yield reduction, CLR is by far the most studied coﬀee
disease.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
CLR damages coﬀee plants by causing heavy leaf defoliation, leading to dramatic
yield losses (up to 75%) and in some cases plant death (Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Countries plagued by CLR
suﬀer ﬁnancial losses at the national level, which have trickle-down eﬀects on poor
farmers and, in extreme circumstances, has led to the mass abandonment of coﬀee
farms.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
In fact, estimates suggest that the most recent epidemic of CLR cost up to US$1
billion in losses and cut 250,000 jobs, mainly on farms.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
CLR was ﬁrst oﬃcially discovered on uncultivated, wild coﬀee oﬀ the shores of Lake
Victoria (Kenya) in 1861 by a British explorer (Koutouleas et al., 2019).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Yet it was not until
1869 that the disease reached the public eye after it reaped havoc across several colonial
Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Tea, coﬀee and chocolate were once considered as luxury imports by the British.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Courtesy
of British Museum (1750–1760).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Obtained from the British Museum, Public domain, via
Wikimedia Commons.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

card_(BM_Heal,68.45).jpg

1869 that the disease reached the public eye after it reaped havoc across several colonial
coﬀee plantations in Sri Lanka (then called Ceylon).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The British colonialists were so taken
aback by CLR in their ﬁelds that they resorted to tearing out the coﬀee plants and
replacing them with tea bushes instead.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Through this case study, the longstanding history of CLR will be considered and linked to
key colonial trade activities (Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The relevance of the disease will be highlighted brieﬂy
in terms of modern coﬀee farming practices using testimonies and data from Central
American and East African coﬀee farms.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Future prospects of coﬀee farming in new ways
to combat disease pressure by H. vastatrix will also be explored.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Causal Agent: Hemileia vastatrix
Hemileia vastatrix
Hemileia vastatrix Berk.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
& Broome is an obligate parasitic fungus in family Pucciniaceae
(Koutouleas et al., 2019).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
This means that the fungus cannot survive in the absence of its
plant host.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Optimal environmental conditions for the development of H. vastatrix are 21–
25°C air temperature with 100% relative humidity.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
CLR infection peaks, therefore, tend to
occur immediately after the peak of the rainy season across tropical and sub-tropical
regions.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Under optimal environmental conditions, a fungal germ tube of H. vastatrix
penetrates via stomatal openings on the underside of the coﬀee leaf.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Upon entry, H.
vastatrix grows nutrient-absorbing mycelium within the leaf mesophyll cells using
haustoria to invaginate the mesophyll cells to obtain nutrients.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Vibrant bouquet-shaped,
orange uredinia and telia sporulate from the stomata (Figs 3 and 4).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Uredinium of H. vastatrix budding orange rust-coloured urediniopores (bar = 20 μm).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Courtesy of Carvalho et al.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: (2011), CC BY 2.5 via Wikimedia Commons.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hemileia_vastatrix_Uredinium_02.png

Uredinia give rise to urediniospores, dikaryotic cells (containing two unfused nuclei),
which can survive up to six weeks on detached coﬀee leaf tissue.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Under cool, dry
conditions, the telia give rise to two more spore types: teliospores and subsequently
basidiospores. Teliospores are two-celled, thick-walled and produce basidia; which then
develop four haploid basidiospores – the sexual spores of H. vastatrix.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
By producing both asexual and sexual spore types, rust fungi such as H. vastatrix increase
their chances of transmission via multiple hosts and across the seasons.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
For this reason,
many rusts are observed to have complex disease cycles with diﬀerent spore types or
reproductive structures (Koutouleas et al., 2019).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The covert and complex nature of the fungal attack lies in the fact that urediniospores
adhere to and enter via the underside of the leaf (where stomata are most numerous).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
This means that the early onset of the disease can go largely undetected to the naked
Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Inspecting the underside of coﬀee leaves for early signs of infection on an experimental
coﬀee farm in Costa Rica (Alajuela).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Photo courtesy of the author.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: eye.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
When traversing a coﬀee ﬁeld infected by CLR, yellow pin spots on the upper leaf
surface can be seen as a sign of disease.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
However, by the time this visual indicator
catches the attention of a coﬀee worker, the fungus has already established its nutrient
supply from the leaf tissues via penetration of the epidermal cells through the stomata.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Discovery of “Devastating Emily” (Ceylon, 1869)
During the 15th century, coﬀee plants were transported from their centre of origin in
Africa, across the Red Sea to southern Arabia (Yemen) and meticulously cultivated along
sloped terraces.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Until the end of the 17th century, the world’s limited supply of coﬀee
was almost exclusively distributed by Yemeni merchants and traders (Friis, 2015).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Ethnobotanists mark this time as the great Yemen coﬀee monopoly era, given that there
was a careful watch on the export of any green coﬀee beans by Arabians (Ukers, 1922).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
In
fact, any precious coﬀee beans leaving Yemen at the time were ordered to be steeped in
boiling water or parched, in order to destroy any possibility of foreign germination of the
cash crop.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Yemen’s coﬀee supply monopoly came to its end by the early 17th century, at
which point the Dutch drove the Portuguese out of Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) and began
coﬀee cultivation.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The British then entered the coﬀee scene through their occupation of
this tropical island in 1796.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: However, they only began formally cultivating coﬀee in 1825.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: In the 50 years thereafter, coﬀee was one of the island’s leading export products.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
H.
vastatrix ﬁrst appeared in coﬀee ﬁelds in 1869.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
At ﬁrst, the disease was dubbed by coﬀee
planters and ﬁeld workers as “Devastating Emily” due to the destruction it brought to the
coﬀee ﬁelds.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Little did they know that this plant disease would single-handedly ruin the
coﬀee industry in Ceylon.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
For more than three centuries coﬀee was cultivated by both the Arabian and Dutch
colonialists without any reports of CLR.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The onset of extensive cultivation methods
(introduced by the British) provided the perfect substrate for the fungal pathogen H.
vastatrix to manifest a serious epidemic, destroying coﬀee productivity and proﬁtability.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Enter the British tea industry.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
At the time of the ﬁrst major CLR outbreak exporters and researchers under

At the time of the ﬁrst major CLR outbreak, exporters and researchers, under
secondment by the British government to Ceylon, were trying to ﬁgure out what was
causing the coﬀee yield losses and plant death.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Coﬀee planters and ﬁeld staﬀ surmised
the onset of “Devastating Emily” was due to poor plant growth and humid environments.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Cultural practices with the aim of bolstering plant vigour and growth were used as a
result of these evaluations.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
When these eﬀorts failed, a simple experiment by a tea
planter James Taylor to helped re-write the history books of early coﬀee production.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Taylor demonstrated that tea plants were completely “resistant” to the foliar disease and
henceforth, the majority of coﬀee plants were ripped out of the ground and replaced
with tea plants.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
These days, it is widely known that H. vastatrix only infects coﬀee (as its
primary plant host) and no alternate plant host has been discovered – yet.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Given this,
Taylor’s ﬁndings were somewhat simplistic, as just about any plant (other than coﬀee)
would have been deemed “resistant” to CLR at that time.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
It is often said that this piece of
history explains why the British drinks more tea than coﬀee, even today.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Although this is
considered to be more of a fable than a fact, since any drop in coﬀee supply could have
easily been recouped from other British colonial territories growing coﬀee during the
same period (i.e.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Jamaica, Tanzania, northeastern Australia, etc.).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Scholars are still uncertain why “Devastating Emily” became so severe in Ceylon during
the ﬁrst major outbreak.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
One explanation could be that other outbreaks may have
occurred but either went undetected or unreported by local plantation managers at the
time.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
In fact, British colonial activities represent some of the most detailed records that
we have today concerning trade and agriculture in the period of the ﬁrst outbreak.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Another explanation could be a change in wind patterns which helped to spread fungal
spores across long distances.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
However, this explanation does not explain why CLR
outbreaks were not detected across other Asian coﬀee-producing countries at the time.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Intensive monoculture farming of the coﬀee crop in the Ceylon region no doubt led to a
concentration in coﬀee plant substrate for H. vastatrix, further increasing the likelihood of
such a signiﬁcant outbreak (compared to coﬀee gardens and small-scale production
employed in other regions).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The increase in transportation routes of people and goods
during the late 19th century is another likely entry mechanism for the primary inoculum

of rust spores into coﬀee plantations.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Worldwide Spread of the “Big Rust”
After the debut of CLR in Ceylon, the fungus made its way across Asian and Oceania
coﬀee-producing countries such as Australia, Fiji, India, Indonesia, Mauritius, Pakistan,
Papua New Guinea, the Philippines and Vietnam.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The coﬀee disease was then reported to
have made a return to the mother continent of Africa with widespread outbreaks ﬁrst in
the East (e.g.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Uganda, Kenya and Mozambique) and then in the West (e.g.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Ivory Coast).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Latin American coﬀee production was free from CLR until the 1970s when the ﬁrst report
was made in Brazil.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The disease was coined the “big rust” after the signiﬁcant outbreak
period starting in 2008 in Colombia (McCook and Vandermeer, 2015).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The epidemic
spread north to Central America and Mexico by 2012–2013 and since 2014 has begun
impacting coﬀee farms in Ecuador and Peru.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
In 2020, H. vastatrix reached Hawaii, the only
country growing coﬀee that avoided CLR for more than a century.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Today, CLR plagues all
coﬀee-producing countries, albeit to varying degrees depending on climatic conditions,
on-farm resources, de-forestation activities (in which trees acted as buﬀer zones between
farms) and general coﬀee plant health.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
A group of smallholder coﬀee farmers in
Nicaragua has recently declared that CLR continues to cause heavy disease pressure in
the major coﬀee-growing region of Matagalpa.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Irregular rainfall patterns coupled with
unusually high average air temperatures could be leading to more sporadic and localized
outbreaks, which are being largely controlled through chemical fungicide application
(when accessible to the farmer).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Recent studies from Ethiopia, the motherland of coﬀee,
have shown that the fungal disease is increasing in severity over time across major
coﬀee-growing areas of the Southern districts.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
A surge in CLR has been reported across
Ethiopia, with an average incidence rate of 35.3%.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Moreover, the disease has shown to be
spread upward from lowland to mid and highland coﬀee-growing areas.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
In the
neighbouring coﬀee growing country, Uganda, recent reports suggest that CLR has
reduced average annual yield per hectare from 855 to 432 kg, representing a 49.5%
decrease in productivity and income, as well as a gradual loss of C. arabica plants (due to

high susceptibility to the disease).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
These are just a few developing countries that rely on
coﬀee as a key export commodity and are therefore at the mercy of this devastating
pathogen.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Current Best Management Practices for Hemileia
Hemileia
vastatrix
vastatrix
Carbohydrate production by photosynthesis in leaves ensures the maintenance, growth
and reproduction of the coﬀee plant.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
When H. vastatrix sporulates heavily, coﬀee leaves
are damaged by both the intracellular growth and the nutrient leaching of the fungus.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
In
order to protect coﬀee leaves from CLR, some form of disease control should be
considered.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
This is especially relevant during the fruit development phase which
demands the presence of healthy plant foliage for carbohydrate supply (De Filho and
Domian, 2019).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Both chemical and cultural practices are recommended for the control
and containment of CLR (De Filho and Domian, 2019).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
These include:
• Protective and systemic fungicides
• Coﬀee plant and shade tree pruning
• Use of resistant cultivars
• Renovation of old coﬀee farms with new plants
• Biological control agents
The use of multiple lines of defence against plant pests or pathogens is called an
Integrated Pest-Disease Management system (IPDM) and coﬀee farmers beneﬁt from
employing such an approach when faced with CLR.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Today, the primary mode of control
recommended is a mixture of fungicides (triazoles and strobilurin) to control and prevent
the disease (Table 1).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Resistant and/more tolerant coﬀee varieties and hybrids have been
identiﬁed and selectively bred, based on nine known resistance genes (called SH genes).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Resistance genes SH1, SH2, SH4 and SH5 were discovered in the C. arabica species; SH6,
SH7 SH8

SH7, SH8 and SH9 come from the C. canephora species and the SH3 gene originates from
the less cultivated C. liberica species (De Filho and Domian, 2019).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Combined use of
resistant coﬀee varieties or hybrids, with these SH genes, along with fungicide application
can provide even better protection from severe CLR outbreaks.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
However, H. vastatrix has
evolved to overcome these forms of control to varying degrees.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Given this, other cultural
practices are also recommended in an IPDM system for a coﬀee farm.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
By pruning both the coﬀee plant and the shade trees which surround them, the coﬀee
ﬁeld beneﬁts from better air circulation, lowering the inter-canopy relative humidity
levels, which can hinder the sporulation of H. vastatrix urediniospores.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The mere act of
pruning also removes the possible build-up of primary spore inoculum on the coﬀee
plant itself.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Selection of locally adapted and/or improved varieties, cultivars, or coﬀee hybrids which
exhibit known resistance to CLR is considered as frontline protection from the pathogen.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Locally adapted coﬀee types can exhibit better plant vigour, which, in turn, bolsters their
overall defence when encountered with a disease such as CLR Complete farm renovation
Table 1.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:

Filho and Domian, 2019).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: The dose should be applied to every 0.5 ha of coﬀee land area.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Complete farm renovation
or rehabilitation of old coﬀee plants with these vigorous and/or resistant varieties is a
decision that coﬀee farmers can make only a few times in the long production cycles of
the coﬀee crop.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Therefore, the choice of the coﬀee variety grown is a critical decision to
make and requires a cost-beneﬁt analysis weighing up the suitability of the variety to the
local environment, yield potential, niche market value of the beans, and pest and disease
resistance.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Coﬀee plants that have high production of fruits tend to be more severely attacked in the
subsequent year by CLR.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
This has been attributed to the transport of protective phenolic
compounds from the leaves to the beans, leaving the evergreen leaves vulnerable to
pathogen attack (De Filho and Domian, 2019).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Given these ﬁndings, a holistic approach to
developing an IPDM against CLR involves the ﬁne balance of the coﬀee plant yielding
capacity with the age of the plant (i.e.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
older plants will be less vigorous and therefore
more prone to attack) along with the planting density in the ﬁeld (i.e.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
high-density
planting will lead to higher in-ﬁeld relative humidity thereby promoting disease
outbreaks).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
New biological control agents (BCAs) are being investigated (Table 2) which
are environmentally friendly and show good potential for control of CLR (Koutouleas et
al., 2022).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
However, these BCAs still require large-scale testing for eﬃcacy in the coﬀee
ﬁeld.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Asides from the application of chemical fungicides, most practices recommended
for the control of CLR are compatible with farming systems such as organic, bird-friendly
and agroforestry.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

Discussion
Can natural enemies control H. vastatrix?

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: H. vastatrix?

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Habitat complexity in farming coﬀee can lead to enhanced ecological pest-disease control
and overall better plant health (compared to monoculture farming).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
By farming coﬀee
together with diﬀerent plant and tree species, a higher number of predators and natural
enemies may be present in the coﬀee ﬁeld.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Control of certain pests or pathogens can
also be achieved through the timely introduction of microorganisms or insects which act
as BCAs in the coﬀee ﬁeld (Koutouleas et al., 2022). BCAs may act through various
mechanisms to control a pest or disease.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
These mechanisms include competition,
antibiosis, hyperparasitism, or induced resistance.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Table 2 highlights some of the BCAs
which are known to target H. vastatrix.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
These organisms range from other fungi, bacteria
and insects which can have an inhibitory eﬀect on the growth, survival and/ or
reproduction of H. vastatrix.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
However, there are challenges associated with disease
control with BCAs such as oﬀ-target eﬀects on other organisms in the coﬀee ﬁeld or a
lack of eﬃcacy due to the presence of other enemies which may feed on or compete with
the BCA (Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
similaris
Natural Polymer: Chitosan  (an amino polysaccharide obtained from
crustaceans and insects)
Chitosan is not technically a BCA but is rather considered a biopesticide.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
*

An alternate host or secret sex life?

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
H. vastatrix is considered a macrocyclic rust, which means it produces diﬀerent spore
types.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Thus far, the role of the sexual basidiospores in the fungal life cycle remains
unknown.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Basidiospores are very small (around 5 microns).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The baﬄing thing is, no one
knows the target host these spores are intended for.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
It is hypothesised that H. vastatrix
uses basidiospores to alternate from its primary host (the coﬀee plant) to an alternate
plant host (unknown) (Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
This lifestyle pattern allows the fungus to “overwinter” and
complete its sexual cycle on an alternate plant host when the season changes.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
However,
in tropical coﬀee-growing regions, there is no real winter season, and since the ﬁrst
outbreak of coﬀee leaf rust in 1869, no alternate host has ever been detected in or
around coﬀee plantations.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
With no known host to complete its sexual cycle, it is a
mystery how the fungus can possibly create new, more virulent versions of itself, which
are today plaguing our coﬀee production and therefore causing huge economic losses.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
A
similar situation is known for stripe (yellow) rust of cereal crops and grasses (caused by
Puccinia striiformis).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The rust fungus was discovered in the mid-18th century, yet the
alternate host plant (Berberis spp.)

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: was not detected until 2010.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Some researchers postulate the basidiospores of H. vastatrix are remnants of an earlier
rust ancestor and no longer utilised by the fungus.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Others argue that the preservation of
the basidiospores in the observed disease cycle is enough evidence for the possibility of a
viable, alternate host.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Recent scholars have uncovered a so-called “crypto-sexuality”, in
Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The hyperparasite Lecanicilium lecanii (white spores) attacking H. vastatrix (orange spores)
on a coﬀee leaf.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Courtesy of Dr Melanie Bordeaux, director of NICAFRANCE Foundation’s research
centre, Nicaragua.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
which H. vastatrix can asexually produce new versions of itself without the need for an
alternate host (Carvalho et al., 2011).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Despite apparently not completing its sexual cycle, the fungus is capable of producing
new virulent variants.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: These new “races” hinder plant-breeding eﬀorts.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
In addition, the
fungus can develop resistance to fungicides.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Future coﬀee farming under agroforestry systems
Simply put, agroforestry means “farming with trees”.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
However, this farming system is far
from simple and the ecological interactions which lie within are largely unknown both
from an agronomical and ecological point of view.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
A coﬀee agroforestry system is a
farming approach that incorporates the growth of the coﬀee crop along with other shade
trees and/or shrub species.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The shade tree species are often fast-growing timber, fuel
and/or fruit trees which can provide an alternate means of income for coﬀee farmers
Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Disease cycle of Hemileia vastatrix.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The asexual cycle has been well documented, while the
sexual cycle has been hypothesised to take place on an unknown alternate plant host.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Courtesy
of Koutouleas and Collinge (2022).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: and/or fruit trees which can provide an alternate means of income for coﬀee farmers.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Since C. arabica has its evolutionary origins in the Afromontane forest understorey, many
coﬀee scientists share the opinion that the plant is shade-loving (or shade-tolerant to say
the least).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
With global reforestation being a top priority, the use of agroforestry systems
in coﬀee production has recently gained increased traction.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Some would argue that
traditional African farmers intuitively practiced diﬀerent forms of agroforestry together
with small-scale coﬀee production.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
However, since the expansion of coﬀee production
across sub-tropical growing regions (e.g.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Vietnam, Bolivia, etc.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
), coﬀee agroforestry
systems have decreased in popularity.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Monoculture coﬀee farming in open ﬁelds with full
sun exposure has been shown to increase short-term yields and easily scale-up
production (compatible with modern agricultural technologies).

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
But how does infection
by “Devastating Emily” compare between a monoculture versus agroforestry coﬀee
production system?

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Researchers have been elucidating the interactions between shade
and CLR.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Figure 7 illustrates the key dynamics that have been identiﬁed to play a role in
disease development in shaded coﬀee.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Under the shade, coﬀee tends to produce a lower
fruit load which in turn reduces the likelihood of rust infection.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
However, dense shade
trees promote a higher overall relative humidity which allows for more leaf moisture and
the potential for optimal water conditions for the sporulation of H. vastatrix
urediniospores.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The habitats under the shaded coﬀee system can also play a role in the
disease development of CLR.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
More diverse plant species can support the presence of
natural enemies of H. vastatrix such as the hyperparasitic fungus Lecanicillium lecanii.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Given these dynamics, it is easy to see how the use of shade is a contentious issue for
coﬀee farming.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Coﬀee leaf rust and climate change
Interactions between H. vastatrix and weather patterns have been linked to diﬀerent
stages of the disease cycle.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
However, predictions concerning future climate changes and
disease pressure are diﬃcult to unravel.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Like most fungal pathogens, the disease cycle of
H. vastatrix is tightly regulated to the atmospheric temperature and humidity.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Provided
that the coﬀee plant leaf is moist for 6–24 hours and air temperatures are maintained
between the optimal of 21 and 25°C, then H. vastatrix can germinate in most coﬀee-
growing environments.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
If future coﬀee-growing climates are warmer and drier then CLR
prevalence may be reduced. On the other hand, if excessive rainfall occurs in the dry
seasons then there could be more opportunity for additional CLR outbreaks to occur.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Nevertheless, recent modelling eﬀorts in coﬀee-growing areas of Brazil have failed to
predict connections between CLR outbreaks and climate forecasting.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
Conclusion
There are many plant diseases that can impact our daily lives; CLR impacts the reliability
of our future coﬀee supply.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
To some, this is a serious threat to a daily habit, natural
stimulant and source of culinary pleasure.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
To smallholder coﬀee farmers, this disease
poses a danger to farm productivity and in turn the livelihoods of those who depend on
coﬀee beans as a main source of household income.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
By understanding the causal fungal
pathogen and the best methods to prevent and control CLR, we can ensure the health of
coﬀee plants across the tropics which supply the nearly 10 billion kg of beans needed
Fig.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text:
The key features under a shaded coﬀee production system that can inﬂuence the
likelihood of a coﬀee leaf rust epidemic.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: Figure courtesy of the author.

metadata.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

text: annually for our cups of “liquid gold”.

text:
Data in Brief 48 (2023) 109226 
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect 
Data in Brief 
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/dib 
Data Article 
CoLeaf-DB: Peruvian coffee leaf images dataset 
for coffee leaf nutritional deﬁciencies 
detection and classiﬁcation 
Victor A. Tuesta-Monteza ∗, Heber I. Mejia-Cabrera , Juan Arcila-Diaz 
Facultad de Ingeniería Arquitectura y Urbanismo, Universidad Señor de Sipán, Perú
a r t i c l e 
i n f o 
Article history: 
Received 4 April 2023 
Revised 26 April 2023 
Accepted 8 May 2023 
Available online 12 May 2023 
Dataset link: CoLeaf DATASET (Original 
data) 
Keywords: 
Peruvian coffee 
Image datasets 
Machine learning 
Deep learning 
Deﬁciencies detection 
a b s t r a c t 
This article introduces Peruvian coffee leaf datasets known 
as CATIMOR, CATURRA and BORBON of coffee plantations lo- 
cated at San Miguel de las Naranjas and La Palma Central, 
Jaén province, Cajamarca, Perú.

The leaves with nutritional 
deﬁciencies were identiﬁed by agronomists, using a physi- 
cal structure the controlled environment was designed and 
the images were captured with a digital camera.

The dataset 
contains 1006 leaf images grouped according to their nu- 
tritional deﬁciencies (Boron, Iron, Potasium, Calcium, Mag- 
nesium, Manganese, Nitrogen and others).

CoLeaf dataset 
contain images that facilitate training and validation dur- 
ing the utilization of deep learning algorithms for coffee 
plant leaf nutritional deﬁciencies recognition and classiﬁca- 
tion.
The dataset is publicly and freely available at http://dx.
doi.org/10.17632/brfgw46wzb.1 .
© 2023 Published by Elsevier Inc.

This is an open access article under the CC BY license 
( http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ ) 
∗Corresponding author at: Facultad de Ingeniería Arquitectura y Urbanismo, University of the Lord of Sipan, Km 5 
Carretera a Pimentel, Pimentel, Chiclayo Peru.
E-mail address: vtuesta@crece.uss.edu.pe (V.A.
Tuesta-Monteza).

https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dib.2023.109226 
2352-3409/© 2023 Published by Elsevier Inc.

This is an open access article under the CC BY license 
( http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ ) 

2 
V.A.
Tuesta-Monteza, H.I.

Mejia-Cabrera and J. Arcila-Diaz / Data in Brief 48 (2023) 109226 
Speciﬁcations Table 
Subject 
Computer Science, Agricultural Science, Biological Science 
Speciﬁc subject area 
Artiﬁcial Intelligence, Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition 
Type of data 
Images 
How the data were acquired 
The coffee leaves were collected and classiﬁed according to nutritional 
deﬁciencies by an agronomist engineer.

Raw JPEG images of the leaves of 
coffee plants were captured under controlled environment with a Canon 
PowerShot SX50 HS camera with a sensor CMOS, resolution of 12.1MP.

Data format 
Raw, the data are in jpeg format 
Description of data collection 
The images present in the dataset were captured in a controlled environment.

The physical structure of the controlled environment allowed to control the 
distance from the digital camera to the object (coffee leaf), improve 
luminosity, distribute the light and to have a 0% shadow capture.

Data source location 
Source location was coffee plantations located at San Miguel de las Naranjas 
and La Palma Central, Jaén province, Cajamarca, Perú with a Latitude 
5 ° 44 ′ 27.2" S and a longitude of 78 ° 51 ′ 25.4" W, in the year 2014.

Data accessibility 
The datasets are publicly and freely available on mendeley data repository 
with DOI: 10.17632/brfgw46wzb.1 at http://dx.doi.org/10.17632/brfgw46wzb.1 
Related research article 
Vassallo-Barco M., Vives-Garnique L., Tuesta-Monteza V., Mejía-Cabrera H.I., 
Toledo R.Y., Automatic detection of nutritional deﬁciencies in coffee tree leaves 
through shape and texture descriptors, Journal of Digital Information 
Management, 15 (1) (2017) 7-18.

Value of the Data 
• Data is used for evaluating algorithms, which are used in machine learning or deep learn- 
ing for training, testing and validation of classiﬁcation of nutritional deﬁciencies for instance 
Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potassium, Magnesium, Boron, Calcium, Manganese, Calcium, Iron and 
others.

• This dataset encourages and motivates further research of machine learning about the char- 
acteristics of coffee leaves.

• Nutritional deﬁciencies in coffee plants affect production and therefore it is important its 
early identiﬁcation.

This dataset can be used in improving the accuracy of coffee leaf nutri- 
tional deﬁciencies detection and classiﬁcation. • In addition to deep learning the present dataset can be used for the extraction of speciﬁc 
characteristics of coffee leaves, such as shape, texture, color, to analyze images, as well as for 
segmentation tasks. It is also possible to employ classical machine learning such as SVM, de- 
cision trees, speciﬁc rule-based image processing to identify nutritional deﬁciencies in coffee 
leaves.

Objective 
Leaves analysis for evaluating the nutritional state of the crops is a practice commonly used 
[1] , by analyzing coffee leaves, nutritional deﬁciencies [2] and common diseases [ 3 , 4 ] can be 
determined.

The present dataset has been used to automatically detect nutritional deﬁciencies 
considering the shape and color of coffee leaves, using a naive Bayes classiﬁer and another clas- 
siﬁer based on neural networks, obtaining for both results that can be improved using other 
classiﬁcation and processing methods.

Data Description 
The composition of the Coleaf-DB data set organized in Table 1 is shown below.

This dataset 
is composed of 10 folders representing the nutritional deﬁciency of Nitrogen (N), Phosphorus (P), 

V.A.
Tuesta-Monteza, H.I.

Mejia-Cabrera and J. Arcila-Diaz / Data in Brief 48 (2023) 109226 
3 
Potassium (K), Magnesium (Mg), Boron (B), Manganese (Mn), Calcium (Ca), Iron (Fe), healthy 
leaves and leaves with more than one deﬁciency present in the leaves of the coffee tree.

The 
images within each folder have the annotations of the nutritional deﬁciency in their respective 
ﬁle name.

The second column of Table 1 indicates the number of images contained in each 
folder, with dimensions of 30 0 0 ×40 0 0 px in compressed jpeg format with a horizontal and 
vertical resolution of 180 dpi and a depth of 24 bits.

Table 1 
Number of digital images by nutritional deﬁciency of coffee leaves from the Coleaf-DB dataset.

Nutritional deﬁciencies of Leaf 
Number of images 
Healthy leaf 
6 
Nitrogen (N) 
64 
Phosphorus (P) 
246 
Potassium (K) 
96 
Magnesium (Mg) 
79 
Boron (B) 
101 
Manganese (Mn) 
83 
Calcium (Ca) 
162 
Iron (Fe) 
65 
More than one deﬁciency 
104 
The researchers conducted a tour of the coffee plantation to collect leaves of the varieties 
CATIMOR, CATURRA and BORBON in their second productive stage, after the phenological phase 
of maturation after having harvested the ﬁrst production and waiting for the next phase of ﬂow- 
ering, about 4 years after planting.

In a controlled environment, images were taken and classi- 
ﬁed according to nutritional deﬁciency considering leaf characteristics (interveinal coloration, 
chlorosis and deformation).

This classiﬁcation was carried out by an agronomist engineer using 
the observation method.
Fig.
1 (a) below shows the image of a healthy leaf.
Nutritional deﬁciencies and their representative characteristics are described below.

Nitrogen (N) 
The symptoms appear ﬁrst in the old or developed leaves and progress towards the young 
parts, presenting a uniform chlorosis that advances from the base towards the apex of the leaf 
and from the central vein towards the edges of the leaf, when the deﬁciency is more severe 
it becomes more chlorotic and covers the entire leaf blade.

A total of 64 images were taken 
and processed with this nutritional deﬁciency.
Fig.

1 (b) below shows the image of a leaf with 
Nitrogen deﬁciency.

Phosphorus (P) 
Older leaves show lobular interveinal chlorosis, with irregularly shaped yellow-tan spots 
showing areas with a reddish hue.

A total of 246 images were taken and processed with this 
nutritional deﬁciency.
Fig.
1 (c) below shows the image of a leaf with Phosphorus deﬁciency.

Potassium (K) 
At the beginning, a yellow-brown spot appears as a band, becoming necrotic later with a 
dark brown shade, a yellow halo limits the necrosis of the edge; this deﬁciency appears ﬁrst in 
the old leaves, ﬁnally the edges of the leaves and the tips curl upwards [5] .

A total of 96 images 
were taken and processed with this nutritional deﬁciency.
Fig.

1 (d) below shows the image of a 
leaf with Potassium deﬁciency.

4 
V.A.
Tuesta-Monteza, H.I.

Mejia-Cabrera and J. Arcila-Diaz / Data in Brief 48 (2023) 109226 
2.4.

Magnesium (Mg) 
This nutritional deﬁciency is shown by interveinal chlorosis on the older leaves of the plant.

The yellowing starts at the base of the branch and spreads towards the tip, with green stripes 
appearing along the midrib of the leaf forming an inverted wedge towards the petiole, the 
chlorosis is followed by rapid and severe defoliation.

A total of 79 images were taken and pro- 
cessed with this nutritional deﬁciency.
Fig.

1 (e) below shows the image of a leaf with Magne- 
sium deﬁciency.

Boron (B) 
This deﬁciency manifests itself in the young leaves, which are small, elongated, twisted, wrin- 
kled, with irregular edges, deformed and leathery in texture.

Leaves show a dull olive-green 
chlorosis extending from the apex to the base, the leaf margin is rough.

Older leaves are yel- 
lowish at the tip, showing suberization and the midrib and secondary veins are corky.

A total of 
101 images were taken and processed with this nutritional deﬁciency.
Fig.

1 (f) below shows the 
image of a leaf with Boron deﬁciency.

Manganese (Mn) 
This deﬁciency shows up in the young leaves with a pale green color, with the main veins 
and a band on either side remaining deep green.

As the deﬁciency progresses, the leaves turn 
increasingly yellow.

A total of 83 images were taken and processed with this nutritional deﬁ- 
ciency.
Fig.
1 (g) below shows the image of a leaf with Manganese deﬁciency.

Calcium (Ca) 
This deﬁciency is shown by marginal chlorosis of new leaves.

Chlorosis is regularly associated 
with a deformation of the leaf which acquires a convex shape and with the formation of cork 
in the veins on the underside of the leaves.

Leaves lose their erect condition and hang down- 
ward without abscission.

A total of 162 images were taken and processed with this nutritional 
deﬁciency.
Fig.
1 (h) below shows the image of a leaf with Calcium deﬁciency.

Iron (Fe) 
In plants exhibiting Fe deﬁciencies the new leaves take on colorations ranging from greenish 
yellow to very light green (almost white), while the veins remain green, forming a very ﬁne net- 
ting [6] .
A total of 65 images were taken and processed with this nutritional deﬁciency.
Fig.

1 (i) 
below shows the image of a leaf with Iron deﬁciency ( Table 2 ).
V.A.
Tuesta-Monteza, H.I.

Mejia-Cabrera and J. Arcila-Diaz / Data in Brief 48 (2023) 109226 
5 
Fig 1.

Healthy leaf (a), Nitrogen deﬁciency (b), Phosphorus deﬁciency (c), Potassium deﬁciency (d), Magnesium deﬁ- 
ciency (e), Boron deﬁciency (f), Manganese deﬁciency (g), Calcium deﬁciency (h), Iron deﬁciency (i), Leaves with more 
than one deﬁciency (j).

Table 2 
Color and shape characteristics of leaves with nutritional deﬁciencies.

Nutritional 
deﬁciency 
Color characteristic 
Shape characteristic 
Nitrogen (N) 
Light yellow starting at the base.

Phosphorus (P) 
Red and brown (burn).

Potassium (K) 
Brown (burn) with neighboring yellow areas at 
the apex.

Magnesium (Mg) 
Very light green in the leaf area (between the 
veins), with green veins.

Boron (B) 
Rounded apex, rounded leaf 
shape.

Manganese (Mn)

tertiary veins, the main vein maintains the

6 
V.A.
Tuesta-Monteza, H.I.

Mejia-Cabrera and J. Arcila-Diaz / Data in Brief 48 (2023) 109226 
3.

Experimental Design, Materials and Methods 
3.1.

Data Acquisition 
The number of samples for each type of nutritional deﬁciency was limited by the man- 
ifestations of the plantations visited in San Miguel de las Naranjas and La Palma Central in 
the province of Jaen in Peru, which are located approximately 1459 meters above mean sea 
level, with a temperature between 11 °C and 25 °C and an annual rainfall between 700mm and 
20 0 0mm approximately.

A possible bias is presented in the imbalance of samples for each nutri- 
tional deﬁciency, because the state of health of the plantations has depended on the agricultural 
management of the coffee plant by the owners.

In the area of sample acquisition, it was found that the plants showed recurrent manifes- 
tations of 8 nutritional deﬁciencies, these being Nitrogen (N), Phosphorus (P), Potassium (K), 
Magnesium (Mg), Boron (B), Manganese (Mn), Calcium (Ca), Iron (Fe), likewise, the number of 
samples for each deﬁciency is related to the ﬁeld observations by the agronomist during the 
visits, carrying out the following tasks: 
a) The work team led by the agronomist identiﬁed the area of land with the coffee plantation 
and was located in one of the corners where the plantation began with the purpose of mak- 
ing a sweep in an orderly manner.

b) Each one of the plants was checked to collect samples of leaves with nutritional deﬁciencies 
identiﬁed according to what was found, for this reason the quantities were not balanced.

c) In each plant the agronomist made a thorough observation and took the leaf that adequately 
represented the nutritional deﬁciency, verifying with the table of characteristics of nutritional 
deﬁciencies, then the corresponding classiﬁcation was made.

Images were captured in a controlled environment using a Canon PowerShot SX50 HS digital 
camera with a CMOS sensor and 12.1MP resolution.

Considering the recommendations of the photographic experts, the physical structure of the 
controlled environment for image capture was built ( Fig.

This physical aluminum structure 
allowed to control the top, bottom, right and left distance from the digital camera to the ob- 
ject (coffee leaf).

To control the light intensity, a cylindrical structure of 34cm in diameter and 
34cm in height was built, surrounded by white muslin cloth; this cloth was chosen because 
it allows the passage of light in an adequate manner.

Two 250 lumen artiﬁcial light sources 
were included, placed at a distance of 14 cm each from the cylindrical structure and at about 
45 degrees of light beam angle with respect to the object.

The capture of images is done at a 
distance of 34cm, which allows capturing complete leaves of different sizes, the luminosity was 
improved without bouncing due to the cylindrical structure that evenly distributes artiﬁcial and 
natural light, also to have a capture with 0% shadows a transparent stool was placed that al- 
lows having the object (coffee leaf) suspended in the air.

The images acquired with dimensions 
of 30 0 0 ×40 0 0 pixels were not preprocessed in order to preserve all the information in them, 
so that the researchers can use the dataset with the original data and apply the preprocessing 
techniques according to their research objectives.

Preliminary Results 
To obtain preliminary results, the deep convolutional neural network ResNet50 was used to 
classify coffee nutritional deﬁciencies in the Coleaf-DB dataset.

The dataset was divided into a 
training set with 800 images and a test set with 200 images, i.e.

from each group of nutri- 
tional deﬁciencies 80% of images have been taken for training and 20% for evaluating the neural 
network.

The images were resized to 224 ×224 pixels to ﬁt the ResNet50 input, normalizing all 
pixels.
V.A.
Tuesta-Monteza, H.I.

Mejia-Cabrera and J. Arcila-Diaz / Data in Brief 48 (2023) 109226 
7 
Fig 2.
Physical structure of the controlled environment for image capture.
The model was trained for 100 epochs with a batch size of 64 and a learning rate of 0.001.
The cross-entropy loss function and the Adam optimizer were used.

The model achieved an 
accuracy of 87.75% on the test set.

Ethics Statements 
The dataset presented in this work does not include tests on animals or humans.

All images 
used were obtained by the authors and do not come from any other source.

Declaration of Competing Interest 
The authors declare that they have no known competing ﬁnancial interests or personal rela- 
tionships that could have appeared to inﬂuence the work reported in this paper.

Data Availability 
CoLeaf DATASET (Original data) (Mendeley Data).

CRediT Author Statement 
Victor A. Tuesta-Monteza: Writing – review & editing, Investigation; Heber I. Mejia-Cabrera: 
Writing – original draft; Juan Arcila-Diaz: Methodology, Conceptualization.

MINERAL DEFICIENCY SYMPTOMS OF COFFEE
Mike A. Nagao, Kent D. Kobayashi, and George M. Yasuda
INTRODUCTION
High yields of coffee (Coffea arabica L.) in the
Kona district of Hawaii are attributed to Kona's
unique climatic conditions, pruning, dense plan-
tings, and high fertilization rates (1).

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Fresh cherry
yields of 16,800 kg/ha have been recorded (4) and
are estimated to remove 43.1,3.6, and 38.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
I kg/ha of
nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K)
respectively (7).

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
The importance of nitrogen and
potassium for high yields was shown in a study in
which coffee fields receiving low nitrogen and potas-
sium fertilization had a nine-fold yield reduction
within two years (3).

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Although a response to phos-
phorus fertilization was not observed in this study,
yields increased 28 percent when nitrogen was sup-
plemented with phosphorus and given in four
applications during the crop cycle (2).

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
It was con-
cluded
that
when
nitrogen requirements were
satisfied, plants responded to phosphorus.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Three other macronutrients, and seven micro-
nutrients, also are essential to crop production.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
The macronutrients are calcium (Ca), magnesium
(Mg), and sulfur (S); the micronutrients are iron
(Fe), zinc (Zn), boron (B), manganese (Mn), cop-
per (Cu), molybdenum (Mo), and chlorine (Cl).

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
When plants are grown without adequate essen-
tial nutrients, characteristic deficiency symptoms
result.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Recognizing these visual symptoms can aid
growers in assessing the nutritional status of their
coffee crops and applying corrective measures.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
This study provides descriptions and photographs
of mineral deficiency symptoms ofthe Guatemalan,
Caturra, and Maragogipe (Java) coffee cultivars.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Mineral nutrient concentrations in leaves of defi-
cient and normal (control) plants are also given.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
MATERIALS AND METHODS
Experiments were conducted in Hilo and Kona,
Hawaii, between March 1984 and October 1985.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Seeds of the Guatemalan, Caturra, and Marago-
gipe cultivars were obtained from the University
of Hawaii Experimental Station in Kona, germi-
nated in vermiculite, and planted into 15.5xl1.5-cm
pots containing vermiculite.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Plants were kept in a
fiberglass greenhouse and irrigated twice a week
with 200 ml of a complete nutrient solution (5).

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
The medium was leached with 200 ml distilled water
every two weeks.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
After reaching heights of 15 cm
(Guatemalan and Caturra cultivars) and 25 cm
(Maragogipe cultivar), plants were transplanted
to 15.5xl1.5-cm pots containing perlite.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Control
plants were then watered three times a week with
200 ml of a complete nutrient solution; test plants
were similarly watered with a solution lacking in
nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, calcium, mag-
nesium, sulfur, or iron (5).

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
The pH of the solutions
was adjusted to 6.5-6.8 with 1.0 N HCl or NaOH.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Pots were leached with 200 ml distilled water every
two weeks.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
The study was set up in a statistically
random design with two to four plants per treat-
ment.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
When visual symptoms became severe, all fully
expanded leaves were harvested from deficient
and control plants and analyzed for nutrient con-
tent with an X-ray fluorescent quantometer.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
The
experiments were performed three times for the
Guatemalan and twice for the Caturra and Mara-
gogipe cultivars.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Only the Guatemalan cultivar was used to 0 b-
serve boron and zinc deficiencies.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Plants 15 cm
high were transferred to foil-covered wide-mouth
glass jars containing 850 ml of a complete solution
(control) or solutions lacking zinc or boron (5).

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Solutions were adjusted to pH 6.5, constantly aer-
ated, and replaced at two-week intervals.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Plants
were kept in a fiberglass greenhouse.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Each treat-
ment consisted of two replicate plants.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
After six
months the plants were analyzed for nutrient con-
tent as previously described.

RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Deficiency symptoms for nitrogen, phosphorus,
potassium, calcium, magnesium, sulfur, and iron
were consistent among all cultivars studied.

key to these symptoms is given in Table 1.

Nitrogen deficiency, observed four to six weeks
after treatments began, was characterized at first
by general chlorosis of the youngest leaves (Fig.

nitrogen deficiency of coffee grown in full sun de-
velops rapidly in younger leaves.

GLOSSARY
Abscise: To shed plant parts, e.g., leaves, flowers,
fruit.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Acute: Condition when severe symptoms are vi-
sible.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text: Apical Bud: Growing region at the tip of a shoot.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text: Blade: Broad, expanded part of the leaf.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Chlorosis: Yellowing of plant tissues due to loss
of green pigmentation.

metadata.filename: Coffee plant nutritional deficiency symptoms (with pictures) Hawaii.pdf

text:
Internode: Region on a stem between two succes-

text:
Introduction 
International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN), through its BRIDGE 
program (Building River Dialogue and Governance), is supporting work on transboundary river 
cooperation in the 3S (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: Srepok, Sesan and Sekong) river basins.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Coffee is the dominant 
commercial land use and a major user of water in the Central Highlands of Vietnam, which forms the 
headwaters of the Srepok and Sesan (2S) Rivers.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In 2019, a rapid assessment of opportunities was conducted to transition coffee monocultures into 
diversified coffee farming with significant benefits in terms of total crop value, drought resilience, 
existing coffee supply to the global market and dry season water availability and downstream flows.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The analysis showed that more efficient irrigation and the transition of drought prone areas out of 
coffee and into high value tree crops could increase the dry season flow of the 2S by 50% with 
potentially substantial downstream and transboundary benefits.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The assessment was updated in 2020: https://www.iucn.org/news/viet-nam/202008/transforming-
coffee-and-water-use-central-highlands-vietnam-case-study-dak-lak-province.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
There is growing business interest in such transition to reduce the risk of farmers abandoning coffee 
altogether under conditions in increasing weather variability, thereby threatening supply chains, and 
to ensure compliance with increasingly strict international regulations on pesticide residues.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
See: 
https://www.iucn.org/news/viet-nam/202010/business-consultation-coffee-transformation-and-water-
use-vietnams-central-highlands.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Building on the 2020 assessment, the objective of this assignment is to provide a more detailed 
analysis of the costs and benefits of the proposed transition from coffee monocultures into diverse, 
higher value, and water saving agroforestry across all five provinces in the Central Highlands.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The goal of this study is to: 
1.

soil/topography.

IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Identify areas with a potential water shortage in extreme dry years for the December-May dry 
season by looking at the monthly Standard Precipitation Index and the Normalized Difference 
Vegetation Index derived from satellite imagery, over a 20-years period.

a.
