7 
 
This analysis differs from the initial rapid assessment in the following ways: 
a.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: The report covers all 5 provinces of the Central Highlands (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Kon Tum, Gia Lai, Dak Lak, 
Dak Nong and Lam Dong).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Looking at the study from an administrative boundary perspective 
may facilitate decision making at provincial level.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: b.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The modelling timeframe has been set at 30 years so as to include the full life cycle of Robusta 
coffee (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: 25 years).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: c. The analysis is done at both the landscape level and the individual farm level.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The landscape 
level is important to understand, e.g.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
total provincial production of coffee and intercrops or to 
better capture regional water savings.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The farm level analysis on the other hand allows us to 
assess farm income and investment needs at the individual level.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
d. The report includes a return on investment (ROI) analysis to help the public and private sector 
understand the cost and benefits of a large-scale intervention strategy.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
At the farm level, the 
ROI analysis can help convince farmers shifting to the new business model and allows to 
estimate farm financing needs (if any).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
e. The report includes a quick assessment of potential carbon sequestration in view of changing 
climate conditions.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: The report is structured as follows.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: At first the rationale for this study is elaborated.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The methodology 
and data used in this report are then described.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In the following chapter (results) different options for 
agricultural transformation are analyzed in terms of coffee production, water saving, profitability and 
climate change mitigation both at the landscape and farm level.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Finally, conclusions and 
recommendations are presented.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf
IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Background 
Vietnam is the world’s second largest coffee producer and leading Robusta coffee exporter.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The 
country achieves the world’s highest coffee yields which puts it in the center of the global coffee 
market as demand is constantly increasing (1-3% per year).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Coffee is the most important agricultural 
export product in value for Vietnam and supporting the rural livelihoods of over 2 million people, mainly 
in the Central Highlands.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Export volumes peaked at 30 million bags in 2018 generating revenues of 
3.54 billion USD.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: The Central Highlands has a population of circa 5.7 million (GSO, 2016).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
It is the second poorest 
region in Viet Nam and rural poverty is almost double the national average (28.8% vs. 17.9%) with 
particularly high poverty rates among ethnic minorities who make up 32% of the population.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Over 40% 
of the Central Highlands’ population earns an income from coffee production.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In order to make coffee farming economically viable, irrigation is needed to achieve yields that 
average 2.3 tons of green beans per ha (ICO, 2019).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
However, people living in the Central Highlands 
increasingly face the challenges of drought and extreme water shortage.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
These threaten agricultural 
production, which not only affects community life but also weakens the local economy (ICEM, 2013).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: E.g.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: as a result of the 2016 drought, the discharge of main rivers reduced by 20-90% (NCHMF, 2016).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: The same year, about 70% of the cultivation area experienced severe drought (MARD, 2016).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Nearly 
170,000 ha of crops were affected by the drought, of which 7,100 ha were left fallow and more than 
95,000 ha were deficient in irrigation (CGIAR, 2016).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Aggravating this situation is the absence of systematic monitoring of water resources, which makes 
it impossible to provide information on the condition of water resources and recommend a course of 
action on water resources management for the region.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: During the dry months (January-April) Robusta coffee in Vietnam needs to be irrigated.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Although 
water is scare during this period, smallholder coffee farmers tend to irrigate up to 2 times more than 
what MARD recommends.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Over-extraction can be explained by the fact that water is an open access 
resource, has no price and licensing regulations about the maximum number of wells and their 
maximum extraction depth are not enforced.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
During the 2016 drought, CGIAR experts conducted a rapid appraisal on how to cope with climate 
change and water scarcity in agriculture and made the following recommendation to MARD: “Develop 
appropriate policies to encourage diversification of agricultural systems, including innovative financing 
mechanisms to support smallholders.” The authors argue that: “Changing land use patterns and 
landscape management are options for long-term adaptation.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Typical monocultures in the Central 
Highlands could be replaced with diversified cropping systems, which vary agricultural products (both 
cultivation and livestock).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
These diversified systems engender multiple sources of household income 
and promote resilience to climate change and extreme weather events.” 
Aligned with the above recommendations, this report presents a macro-economic landscape and farm 
level analysis for transforming coffee monocrop into diversified farming systems.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf
IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Materials and methods 
4.1  Study area 
The study area is the Central Highlands (Figure 4.1) 
which is comprised of 5 provinces, from north to south, 
Kon Tum, Gia Lai, Dak Lak, Dak Nong and Lam Dong.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The current coffee area in this region was estimated at 
586,000 ha based on SPOT satellite imagery (NIAPP, 
2015).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
To address agricultural transformation needs in 
response to climate change, it is important to 
understand land suitability for the Robusta coffee in 
terms of soil and landscape characteristics (e.g.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
topography) as well as water availability for irrigation 
during the dry season.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In an earlier IUCN report on Dak 
Lak Province (D’haeze, 2020), water scarce coffee 
areas were identified based on a geohydrological study 
by Milnes et al.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf
IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Since this information is not 
available for the entire Central Highlands, this study 
relies on time series satellite imagery to identify drought 
prone areas using the Standard Precipitation Index 
(SPI) and to assess crop vegetative response using the 
Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
4.2 Identification of drought prone coffee areas 
4.2.1 Spatiotemporal drought analysis 
A commonly used indicator to identify the severity of 
drought events, recommended by the World 
Meteorological 
Organization, 
is 
the 
Standard 
Precipitation Index (SPI).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
SPI is a normalized, 
dimensionless index representing the probability of 
occurrence of an observed rainfall amount when 
compared with the long-term median rainfall at a 
certain geographical location. Negative SPI values 
represent rainfall deficit, whereas positive SPI values 
indicate rainfall surplus.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The intensity of drought 
events can be classified according to the magnitude 
of negative SPI values (Table 4.1).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
For example, a 
negative SPI value greater than 2 is classified as extremely dry.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
SPI also enables rainfall conditions 
to be quantified over different time scales (e.g.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
3, 6, 12 or 24-months), facilitating the analyses of 
drought impact on various water resource needs.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
For example, SPI3 applied in this study, measures 
rainfall conditions over a 3-month period, the anomalies of which impact mostly soil water conditions 
and agricultural produce.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

Monthly CHIRPS (Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data) satellite images 
(Figure 4.2) were used for a period of 20 years (2001-2020).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
CHIRPS is a 35-year quasi-global rainfall 
data set, which is available in different time steps at a spatial resolution of 0.05° (~ 5 by 5 km).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The 
data can be freely downloaded at https://data.chc.ucsb.edu/products/CHIRPS-2.0/.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Using freeware 
software packages QGIS 2.16 and R Studio 1.4.1717, the SPI3 was calculated pixel by pixel for              
a 20-years monthly time series1 of CHIRPS rainfall records (Figure 4.3).

These maps are part of a full time series that 
consists of 240 maps for rainfall and SPI each (monthly data over 20 years).

Figure 4.4 shows the monthly average SPI3 for the entire Central Highlands over 20 years and 
indicates that in order of drought severity 2005, 2014 and 2020 were the most critical years.

4.2.2 Spatio-temporal vegetative crop response analysis 
Since coffee in the Central Highlands is irrigated, land suitability highly depends on water accessibility 
during the dry season.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In case of water scarcity, the trees will start dehydrating and may in extreme 
cases die.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This vegetative plant response in relation to water availability can be monitored with the 
Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), which measures the difference between                  
near-infrared (which healthy vegetation strongly reflects) and red light (which healthy vegetation 
absorbs).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: The NDVI can have a value between -1 and 1.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Values below 0 are classified as water bodies 
or clouds, values between 0 and 0.2 are bare or rock land and values above 0.2 depict vegetation.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: The higher the NDVI value the healthier/greener the vegetation.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf
IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
They have a spatial resolution of 250 by 250 m,                  
are 
available 
on 
a 
16-day 
interval 
and 
can 
be 
downloaded 
for 
free 
at 
https://modis.gsfc.nasa.gov/data/dataprod/mod13.php.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Figure 4.5 shows the NDVI trends over time 
in 2019/2020.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
For example, in Dak Lak, coffee areas in the east appear clearly affected by water 
scarcity in February (red), while in the center of the basalt plateau the NDVI values remain rather 
stable (greenish) indicating sufficient water availability (less plant water stress).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:

in coffee areas 
 
To understand plant response in relation to water availability, a spatio-temporal NDVI trend analysis 
was done using the modified Mann-Kendall method to derive the Sen slope (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
the trend direction) 
and its significance (p value).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Applying freeware software packages QGIS 2.16 and R Studio 
1.4.1717, the trend analysis was done pixel by pixel for the three driest years (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
2005, 2014 and 
2020) and for the dry season months only (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
December in the previous year till May in the current 
year; i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: 2 images/month x 6 months = 12 images/year).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
It is assumed that the NDVI will remain 
stable or show a slight decline during the dry season in irrigated areas with sufficient water availability, 
while the NDVI will significantly decline (plant wilting) towards the end of the dry season in areas with 
water scarcity.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: Figure 4.6 shows the NDVI trend during the dry season in the three driest years.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In 
2020, coffee trees in Gia Lai, Dak Lak and northern Dak Nong appeared suffering more from water 
stress (red), compared to Lam Dong province (bluish).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
13

(2005, 2014 and 2020) in coffee areas

studied (NDVIdiff = NDVIMay - NDVIDec).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
water 
scarcity), while positive values show vegetative plant recovery in May as compared to the start of the 
dry season in December (Figure 4.7).

4.2.3 Water scarce coffee areas 
Combining the results of the meteorological drought and vegetative crop response analyses allows 
us to identify areas at risk of severe water shortage during the dry season.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
For each extremely dry 
year (2005, 2014 and 2020), coffee areas with a significant negative NDVI trend (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
statistically 
significant negative Sen slope at p<0.05) and having a net negative NDVIdiff value, were identified.

4.4 Crop water requirements and current actual water use 
4.4.1 Robusta coffee 
Empirical research shows that the maximum required irrigation volume per coffee tree per round is 
~400 liters for hose irrigation (D’haeze, 2003).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
A recent study (Viossanges et al., 2019, IWMI/Nestlé/SDC project report3) found that farmers in the 
Central Highlands in general and in Dak Lak in particular appear to be shifting from traditional hose 
irrigation to overhead sprinkler to save labor time and costs (Figure 4.10).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
To calculate the landscape 
wide water requirement, the irrigation method needs to be factored in as some methods are more or 
less efficient than others.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
For hose irrigation, water is conveyed directly 
from the source to the individual coffee tree 
without significant losses.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Hence the crop water 
requirement of 400 l/tree/round is equal to the 
water extraction volume.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Assuming that the 
dimensions of each basin around an individual 
coffee tree are 2.5 by 2.5 m, then the wetted soil 
surface is 6.25 m2.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
For overhead sprinkler the 
entire field is wetted.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Given the plant spacing of 
3 m by 3 m (1,110 trees / ha), this is equivalent 
to 9 m2 per tree.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Therefore, without considering 
evaporative water losses on the canopy, the 
sprinkler method requires about 45% more 
water i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: ~600 l/tree/round (Table 4.4).

4.5 Crop modelling 
4.5.1 Crop life cycle 
Based on literature review and discussion with 
experts, the crop life cycles for Robusta coffee 
(Coffea canephora), black pepper (Piper nigrum), 
Avocado (Persea americana) and Durian (Durio) 
were developed (Figure 4.13 and Table 4.6).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The 
latter three species were recommended by WASI as 
potential intercrops.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The coffee life cycle starts with 2 zero-production 
years and subsequently 5 linear production 
increase years (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
from year 3 to 8 productivity 
linearly increases from 0.5 to 6.0 t/ha).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The 
maximum potential yield is reached in year 8. The 
stable maximum potential yield phase counts 10 
years (years 8 to 17) after which productivity 
declines linearly to 0.75 t/ha in year 25.

gives on overview of the life cycle stages and

was 
calculated for each rejuvenation 
cycle.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The one with the highest 
average over 30 years results the 
optimum rejuvenation cycle.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The above procedure was repeated for each crop species (4 in total) and run separately for (i) the 
entire current coffee area, (ii) the suitable coffee areas and (iii) the unsuitable coffee areas.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Figure 4.16 shows the total coffee production per 
year for 2 distinct rejuvenation cycles (19 and 25 
years) per hectare.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
These were chosen as the        
19 year-cycle results in the highest average yield 
(among all 30 scenarios analyzed) and 25 years 
coincides with the end of the productive lifetime for 
coffee.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
It shows that the better option is to 
rejuvenate earlier as the overall average yield will 
stabilize at 4.4 t/ha, 12% higher than the stable end 
yield for a 25-year cycle.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
At the landscape level 19 years may be an 
interesting option to spread required investment 
costs over a longer time horizon.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
However, at the 
macro-level one may want to transition faster if 
possible.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Faster transitioning meaning that larger 
areas need to be converted on an annual basis.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
At the farm level, a farmer would usually try to 
rejuvenate over a shorter time horizon if financing 
allows.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
However, it would be good to keep a 19-year rejuvenation cycle once the farm is fully 
replanted.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This is equivalent to rejuvenating 3-5 % or ~55 trees per hectare annually for monocrop 
farming.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This will guarantee a stable yield over time (beyond 25 years) and allows spreading 
investments.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: One can look at this as a depreciation process.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

4.5.3 Agricultural land use transformation scenarios 
In this report with a focus on agricultural transformation for the Central Highlands, two land use 
scenarios will be assessed: 
1.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Coffee monocrop 
This is the business as usual (BaU) scenario where it is assumed that farmers continue growing 
coffee as a monocrop (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
1,110 trees per ha) in the current coffee areas (~586,000 ha in the 
Central Highlands; cf.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: section 4.3).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The model assumes that farmers rejuvenate gradually and 
replace old coffee trees with better varieties (e.g.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
TRS1, TR4, TR9 and TR11) at a pace of ~5% 
per year equivalent to a full replacement over 19 years (cf.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
optimal crop rejuvenation cycle 
described in chapter 4.5.2).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
At landscape level a 19-year rejuvenation cycle is equivalent to 
~31,000 ha conversion of land use annually.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf
IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Coffee intercrop 
In this new scenario a distinction in land use destination at landscape level is made based on the 
aforementioned land suitability analysis (cf.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
chapter 4.3) which shows that ~532,000 ha is suitable 
for coffee production, while ~ 32,500 ha faces seasonal water scarcity.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Therefore, this new 
scenario is split into 2 parts:  
a. suitable land units where coffee is grown intercropped with pepper, avocado and durian; 
and 
b. unsuitable (water scarce) land units where coffee is replaced by an intercropped farming 
system with pepper, avocado and durian only.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
4.5.4 Maximization of gross revenue at farm and landscape level 
As described above, the agricultural transformation model aims to diversify agricultural production in 
order to save water and maximize gross revenues.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Gross revenue is calculated by multiplying the 
annual yield (t/ha) by average annual price (USD/t) per crop species.

were derived from various sources (Figure 4.17 and Table 4.7). Table 4.7 Average annual crop price

based on data from 1991 to 2018.

software.

With this method it is possible to determine the number of plants per crop species per 
hectare, while maximizing the total gross revenue for all species over a 30-year time horizon.

In the 
process, constraints can be added, e.g.

the maximum number of coffee trees may not exceed       
1,110 per hectare or coffee production in year 30 must be 20% higher than the production in year 1.

Several iterations were run, starting with few simple constraints and stepwise adding more and more 
complex constraints.

conditions and the sum of the area taken per crop species may not exceed 1 ha (i.e.

4.5.6 Calculation of the profit/loss probability and risk exposure 
In order to understand the probability of making an annual loss or profit and the associated value or 
risk for the intercrop model compared to the current situation, a Monte Carlo simulation was 
conducted.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: At first, the historic prices for each crop were tested for normality using the Shapiro-Wilk test.

This 
showed that the time series deviate significantly from normality.

text:
Therefore, a Kernel Density 
Estimation (KDE) was used to estimate the probability density functions for each historic crop price 
timeseries.

prices following the trend depicted in Figure 4.19, applying Excel’s discrete random number generator.

5.1.3 More coffee and other crops with less water 
In the Central Highlands, monocrop coffee under current excessive irrigation conditions consumes 
about 1.12 billion m3 water per year (Figure 5.5). If irrigation management is optimized for monocrop 
coffee about 290 million m3 of water can be saved (-26%).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In the intercropped scenario, water use 
gradually decreases until year 19 as coffee is gradually taken out on the water scarce land units.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In 
this case 407 million m3 of water can be saved as of year 19 compared to the BaU (-36%).

text: Optimization of water use goes hand in hand with cost savings for labor and energy.

text:
About 38 million 
USD can be saved annually or ~ 65 USD/ha/y.

58% to energy (Figure 5.6).

5.1.4 High return on investment 
Agricultural land use transformation comes at a 
cost.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Table 5.1 presents the total investment 
costs for a 20-year program of ~638 million USD.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This is equivalent to ~50-60 USD per farmer per 
year (assuming 1 ha per farming family).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
It is 
recommended to implement a large-scale 
training program for farmers on good agricultural 
practices for all crops and financial literacy in 
combination with regular awareness raising 
through simple and short TV spots explaining the 
socio-economic and environmental benefits of 
diversified farming.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The agricultural education program ideally starts 
off with a thorough training of local trainers 
(government extension officers as well as 
agronomists of private traders and end-buyers) 
by professional agricultural extension experts.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
It 
is assumed to train 470 extension officers and 
agronomists (three 4-day trainings per year) on 
sustainable 
diversified 
farm 
management          
(i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: coffee + a choice of intercrops).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Subsequently, the extension officers provide farmer 
training in traditional Farmer Field Schools (FFS) for 
groups of 25 farmers (10 FFS per beneficiary), and 
additionally through one-on-one Farmer Coaching Visits 
(FCV; 10 per beneficiary).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Through FCVs, the trainers 
reach out to individual farms where they appraise the 
farm management conditions in the field and provide ad 
hoc advice.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This approach is envisaged to be more 
impactful.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
However, this more intensive approach is also 
costlier.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In parallel, it is recommended to invest in professional nurseries to produce coffee, pepper, avocado 
and durian seedlings.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The investment costs include the cost for seedlings either to be paid by farmers 
at market price or subsidized by the government and/or the private sector.

5.1.5 Carbon sequestration potential for the Central Highlands  
Based on allometric equations, the potential for carbon sequestration was calculated for BaU 
(monocrop coffee) and for a fully intercropped farming system.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The simulation assumes for both 
scenarios that the current (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
simulation year 1) Central Highlands’ wide coffee tree stock has an 
average age of 15 years.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: This is equivalent to a carbon stock of 5.7 mio.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: tons (Figure 5.9).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
For 
monocropping, the carbon stock gradually reduces and stabilizes at 3.8 mio tons.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This trend may look 
odd but can be explained by the fact that trees will continuously be rejuvenated following a 19-year 
crop cycle to maximize productivity.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In other words, the average age of the tree stock will stabilize at 
10 years (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: at any given time there will be trees in a range of 1 to 19 years in the same field).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
For the intercrop model a similar downward trend is observed, but from year 19 onwards, additional 
carbon sequestered by avocado and durian trees adds to the equation, resulting in a total carbon 
stock of 6.9 mio tons at landscape level or 21% higher compared to the current situation (year 1).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In 
decreasing order, coffee is the main contributor to the carbon stock, followed by durian and then 
avocado (Figure 5.10). Note that in absolute terms if either of the three crops are planted as a 
monocrop, then durian has the highest carbon capturing potential, followed by avocado and then 
coffee (Figure 5.23 in chapter 0).

5.2 Farm level 
5.2.1 Higher coffee production with fewer trees 
The crop production simulation (Figure 5.11) shows that the farm level yield in year 1 for BaU 
(monocrop coffee) is ~2.37 t/ha.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This is in line with a recent ICO report (2019), mentioning that the 
average national coffee production stands at 2.3 t/ha.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Under BaU conditions, farm output declines to 
a minimum of 1.41 t/ha in year 6 (-40% vs. year 1) and then recovers to break-even in year 12          
(2.57 t/ha), to reach stable production in year 19 (4.4 t/ha).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: This is 86% higher compared to year 1.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In the new agricultural transformation model, it is assumed that farmers plant only 887 coffee trees 
(high yielding variety with a maximum potential productivity of 6 t/ha), intercropped with pepper, 
avocado and durian, compared to the traditional 1,110 coffee trees mono-cropped per hectare (-20%).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In this scenario, the coffee yield drops to 1.29 t/ha in year 7 (-46% versus year 1), then climbs to break 
even in year 14 (2.41 t/ha) to reach stable production in year 19 (3.34 t/ha).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This is 41% higher 
compared to year 1.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Figure 5.11 shows that it takes more time for the intercrop system to reach the same coffee yield per 
hectare (compared to BaU), since there are 20% less coffee trees.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The decline in yield and 
consequent income loss are partially compensated by the upcoming production of the intercrops       
(cf.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: chapter 5.2.2).

5.2.5 Initial high financial risk exposure 
Applying Monte Carlo simulation, Figure 5.20 shows a summary of the financial risk farmers may face 
if they decide to transform their farms from coffee monocrop to a fully intercropped system with 
pepper, avocado and durian.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
It is obvious that the likelihood of loss is over 50% for the first 10 years, 
with a peak of ~80% deficit risk in year 5.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
From year 14 on the probability to make profits is over 80% 
and the risk of loss becomes negligible (p<10%) as of year 17.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The total average loss value over the first 13 years (probability of loss >20%) is estimated at       
~25,000 USD/ha, while exposure to make loss (i.e. average loss times its probability) over the same 
time period is valued at ~15,000 USD/ha.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This loss is fully compensated for by the profits made from 
year 14 to 19 (6 years), in other words the break-even point is reached after 18 years.

average ~7,255 USD/ha/y, while diversified farming would bring about ~10,340 USD/ha/y 
(under constant prices over 30 years).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
d. Transformation into diversified farming will likely lead to losses valued at ~25,000 USD/ha 
over the first 13 years.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: The exposure to make loss (i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
average loss times its probability) over 
the same time period is valued at ~15,000 USD/ha.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This loss is fully compensated for by the 
profits made from year 14 to 19 (6 years), in other words the break-even point is reached after 
18 years.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: e. Transformation to intercropped farming systems requires time and resources.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The RoI 
analysis at landscape level shows that quick conversion towards diversity over a 10-year 
horizon will lead to losses and only break even in year 28, while a more gradual transformation, 
following the 19-year crop life cycle of coffee, would turn the RoI positive in year 15.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
5 https://www.globenewswire.com/en/news-release/2021/11/17/2335973/0/en/Global-Black-Pepper-Market-Is-Expected-to-
Reach-USD-5990-65-million-by-2028-Fior-Markets.html 
6 https://www.globaltrademag.com/global-pepper-market-is-expected-to-reach-840k-tonnes-by-2025/ 
7https://www.globenewswire.com/en/news-release/2020/12/02/2138112/28124/en/Global-Avocado-Market-Report-2020-
 Market-is-Forecast-to-Reach-US-17-905-Billion-by-2025-Increasing-from-US-12-824-Billion-in-2019.html 
8 https://www.mordorintelligence.com/industry-reports/fresh-durian-market 

39 
 
7.2 Environmental gains – water saving and climate change mitigation 
a.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Transformation of monocrop coffee production to a diversified crop production model comes 
with considerable water saving.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Monocrop coffee under current excessive irrigation conditions 
(BaU) consumes about 1.12 billion m3 water per year in the Central Highlands.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
If all farmers 
were to optimize irrigation volumes in this scenario, ~290 million m3 of water can be             
saved (-26%).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: b.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
For fully diversified farming on suitable land units (coffee, pepper, avocado and durian) and 
only fruit trees and pepper on water scarce land units, the total water requirement is estimated 
at ~720 million m3 per year in the Central Highlands.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In this case 407 million m3 of water can 
be saved as of year 19 compared to the BaU (-36%).

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: c. Optimization of water use goes hand in hand with cost savings for labor and energy.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: About 38 million USD can be saved annually.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Out of the total irrigation cost, 42% goes to labor 
and 58% to energy.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
d. Compared to monocrop coffee production, fully diversified farming returns carbon 
sequestration gains in the order of 82%.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Carbon capturing for monocrop coffee will reach       
3.80 mio.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: tons at landscape level in year 30.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
For intercropped farming systems this will 
increase to 6.91 mio.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: tons at the landscape level.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
7.3 Intervention strategy – costs and return on investment 
a.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
To realize this agricultural transformation, it is recommended to implement a large-scale 
training program for government extension officers, private sector agronomists and farmers in 
combination with regular awareness raising through simple and short TV spots explaining the 
socio-economic and environmental benefits of diversified farming.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
In parallel, it is 
recommended to invest in professional, accredited nurseries to produce coffee, pepper, 
avocado and durian seedlings.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: b.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The investment projection for such a long-term program is estimated at ~638 million USD over 
20 years.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
While this figure may look high, it is equivalent to only ~60 USD per farming 
household per year (assuming 1 ha per farming family) or ~1,200 USD per ha over 20 years.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
c. While the investment costs per farmer may be relatively low, agricultural transformation will 
come with losses compared to the current situation.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Only after 18 years farmers would 
generate a net benefit.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
40 
 
7.4 Recommendations 
a.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Previous projects learned that adoption of optimal (lower) irrigation application practices takes 
time despite the fact that coffee yield and product quality are not affected.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Therefore, it will be 
key to translate the proposed intercropping model into a simple concrete business case for 
communication purpose, clearly emphasizing the direct socio-economic farm benefits.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This 
will likely be more appealing for farmers to change their mindset than messaging water saving 
for the sake of downstream user benefits.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: b.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This study showed that for a given coffee life cycle of 25 years, the optimal rejuvenation cycle 
is 19 years.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Currently, farmers typically rejuvenate their farm only after 20-30 years at once or 
say 50% at a time, based on cash in hand.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The better strategy would be to depreciate the farm 
each year, i.e.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
rejuvenate each year 3-5% of the worst performing trees in order to maintain a 
long-term stable yield, hence spreading investment costs over time.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: c. In this analysis, 3 alternative intercrops were selected based on research by WASI.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The results 
show that the total production for pepper, avocado and durian could possibly reach an annual 
output of 0.13 mio.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: t/y, 1.11 mio. t/y and 0.92 mio.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: t/y respectively after 25 years.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
While beyond 
the scope of this study, it would be important to understand the extent of current production 
areas for these crops (mono- and intercrop) and resulting actual production in Vietnam.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
This 
should be compared with domestic and global supply/demand forecasts in order to quantify if 
and how much more produce of each crop the market could still absorb in the years to come, 
avoiding market saturation and inherent price collapse.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Further, it might be worth to look at 
additional intercrops such as macadamia, cashew, passion fruit, vanilla, etc.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: d. A total investment of ~638 million USD would be needed over 20 years.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
However, it requires 
further stakeholder consultation and discussion with respective government bodies, private 
sector players (traders, roasters, retail, coffee shops, etc.)

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
and not at least farmers as to how 
best share costs throughout the supply chain to effectively materialize the suggested 
agricultural transformation.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text: E.g.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
currently Vietnam has a fine network of government extension 
services from the national level, over the provinces, down to the districts and communes.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
It 
would be critical to understand the financing gap between current extension expenses broken 
down per sector (e.g.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
coffee, fruits and vegetable, rice, livestock) and the required budget to 
implement the program suggested above.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Another observation is that the investment cost for 
training and acquisition of seedlings (~50-60 USD/farmer/y) is relatively low compared to 
anticipated gross farm income if spread over time.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Therefore, one may consider a farmer-pay-
for-service-and-inputs financing model, rather than going for grants, subsidies or government 
bank loans.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
A third reflection for further discussion, refers to the payment of premium prices 
for so-called sustainable mainstream coffee.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
The roasting and retail industry used certification 
over the last 20 years to promote and communicate sustainable coffee production at very high 
cost (premium farm gate price, volume-based commission to the certification bodies and 
payment for audits, let alone additional logistic cost to separate coffee to keep it traceable to 
origin) and questionable impact at the farm level.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
Therefore, it may be worth rethinking the 
sector’s approach to support sustainable development e.g.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:
by paying into a transparently 
managed agricultural transformation fund, based on respective coffee volumes sourced at 
origin.

metadata.filename: IUCN Vietnam - water efficiency in coffee bridge_ch_coffee_transformation_final_february_2022-_revised_2_ddh_for_publication.pdf

text:

RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Coffee Leaf Rust (Hemileia vastatrix) 
Sources of Information 
●​ Perfect Daily Grind: Guide to Coffee Pests & Diseases 
●​ ScienceDirect: Coffee Leaf Rust Management 
Symptoms 
●​ Yellow-orange powdery spores on the underside of leaves.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ●​ Premature leaf drop, leading to reduced photosynthesis.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ●​ Severe cases result in defoliation, weakened plants, and reduced yields.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Preventive Actions & Why They Work 
✅ Plant Resistant Varieties (e.g., Catimor, Sarchimor) 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Some cultivars have genetic resistance to leaf rust.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
✅ Prune for Better Airflow 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Reduces humidity, which is necessary for spore germination.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
✅ Balanced Fertilization (Avoid Excess Nitrogen) 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Excess nitrogen promotes soft leaf growth, which is more susceptible to infection.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Corrective Actions – Biological/Natural Methods 
🌱 Apply Bordeaux Mixture (Copper Sulfate + Lime) 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Creates a protective film that prevents fungal germination.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
🌱 Use Neem Oil or Trichoderma-Based Biocontrols 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Neem inhibits fungal spore germination, and Trichoderma outcompetes leaf rust fungi.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Corrective Actions – Chemical Treatments 
🧪 Systemic Fungicides (Triazoles, Strobilurins, Copper-based Fungicides) 
●​ Mode of Action: 
○​ Triazoles: Disrupt fungal cell membrane production.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ○​ Strobilurins: Block fungal respiration.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ○​ Copper-based fungicides: Act as a contact barrier against spores.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Regenerative Farming Recommendations 
1️⃣ Shade Management: Maintain diverse shade trees to buffer temperature changes that trigger rust 
outbreaks.​
2️⃣ Compost & Biochar Application: Enhances soil microbiology, which supports plant immunity.​
3️⃣ Intercrop with Nitrogen-Fixing Plants: Improves plant nutrient balance to avoid excessive nitrogen.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf
RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Coffee Berry Borer (Hypothenemus hampei) 
Sources of Information 
●​ Perfect Daily Grind: Coffee Berry Borer Guide 
●​ Journal of Economic Entomology: Biological Control of Coffee Berry Borer 
Symptoms 
●​ Small holes on coffee cherries.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ●​ Premature fruit drop.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ●​ Presence of black beetles inside berries.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Preventive Actions & Why They Work 
✅ Timely Harvesting of Ripe & Overripe Cherries 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Reduces borer reproduction inside berries.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
✅ Maintain Field Sanitation (Remove Fallen Cherries) 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Eliminates breeding sites.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
✅ Introduce Parasitic Wasps (E.g., Phymastichus coffea) 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Wasps attack borer larvae, preventing reproduction.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Corrective Actions – Biological/Natural Methods 
🌱 Beauveria bassiana Fungus Application 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: This naturally occurring fungus infects and kills the beetles.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
🌱 Trap Cropping with Attractive Pheromone Lures 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Diverts borers away from main crops.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Corrective Actions – Chemical Treatments 
🧪 Insecticides (Pyrethroids, Neonicotinoids, Spinosad) 
●​ Mode of Action: 
○​ Pyrethroids: Paralyze the insect nervous system.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ○​ Neonicotinoids: Bind to receptors that cause overactivation.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ○​ Spinosad: Disrupts insect neurotransmitters.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Regenerative Farming Recommendations 
1️⃣ Agroforestry Systems with Mixed Canopy Layers: Encourage natural predators like birds and wasps.​
2️⃣ Mulching with Neem Leaves: Neem contains natural insecticidal compounds that deter borers.​
3️⃣ Use of Beneficial Soil Microbes: Enhances tree health, making them less attractive to borers.

text:
Black Twig Borer (Xylosandrus compactus) 
Sources of Information 
●​ Wikipedia: Black Twig Borer 
●​ Journal of Applied Entomology: Biological Control of Stem Borers 
Symptoms 
●​ Sudden wilting of twigs and small branches.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ●​ Entry holes in stems with frass (insect waste).

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Preventive Actions & Why They Work 
✅ Prune and Destroy Infested Branches Early 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Prevents further spread.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
✅ Encourage Natural Predators (Woodpeckers, Parasitic Wasps) 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: These predators attack borer larvae inside the wood.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
✅ Apply Tree Wound Protectants After Pruning 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Prevents reinfestation.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Corrective Actions – Biological/Natural Methods 
🌱 Use Fungal Biocontrols (Beauveria bassiana, Metarhizium anisopliae) 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: These fungi infect and kill borers inside the bark.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
🌱 Apply Neem or Garlic-Based Sprays on Tree Bark 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Natural deterrents reduce female beetle colonization.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Corrective Actions – Chemical Treatments 
🧪 Systemic Insecticides (Imidacloprid, Acephate, Pyrethroids) 
●​ Mode of Action: 
○​ Imidacloprid: Disrupts insect nervous systems, leading to paralysis.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ○​ Acephate: Interferes with nerve transmission.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Regenerative Farming Recommendations 
1️⃣ Maintain High Organic Matter in Soil: Healthier trees resist infestations better.​
2️⃣ Incorporate Barrier Trees: Acts as a buffer zone against borer spread.​
3️⃣ Avoid Monoculture (Intercrop with Banana for example): Diversifies the ecosystem, making trees less 
attractive to borers.

text:
Coffee Leaf Miner (Leucoptera coffeella) 
Sources of Information 
●​ FAO: Integrated Pest Management for Coffee 
●​ Journal of Applied Entomology: Control of Coffee Leaf Miner 
Symptoms 
●​ White, serpentine mines on leaves.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ●​ Leaves curl and dry out.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ●​ Severe infestations cause leaf drop, reducing photosynthesis.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Preventive Actions & Why They Work 
✅ Encourage Natural Predators (E.g., Parasitic Wasps - Hymenoptera spp.)

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Parasitic wasps lay eggs inside miner larvae, preventing damage.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
✅ Use Reflective Mulch Under Trees 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Reflects sunlight, disorienting adult moths and reducing egg-laying.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
✅ Avoid Excessive Nitrogen Fertilization 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Too much nitrogen produces tender leaves, attracting more miners.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Corrective Actions – Biological/Natural Methods 
🌱 Neem Oil Sprays 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Interferes with leaf miner development and reduces egg-laying.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
🌱 Apply Beauveria bassiana (Entomopathogenic Fungus) 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: This fungus kills the larvae inside the leaves.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Corrective Actions – Chemical Treatments 
🧪 Insect Growth Regulators (IGRs) like Diflubenzuron 
●​ Mode of Action: Prevents larvae from molting, stopping their development.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
🧪 Spinosad (Natural Insecticide) 
●​ Mode of Action: Attacks the insect nervous system while being safe for beneficial insects.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Regenerative Farming Recommendations 
1️⃣ Increase Tree Diversity in Coffee Farms – Encourages natural predators like birds and parasitic wasps.​
2️⃣ Enhance Soil Health with Microbial Inoculants – Stronger trees resist infestations better.

text:
Brown Eye Spot (Cercospora coffeicola) 
Sources of Information 
●​ Perfect Daily Grind: Cercospora in Coffee 
●​ Plant Pathology Journal: Fungal Diseases in Coffee 
Symptoms 
●​ Small brown lesions with yellow halos on leaves.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ●​ Can affect both leaves and cherries.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: ●​ Causes defoliation and premature fruit drop.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Preventive Actions & Why They Work 
✅ Apply Balanced Fertilization (Especially Potassium and Calcium) 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Strengthens leaf tissue, reducing fungal penetration.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
✅ Reduce Leaf Wetness 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Fungal spores germinate in moist environments—improve airflow to dry leaves faster.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
✅ Prune Excessive Vegetation 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Lowers humidity levels, reducing infection risk.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Corrective Actions – Biological/Natural Methods 
🌱 Apply Bordeaux Mixture or Copper-Based Sprays 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Prevents fungal spore germination.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
🌱 Use Trichoderma-Based Biocontrols 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Competes with Cercospora fungi and reduces disease severity.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Corrective Actions – Chemical Treatments 
🧪 Contact Fungicides (Copper Hydroxide, Mancozeb) 
●​ Mode of Action: Prevents fungal spore germination.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
🧪 Systemic Fungicides (Azoxystrobin, Propiconazole) 
●​ Mode of Action: Disrupts fungal respiration and growth.

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text:
Regenerative Farming Recommendations 
1️⃣ Plant Shade Trees – Helps regulate leaf moisture levels.​
2️⃣ Apply Compost Tea Sprays – Strengthens plant immunity against fungal infections.​
3️⃣ Use Rock Phosphate as a Soil Amendment – Provides natural phosphorus to strengthen cell walls.

text:

text: Fungal spores spread through water splashes.

text:

text: Reduces humidity, preventing fungal germination.

✅ Plant Resistant Coffee Varieties (E.g., Sarchimor) 
●​ Why?

metadata.filename: RAG - Robusta - Known pest and diseases.pdf

text: Has genetic resistance to anthracnose.

text:

text: Natural antifungal properties reduce disease severity.

text:

text: Competes with Colletotrichum fungi, suppressing disease development.

text:

text:
🧪 Copper-Based Fungicides (Bordeaux Mixture, Copper Oxychloride) 
●​ Mode of Action: Forms a protective barrier, preventing fungal infection.
